In SC we encounter the santana crow, described as having blade wings (maṅhəlar curiga): əntasniya sakeṅ kavah, diparabkən ka asu di pañcasora, asu maṅtəndas iyaksa, gagak maṅhəlar curiga, təhərna mava ruji bəsi, dəṅ na gagak santana “After being lifted up from the cauldron, he is given as food to the Five-Sounded dogs, dogs with yakṣas as their head, the crow with blade wings, then they take the iron fencing, together with the crow [called] Santana”. The word santana is probably none other than patana (see fn. 339). This passage runs parallel with Kuñj 13: hana ta pākṣi yakṣa si ṣantana ṅaranya, gagak (all mss. AHK; gālak Kern) mahəlar curigā, kaṇḍaga pinakākukunya, kukunya bajra (H and K; kuku mānval bajra A and Kern) mahəlar kaṇḍaga, mavulu (H; mamava hru K; mavaruṅ A and Kern) tajī “There are the ghost-birds called Santana, the crows with blade wings, having swords as their nails, their nails are made of iron, having blades as wings, having spikes as feathers”. In Uttarakāṇḍa 32, the crow is Yama’s incarnation when he faces Rāvaṇa. The crow mentioned together with the dog, both representing sinners, is also found in SHH 5.12: hilaṅa ikaṅ bāyu śabda hədap sakeṅ śārīranya məne, ndatan mulya pih asiṅ vvaṅ magaməl, tinimpalakən raśmi, pinarəbutakən deniṅ gagak mvaṅ asu iku “When the breath, the speech, and the mind are now gone from their body, whatever people do is worthless. The beauty (of the body) is turned off, as the crow and the dog fight over it”.
  346. ^346. The word curavəda is clearly derived from Skt. curavāda (= OJ) ‘speaking untruths’.
  347. ^347. I take -na in atmana as a possessive suffix, even though the word atmana as a synonym of atma is attested. Cf. Kuñj 2306 (van der Molen 1983: 229) piraṅ kee hatmana riṅ sarira, limma kvehnya, mapa lvirnya “How many numbers are the soul in the body? Its number is five. What is the form”?
  348. ^348. The conjunction mana is suspicious here, and should possibly be emended to atmana. If this is the correct emendation, then the translation would be ‘his soul is far from rebirth’.
  349. ^349. Unidentified animal. In SC 825–830, we read oter instead of koter: təmah saṅ hyaṅ atma papa, jadi oter jadi jaṅgel, jambəloṅ limus sakərət, kararamu hapur muṅkal, satva kinaririsan, satva kinavədian ‘the consequence of the sinful soul, [is that] it becomes oter and jaṅgel, jambəloṅ and leatherleaf slug, kararamu and hapur muṅkal, despised [and] disgusting animals’. Is it equivalent to OJ kulir? Cf. also MdJ bolèr ‘small fruit worm’.
  350. ^350. Unidentified animal. In MdS, jaṅgel means ‘corn cob’, but here probably refers to a kind of worm or leech whose appearance is resembled corn cob?
  351. ^351. The species hiləd tahun is likely to refer to a kind of caterpillar. Kompas 30 May 2011 reported a high population of caterpillars in Gunung Kidul, one of the species being called ulat tahun (see https://amp.kompas.com/ekonomi/read/2011/05/30/0533052/policy.html). Cf. OJ ulər tahun. See SKK 1.2 where tahun means crop. Is it related to Mal. ulat daun?
  352. ^352. The word pitək ‘horse-fly, gadfly, warble-fly’, as in MdS. Cf. Mal. pikat, OJ caṭak.
  353. ^353. In MdS, titiṅgi refers to a kind of millipede. Cf. Mal. kaki seribu.
  354. ^354. The word jambəloṅ is not found in MdS, but is probably equivalent with MdS katélong (a kind of big centipede). Tien Wartini et al. 2011 interpret jambəloṅ as ‘lintah kerbau, lintah besar dan hitam yang tempat hidupnya di tanah lembab’. Cf. MdJ təmbalong ‘a certain large centipede’ (Horne 1974, s.v.).
  355. ^355. On limus sakərət, see my comment on the OJ word hiris pvah in SiGu 8.4.
  356. ^356. mear is not recorded in MdS, but I googled it and found that in Bogor people still recognize it as a kind of leech. This word is also known as the toponym of kampung in Jasinga, Bogor.
  357. ^357. pacet = Mal. (also pacat). Cf. OJ and MdJ pacət ‘kind of leech’ (Haemadipsa teylandica).
  358. ^358. Both ləhəṅ and gərəṅ are unidentified animals.
  359. ^359. The word harən is not found in dictionaries, and my translation ‘anxiety’ is based on the tentative assumption of a connection with MdS hara-haraeun ‘present difficulties, raise objections, unfavorable (of a place or time where all kinds of things are lacking, a place difficult to pass, a bad and dangerous road, etc.)’. Hardjadibrata relates hara-haraeun to MdS ara, aru-ara and uru-ara ‘commotion, stir, disquiet, unrest, uproar’. In KS 6.11–26 we read sakti atma ləpas, ləñəpniṅ rupa bayu, revaca saṅ harən saṅ harəsa, “Strongly, the soul has vanished, the dissolution of the breath’s form, the anxiety and lust are revaca (?)”.
  360. ^360. In this sentence, pahi cannot have a meaning ‘all’ referring to the subject like we have in other contexts, but serving as an adverb. Cf, Mal. serba tahu. Another adverbial meaning is attested in RR 1480–1481 padoyoṅ pahi daékna, silih taña kahayaṅna “matching each other with equal strength, asking each other what they wanted”.
  361. ^361. The author uses the combination arum mavaṅi instead of ruum avaṅi, reflecting a Javanese code switching; cf. Kuñj 335–336 (ms H in van der Molen edition): śammida dupa (em. śammi dadupa ed.) mrabukk arum pavaṅi. In Old Sundanese corpus, see KaPañ 719 ruum buṅbuṅ gandavaṅi, SA 824 ruum miṅiṅ ganda vaṅi, SC 316 ruum səṅit rumavaṅi. The word rumavaṅi in SC 316 seems to be a brief variant of ruum avaṅi.
  362. ^362. I choose the reading B bənaṅna instead of bənaṅ by comparing this passage with SKK 8.3 ku bənaṅna ilik di guna sakalih. Cf. bənaṅna ñaho in SKK 18.4.
  363. ^363. The expression of labuh siloka is attested in SC 310 misi na labuh siloka ‘having endowed (misi) with suitable words’. In MdS, labuh means ‘fall (because of slipping, bumping against st., etc.); ngalabuhkeun let so. fall (on his face); balabuh be (lie, ride) at anchor’. Cf. OJ alabuh ‘to cast os. down (on or into st.) and seek one’s death’. I presume that milabuh siloka is similar in meaning to the expression manibakən sastra ‘to execute the writing’, from tiba ‘to fall’.
  364. ^364. The word basana is at first sight ambiguous. In MdS, basa can have two meanings: first, it can be a conjunction ‘when, at the time of’; second, it can be a noun, ‘language, word’. In OS, the first meaning is more common (cf. SKK 12.2). But here the word basana appears between the particle ma and the punctuation mark, followed by a list of vocative words to the relatives, indicating that the meaning intended by the author must have been ‘his words’.
  365. ^365. In MdS utun means ‘(a friendly term of address for boys and young men) boys, lads; utun inji (name of an unborn foetus) boy-girl; cf. inji’. In OS, most occurrences are vocative, although the use as common noun also appears in the combination with si (si utun ‘the child’).
  366. ^366. The word eten is exclusively used as a vocative in the OS corpus at my disposal. It is attested in KaPaṅ passim, used by Jayakeling to address his wife, and by Batara Guru to his daughter Sri in KaKat.
  367. ^367. The word lañcək ‘elder brother’ is not necessarily gender-specific, but it tends to be used for male addressees. Cf. MdS pun lanceuk ‘my husband’ (a wife when addressing her husband). The presence of əcə in the list also suggests that the author intended to list both a term for a male and for a female elder sibling.
  368. ^368. Cf. vastu in OJ (OJED s.v. vastu 2) ‘to declare that something will or must certainly happen, to lay down (also by means of a blessing or curse), to settle (give a pronouncement with vastu)’; also pamastu = paṅastu (from vastu?) KHWj 2.116b: ḍuh pukulun dumadak pamastu paduka saṅ mahamuni. I interpret paṅvastu as ‘salutation, blessing’ in the light of the meaning of pangésto or pangéstu in MdS, namely ‘blessing, exclamation of blessing, opening term; (esp. used as a polite term when replying if asked how he, the family is’.
  369. ^369. The dasa-pasanta in this passage seems to be a localization case from the concept daśa-pāramitā found in SiGu 11. For the notion of dasa-pasanta influenced by Buddhist teachings, see Chapter 10, §Borrowing Buddhist Doctrines.
  370. ^370. The translation of guna as ‘virtuous’ is based on the explanation in SMG 22.1 ini ma iña hayu na təmən, diṅaranan saṅ hyaṅ dasa-sila, dasa ta ma sapuluh, sila ta ma ṅaranna guna “As for this one, it is the essence of goodness, called the ten holy virtues (saṅ hyaṅ dasa-sila). Dasa means ten, sila means virtuous”.
  371. ^371. In OJ and OS, the word nama in the meaning ‘salutation, reverential’ only occurs in invocations. The base form in Skt. is namas, probably the OJ and OS derivation nama from namas is similar to OJ tapa < Skt. tapas.
  372. ^372. In MdS, we find hook only in the suffixed form hookeun ‘stand looking dumbfounded/ disconcerted’. The context suggests a meaning like ‘sympathy’ or ‘enthusiasm’. No other occurrence is found in OS texts.
  373. ^373. On the meaning of pesok, See my comment on this word in SMG 20.5.
  374. ^374. See my comment on the word mukpruk in SMG 20.5. For the /k/ ~ /ø/ variation, see Chapter 3, §Phonology.
  375. ^375. In MdS, ulas means ‘to polish st., coat st., spread st. (e.g. with paint, whitewash, ointment, salve, oil, etc., also in conjunction with moistening of materials with water in the traditional way of weaving). I suggest that it should be related to MdS and Mal. elus ‘handle so. tactfully, talk to s.o. quietly, softly, sooth, calm, appease s.o.’.
  376. ^376. Based on the context, this metaphor seems to refer to parigəiṅ.
  377. ^377. The occurrence in this context of the word pañcaksara, designating the Skt. phrase namaś śivāya, or ‘Homage to Śiva!’, seems to imply that it was in common use as a polite greeting to interlocutors. See examples of salutations nama sivaya in Chapter 10, §God among gods.
  378. ^378. The occurrence of loganda in this context is comparable to Mal. compounds with similar imitative reduplication: porak-poranda, karut-marut. See Sneddon 2010: 26.
  379. ^379. On the word caṅciṅ, see my comment on ; cf. SKK 8.1.
  380. ^380. The word imuc corresponds to MdS imut ‘smile’. See Chapter 3, §Phonology.
  381. ^381. The base word of pabuntəlan, viz. buntəl, means ‘to wrap, to roll’ in MdS. Cf. OJ vuntəl, avuntəlan ‘with a wrapping of..., with… intertwined’ attested in KY 31.2: dyah maṅken pasavit gaḍuṅ rari gəluṅta linaraṅan avuntəlan səkar where Soewito Santoso translates it as ‘decorated’: “Milady, now you must wear a necklace of gadung flowers and your hair knot may not be decorated with flowers anymore”. Seeing the relation of vuntəl with flowers, it may be that pabuntəlan refers to a place where rolled objects — probably leaves with flowers like we find in Bali nowadays — are offered. Pabuntelan is also recorded as a toponym in south Bandung (Lasmiati 2016: 389).
  382. ^382. The term imah manəh only occurs in this text and in Sri Ajñana. In the latter, imah manəh occurs five times, referring to the abode of the Five Gods (pañca-devata), located in the upper world. Could it be referring tocaṇḍi-type shrines?
  383. ^383. The word liṅgir is a variant of liṅir ‘carved or chiseled image’ (OJED, s.v.). Cf. haṅər = aṅgər.
  384. ^384. Zoetmulder defines gaṅsa as ‘bell-metal’ (OJED, s.v.). He mentions its occurrence in SD 29.8: kəṇḍaṅ goṅ gaṅsa gubar asahuran “kendang drum, gong, gangsa, and small gong (gubar) are sounding alternately”, in which gaṅsa clearly refers to a music instrument, but it is unclear whether it is distinct from goṅ, or is a particular kind of goṅ. SC 1110–1114 also mentions batu gaṅsa among objects in a shrine: aṅgəs ma eta sakitu, ditəndən liṅga liṅgir, candi baṅ candi putih, candi hejo candi kuniṅ, harəca dəṅ batu gaṅsa “After [mentioning] all of that, lingga and statue are placed [in] the red and white sanctuaries, green and yellow sanctuaries, [along with] sculptures and the gaṅsa stones”. Cf. BM 98–99 iṅ na gooṅ braṅ na gaṅsa, seah na gəndaṅ sarunay which Noorduyn & Teeuw translate as “the gongs droned, the cymbals sounded, the drums and the shawms were played”. West (2021) prefers to translates gaṅsa as ‘flat gong’. In MdS, gangsa means ‘bronze’ (for basins, gongs, etc.). In MdJ, it means ‘1 classical Javanese musical instrument or ensemble of instruments (kr for gamelan). 2 bronze. 3 gamelan gong’. The term batu gaṅsa is perhaps equivalent to what is called batu goong in the Sundanese-speaking area nowadays. Examples of this kind of stone, scattered around a lingga, are found at Situs Citaman, Pulosari, Banten, known as Batu Goong.
  385. ^385. These figures occur (with some variant readings) in the Carita Parahyaṅan among the ultimate ancestors of Sundanese kings. According to this chronicle, Rahyangta Déwaraja and Rahyangta ri Medang refer to one figure, Kandiawan. Déwaraja is the name he bore before he became an ascetic, while Rahyangta ri Medang is the name he took after becoming a rajarəsi. In the same narrative, Rawung Langit is the fourth of the five sons of Kandiawan, who ruled as king before Mandimiñak. The last figure, who also seems to be the most important, is Rahyangta ri Mənir, the other name of Wreti Kandayun, the incarnation of the fifth kusika, Patañjala. He is attributed as the creator of Purbatisti and Purbajati, the two main scriptures of the ascetic group (karəsian).
  386. ^386. In OJtexts, janmarahasya means ‘the secret of life’, but here it seems to be used of menn who have secret knowledge, so we are dealing with a local reinterpretation of the term. For an occurrence of janmarahasya in the OJ corpus, see KuñjDhK 21.1 yekin janmarahasya mūlya pavarahkv iri kita pituhun, ndah yatneriya paṅrəṅə̄ varavarahku tan imanimanən “This is the sublime secret of human life — take to heart these teachings of mine to you, listen attentively to my lessons and do not treat them lightly”.
  387. ^387. The word ləñəp is a synonym of mokta. Cf. SMG 33.3 ini kaləpasənana ṅaranya, saṅ hyaṅ nirmala, ya catur-mokta ṅaranya, ləpas, ləñəp, mokta, hilaṅ, ya ta catur-mokta ṅaranya “This is called the release, the holy purity. It is called the four final liberations (catur-mokta): release, disappearance, vanishing, dissolution. That is called the four final liberations”. Cf. also Mal. lenyap ‘diminished’.
  388. ^388. Based on the context, what is meant by ‘people in the present’ here refers to deified ancestors mentioned in 15.1.
  389. ^389. Cf. the similar expression in SiGu 6.1 ndya ya nihan saṅ hyaṅ jagat upadrava ṅaranya, ndya ya, nihan, hala tuməmu halanya, hayu tuməmu hayunya, vilut tuməmu vilutnya, bənər tumemu bənərnya, sukha tuməmu sukhanya, duhkha tuməmu duhkhanya. This expression alludes to the notion of karma. See Chapter 10, §Siksa Kurung.
  390. ^390. The mss. AB spell paramarata instead of paramarta (Skt./OJ paramārtha). This is common in the OS corpus: cf. RD 45 tuturnya paramarata “His consciousness is prominent”, PR 19r4 ləvih balik alit sarira sunya-paramarata “superior while returning to the subtle element, the body whose nec plus ultra is the void”. I take paramarta with lokika as compound, lokika-paramarta. It is an attribute to the viku, so that viku lokika-paramarta means ‘the vikus for whom the nec plus ultra is worldly’.
  391. ^391. It is noteworthy that ms. A consistently spells centana and acentana. These spelling variants are also attested in ms. A of the Kuñjarakarṇa (also of West Javanese provenance): Kuñj 808 centanātma; 1805 centāna (ed. van der Molen 1983).
  392. ^392. See my comment on a similar expression ṅrətakən bumi in SKK 12.2.
  393. ^393. In the Old Sundanese context, the word liñok is only found once in this text and nowhere else. Even in OJ, this word only appears in later texts such as Koravāśrama, Bhīma Svarga, and Pararaton.
  394. ^394. The word drəbya ‘possession’ in this context refers to the internal possessions of the holy man, i.e., the macrocosmic and microcosmic world (bhuvana lavan śārīra), and the three instruments (bāyu, śabda, hədap). Cf. SHH 18.1 sira ta sinaṅguh saṅ hyaṅ pramāṇa, makadrabya bhuvana lavan sarva śārīra, ṅuniveh bāyu śabda hədap “He is considered as The Authority, having the world and body as possessions, also the breath, the speech, [and] the mind”. It seems that the author intends to associate bāyu, śabda, hədap to the three rulers. On mahayu as a transitive verb, cf. mahayu na kadatvan ‘to beautify the palace’ in the inscription Kawali 1a (Aditia Gunawan & Griffiths 2021: 184–185).
  395. ^395. On the concept of tri-tantu, see Chapter 10.
  396. ^396. The pronoun kita only appears here in the whole SKK. See Chapter 3, §Pronoun.
  397. ^397. Cf. bumi lamba in SKK 1.3 and 1.4.
  398. ^398. The word vartamanah is from Skt. vartamāna ‘present, existing; the present, in the present time’. On unetymological -h and -k, see Chapter 3, §Phonology.
  399. ^399. The word palikən is not recorded in dictionaries. It seems implausible to emend it to palika ‘diver’ (found in SKK 7.3) since it is mentioned along with the list of people related to religious institutions. Might there be any connection with the Skt. term kāpālika? See OJED kapālikabrata ‘of the observance of the Kapālikas’ (the correct spellings would have been kāpālika- and Kāpālikas).
  400. ^400. My interpretation of aməṅ as wandering ascetics is based on Bujaṅga Manik, the protagonist of the eponymous text. Another name for the protagonist is aməṅ layaran, attributed when the ascetic stepped off a boat, anchored in Kalapa during his first return from pilgrims as a hermit in eastern Java.
  401. ^401. On the interpretation of the term vaśi, see Appendix 1.
  402. ^402. For an explanation of the term əbon, see Chapter 11.
  403. ^403. My translation assumes thatəvah is equivalent to MdS euwah-euwah ‘scoundrel, thief, robber; manuk euwah-euwah (C.) bird of prey’. Without proposing any gloss, OJED records aṅəvah as attested in Sum 10.9 solah bhāvanirāmaṅun sih aṅəvah bapa-bapa juga denirāṅucap. This has been translated as “Everything she did aroused affection, even if she could only sigh ( aṅəvah) and say ‘da, da’”. (ed. and trans. Worsley et al. 2013). Worsley et al. have taken the word aṅəvah to be a variant of aṅəhah (cf. OJED uməhah, s.v. əhah), meaning ‘to sigh, moan’). This OJ evidence does not seem to furnish a more promising angle of interpretation than MdS euwah-euwah.
  404. ^404. In the light of SMG 19.2 it is clear that masaṅ refers to an agricultural activity: tani ma ṅaranya, paka dibuat ñadap masaṅ ñavara, cocooan, pəpəlakan, ya tani ṅaranya “The farmer (tani) means: [they] are advanced (paka) in harvesting rice (dibuat), in tapping, in putting the yoke, in planting paddy (? ñavara), in taking care of the livestock, in planting the crops”.
  405. ^405. I supply a comma after maṅhurip, since in OS this word is usually placed at the end of a clause or a sentence. Cf. FCP 26r3: kita tuturkənən voṅ sakabeh, pinakadədəlan bvana, pinakadasarniṅ prətivi, andəlan sarva maṅhurip “you are the person to be followed by all people, serving as the support of the world, as the foundation of the earth, the stabilizer of all living beings”. In this case, maṅhurip ‘to live’ seems to be intransitive, and it corresponds to OJ (m)ahurip ‘to live, living’, not to (m)aṅhurip ‘to give life, to grant life’.
  406. ^406. In this context, vastu probably means ‘substance’. Cf. the name of the Sundanese King, Wastu Kancana, literally meaning ‘the substance of gold’ or Lingga Wastu ‘whose essence is the lingga’ in CVG; cf. KaPaṅ 202 ṅaranna vastu muliya ‘its name is the priceless essence’.
  407. ^407. This sentence and the one that follows are syntactically problematic because of the conjunction kena, whereas we expect a conjunction that expresses the meaning ‘only’ or ‘but’, such as ṅan, heṅan, or OJ words like kunaṅ, kintu which mean ‘but’ and have the same consonants as kena despite being unattested in OS. Another way to fix the syntax of this sentence would be to skip ruana janma in the first sentence and rampes yuni and rampes baṅsa in the second sentence, so that kena would make sense in the expected meaning ‘because’. Cf. The similar syntax in SKK 8.2 and 8.3.
  408. ^408. We find several occurrences where the word əsi refers to the person. Cf. aya ma nu ṅəsi dayəh ivə ‘If one resides here’ in Kawali 6 (Aditia Gunawan & Griffiths 2021: 188). Cf. əsi imahna ‘wife’ in SKK 12.6.
  409. ^409. In the corresponding SMG passage (17.1), we have urija (or vurija in ms. B). See my comment on urija in SMG 17.1.
  410. ^410. I interpret ṅaromboṅ based on one of the meanings of rombong in Malay, viz. ‘piling or heaping up’. This word is clearly connected to Mal. rombongan ‘a group’. Wilkinson also notes rombong as ‘Malacca basket; this is a basket of fine pandan matwork made usually in a set to nest one within the other; in shape round, triangular or polygonal; each basket having a separate overlapping cover. But the older rombong was of larger size and used for storing rice; tĕrubong. The small sizes (known also as kĕmbal) are used as work-baskets, sireh-baskets, etc.’.
  411. ^411. The verb ñigi is not recorded in dictionaries. However, Hardjadibrata notes its base sigi in the dialect register which means ‘end of warp yarns (hanging like a fringe)’.
  412. ^412. Cf. OJ unte, aṅunte, inunte, aṅunte-hunte ‘to twist together, wind (cf. MdS untay)’. Cf. Mal. untai ‘a chain; numeral coefficient for necklace, etc.’.
  413. ^413. My interpretation of məṅpəṅ is based on the meaning of pəṅpəṅ in OJ ‘(subst.) being used at the right moment’. Cf. MdS meungpeung ‘while it is still ... (do st. that is not possible later, make the best while o. can)’. This word hence seems to be synonymous with OJ səḍəṅ ‘right time (not too early or too late), right moment, right measure (not too big or too small)’. I presume that məṅpəṅ is not only related to time, but also to measure or position.
  414. ^414. mañcir can be recognized from MdS pañcir ‘wedge’, while mancir means ‘use a wedge (e.g. in splitting wood), drive a wedge in somewhere’.
  415. ^415. My emendation of ṅagitaka to ṅaṅgit aṅka is based on the explanation of ñigəṅ which seems to be related to the activity of measuring and apportioning. In MdS, ṅaṅgit means ‘to compose/write st. (a story, speech, etc.) in beautiful form/in elegant style; write st. in verse form)’, while in OJ we only find its passive form inaṅgit meaning ‘to interlace, make into a garland’. It seems that the latter is the original meaning, while MdS reflects a secondary development. In OS, only the base form is attested in SC aṅgit artati dəṅ prəlabi ‘the composition of Artati and Prelabi’. The word aṅka also occurs in OS, e.g. in BM 1300 bənaṅ aiṅ adu aṅka which Noorduyn & Teeuw translate as “what was the result of my weighing inten­tions”. I prefer to translate this phrase as “as the result of my calculation”. The compound ṅaṅgit aṅka (litt. ‘to compose numbers’) seems to be synonymous with adu aṅka (litt. ‘to match numbers’), involving a verb and a noun. On this basis, I interpret ṅaṅgit aṅka as ‘to calculate.
  416. ^416. The number of skills (guna) listed here is six, which is reminiscent of the Skt. and OJ concept of ṣaḍguṇa. What is remarkable is that the six gunas here are entirely different from those we find in OJ sources, where the same terms refer primarily to the ability of the king: sandhi ‘peace’, vigraha ‘war’, āyana ‘marching’, āsana ‘sitting encamped’, dvaidhībhāva ‘dividing his force’, and saṅśraya ’seeking the protection of a more powerful king’ (OJED, s.v. ṣaḍguṇa). The OJ tradition is in conformity with Sanskrit sources, such as Arthaśāstra 7.1.6–12 where the six are listed in prose (transl. Olivelle 2013), while they are listed in verse-form at MDhŚ 7.160: saṁdhiṁ ca vigrahaṁ caiva yānam āsanam eva ca | dvaidhībhāvaṁ saṁśrayaṁ ca ṣaḍguṇāṁś cintayet sadā “He should constantly think about the sixfold strategy: forging alliances, waging war, marching into battle, remaining stationary, pursuing a double stratagem, and seeking asylum” (ed. and transl. Olivelle 2005). In our text, the ṣaḍguṇa is recontextualized, being applied to servants.
  417. ^417. For the interpretation of purna as healthy, see OJED (s.v. pūrṇa 4) ‘restored to its former condition’. Cf. SMG 19.2 purna ṅaranya, hantə dibogakahivaṅan, kativasan “the one who is healthy (purna) means [the one who] does not have defects and diseases”.
  418. ^418. Probably kabava ku should be emended to kabava ka, but kabava ku is very common, while kabava ka never occurs in the OS corpus. Cf. KaPani 440 saṅkan jalma kalolita, kabava ku para yuga “It is the reason why people are convulsed, [and] taken by various yugas”. The term yuga here seems to have a negative connotation.
  419. ^419. The noun sorga preceded by the word para occurs several times in the OS corpus, e.g. in SA 1083–1084 nu ṅəsi rahina sada, pañaraman para sorga “who lives in Rahina Sada, the lessons of all celestials”; PR 63v pahi mijil ti niskala, lain ti na para sorga “All appears from the unmanifest, but not from all kinds of heavens”. The meaning of para sorga seems to vary with the contexts, sometimes indicating celestial beings, sometimes a celestial place. I believe that the latter is intended in this context. This meaning also occurs in KaMah 1455–1457 eboh ta aiṅ magahan, eta tu na para sorga, kasorgaan voṅ sajagat “Here I would like to give [you] advice, that is all kind of heavens, heavens for all people in the world”. Cf. para nusa ‘all kinds of countries’ in SKK 11.31. See Chapter 10, §Cosmology.
  420. ^420. The expression kədi malavadiṅ is undoubtedly equivalent to OJ kəḍi valavadi. OJED glosses kəḍi as ‘emasculated, eunuch’ and valavadi as ‘a woman and not yet a woman. Prob. Skt abala, impotent, and vadhri, castrated’. On the OJ expression, Acri (2017: 229, fn. 47) notes as follows: “ kəḍi valavadi is used in an identical context in the Vr̥haspatitattva, the Tattvajñāna and the Ślokāntara (11–12.2). The last text employs the two words to explain the Sanskrit sequence klīvo ’balo vadhriḥ, as follows: ṅaranya kəḍi, valavadi ṅaranya strī tan strī—‘klīva (from klība, emasculated) means eunuch, valavadi means a woman and yet not a woman’. Vr̥haspatitattva 33.64 explains kəḍi and valavadi as janmāntarapuruṣa, which would translate as ‘transsexual’”.
  421. ^421. The spelling kaduka (for Skt. kaṭuka) is also found in the SiGu parallel. As for tikta, none of the witnesses of SiGu has a correct reading according to Sanskrit spelling. However, ms. C reads tritta, which could be interpreted as a small error for trikta (due to the resemblance of aksaras ka and ta). It should be noted that the word trikta was probably the common OS spelling for Skt. tikta. However, since it is intended as a gloss, I normalize both terms according to Sanskrit spelling in SKK and SiGu. On the spontaneous /r/, see Chapter 3, §Phonology.
  422. ^422. ‘Astringent’ is the meaning of kaṣāya in Skt. and OJ, but the gloss shows that our author understood it differently. The currency of his interpretation in West Java is confirmed by SiGu 2.5.
  423. ^423. On lada as meaning ‘spicy’, see my comment on SiGu 2.5, where the word lada is used in the same meaning and in the same context, even though that text is formulated in OJ.
  424. ^424. Cf. the similar list in AG 1v rakeyan darmasikṣa, siya ṅavarah anak, əñcu, umpi, cicip, muniṅ, aṅgasantana, kulasantana, prətisantana, aṅgasaṅ parigal vit vəkas kulakadaṅ sakabeh “The venerable Darmasiksa instructs his children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, great-great-grandchildren, muniṅ, aṅgasantana, kulasantana, prətisantana, aṅgasaṅ parigal, ultimate descendants, his entire family”. Cf. also OJ lists of descendants, mainly found in inscriptions, such as the Lintakan charter (841 Śaka) 3r20–21: maṅkanā lavasanyan· tmuAkan· sāṁsāra, Avaknya rabinya Anaknya putunya puyutnya Aṅgasnya nāhan· liṁnirar paṅhanākan· sapatha matəhər· mamantiṅakan· hantlū manətək· gulūniṁ hayam· “‘That is how long they will find suffering, themselves, their wives, their children, their grandchildren, their great-grandchildren, and their great-great-grandchildren’. Those were his words as he set the curse. Then he smashed the egg, slit the chicken’s throat” (draft ed. and transl. by Tyassanti Kusumo Dewanti, Wayan Jarrah Sastrawan & Arlo Griffiths). ​​Gandhakuti (964 Śaka) 2v2–2v3 katmva de santāna prātisantānira, Anak putu buyut· cicik muniṁ pituṁ Aṅśa siraji pādukā mpuṅku “would be obtained by his offspring and offspring’s offspring: children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, great-great-grandchildren, the seven [generations of] descendants of Aji Pāduka Mpuṅku” (draft ed. and transl. by Arlo Griffiths & Eko Bastiawan). On the term aṅśa, see Griffiths 2020: 118–122.
  425. ^425. I interpret putu vəkas as compound. In OJ and MdS, putu means grandchild, while OJ vəkas means ‘1. the last of a stretch in time or space, end, limit, final aim; finally; 2. the highest point, top, height, what surpasses all others, paramount, non plus ultra, first, best or worst’. Cf. vit vəkas in OJ.
  426. ^426. The word dipikakolotan, which I translate as ’to be given in inheritance’, is not found in the dictionary. The meaning is based on context. The circumfix dipi- -an is used to form verbs with a causative meaning. The basic form is kakolotan, from kolot ‘old, parents’, which probably means the same as kabuyutan ‘sacred’, also ‘heirloom’, which is derived from buyut ‘great-grandfather, elder’. Cf. dipikabuyutan in SMG 3.7.
  427. ^427. In MdS as in Mal., balañja means ‘shopping’, but Rigg notes babalanja ‘to do marketing, to make purchases of household commodities’. It makes more sense to take it from lañja ‘add a second layer to the first one, cover in (over/up) st.; repeat a job or action; take a second one to a woman; take a second one to a moneylender/supplier’. So probably babalañjaan is a nominal derivation which means something like ‘leasing, leasehold, subletting’. The last meaning is attested in a small number of OJ inscriptions. In the Palepangan inscription, for instance, we find: len· sumaṅkā rika hana ta savaḥ bhaṭāra kmitan· rāmanta lamvit· 1 dmak·ni p⟨ū⟩ja [em., pāja insc.], mūla lamvit· 1 tan inukur· Ikā Āpan· hĭnanyan· svabhāvanya, muAṁ lañjān· pirak· dhā 14 patukan· pirak· dhā 4| panurat· pirak· mā 4 | “Besides them there was 1 lamvit of paddy field of the deity kept by the elders as endowment for the cult (pūja) — the value (mūla) of 1 lamvit was not measured, because of the destituteness of its condition — with the income from subletting (lañjān) of 14 dhāraṇa of silver; the patukan of 4 māṣa of silver; the panurat of 4 dhāraṇa of silver” (draft ed. and transl. by Griffiths 2020; cf. Bosch 1917, Bijlage M: 88–98; Boechari 1985–1986: 124–126). However, the reduplication babalañjaan seems unnatural: should we emend it to babak lañjaan? In MdS, the word babakan means newly founded hamlet.
  428. ^428. Instead of aṅkara, may be it should emend ambara into saṅhara based on ṅahara in H? So cipta saṅhara yield a meaning ‘destructive mind’.
  429. ^429. My emendation dipikaritakən is proposed in the light of the occurrence of krīta ‘purchased slave’ in an OJ legal text that comments on MDhŚ 8.415: dhvajāhr̥to bhaktadāso gr̥hajaḥ krītadattrimau | paitriko daṇḍadāsaś ca saptaite dāsayonayaḥ || “There are seven kinds of slaves: a man captured in war, a man who makes himself a slave to receive food, a slave born in the house, a purchased slave, a gifted slave, a hereditary slave, and a man enslaved for punishment”. This śloka is paraphrased in BAV (5v): ka, panaṅkaniṅ kavulā, tavan, kavula saṅke pinaṅan, krīta, ulihiṅ anuku, datrimah, ṅa, kavula paveveh “The meaning is: the origins of the slave are the captive, the slave from lack of food, the krīta, i.e. the result of purchase, the datrimah, i.e. gifted slave”. In Skt. krīta means ‘bought, purchased; purchased from his natural parents (as a son; one of the twelve kinds of sons acknowledged by the ancient Hindū law)’. In this light, it seems plausible that the base form to which the circumfix dipi- -kən is applied was a word deriving from Skt. krīta, and karita seems to be the closest fit with the ms. readings. The context of nəbus vadon ‘to redeem a woman’ strengthens my hypothesis. It is also possible that dipikaritikən is the intended reading, if we can postulate a locally prevalent form kariti as feminine of karita (although the fem. of krīta would actually be krītā in Skt.).
  430. ^430. I interpret susuk as ‘foundation’ based on the usage of the verb ñusuk which can imply the meaning ‘to build, to open up, to found’. For a discussion of the word ñusuk, see Aditia Gunawan & Griffiths 2021: 152–153.
  431. ^431. The meaning ‘immediately’ is not recorded for tuluy in Sundanese dictionaries and GNT. However, in OJ, tuluy has this meaning. See OJED s.v. tuluy ‘immediate continuation’, tumuluy, tumulvi, tumul ‘to continue immediately, to proceed from one thing to the next; to go straight on, penetrate; thereupon, straight away’.
  432. ^432. The use of the word jati in this context is intriguing since it seems to imply the meaning that jāti typically has in India, namely ‘caste’. The notion of caste is absent in Old Sundanese sources. However, in SKK we see a clear social hierarchy placing the hulun below the tohaan. It may therefore be that jati means ‘caste’ in a loose sense, referring to the low status of the hulun.
  433. ^433. Instead of reading the phrase as bətəṅ diri ti pañjara, another possibility is to render it as bətəṅ di riti-pañjara, which can be interpreted as ‘ceased from the bronze cage’. The word riti is indeed unattested in OS, but it occurs in OJ as a kind of metal. OJED glosses uncertain meanings: ‘a certain metal (bronze, brass?). Cf. PYñ 8.3 hana vəsi riti tambaga matahi-tahi “there are the rusty iron, bronze (? riti), [and] copper”; Tk 1.101b makadi dhātu riti tambaga mvaṅ vəsi vaja rajata kañcana “especially the mineral, bronze, copper, and also iron, steel, silver, [and] gold”; TK 62.35 dhātu vəsi riri (r. riti) tambaga salaka “mineral, iron, bronze, copper, silver”.
  434. ^434. The word dipitotohkən is from toh, which in OJ has the meaning ‘stake (in game, gambling, wager, competition, combat); main stake (in combat)’ (OJED, s.v. toh II). However, it seems that the meaning intended by the author is more related to OJ taruh, anaruh ‘to compete with, vie with, challenge’ (OJED, s.v. taruh), so that in our context it can be rendered as ‘to match’. In MdS, the only related word is bobotoh, meaning ‘the pers. who leads in a cockfight or gambling’. Cf. also OJ adu which has the double meaning ‘to put face to face, bring into contact, make clash, have fight, pit against; to vie in, measure’ and ‘to mix, blend ingredients’ (OJED, s.v. adu).
  435. ^435. The word leṅkeṅ with the meaning of ‘venereal disease’ is only recorded in Rigg (1862, s.v. léngkéng).
  436. ^436. The word kaparisədək is a passive ka- form derived from the secondary base pisədək, with the infix -ar-. See Chapter 3, §Morphology.
  437. ^437. The form pakasabda is remarkable. In OJ, it occurs in Bhomāntaka 100.12c dhvaniniṅ gəlap śatasahasrakoṭi pakaśabdaniṅ prəp anitir, translated by Teeuw & Robson as “The din of a hundred thousand thunderclaps was the sound of the repeated punches”. Their comment on this form is as follows: “pakaśabda ‘was the sound’: a remarkable construction with the prefix paka- literally ‘served as’. Does the author simply mean the sound of the repeated punches was like the din...?”. I rather choose to take it as imperative, based on the occurrence of turut tvah in the previous clause.
  438. ^438. I interpret kasukma as an equivalent of sinūkṣma in OJ ‘to absorb completely (make into the sūkṣma, the essence, of one’s heart)’. Another possibility is to take kasukma as a noun, then the alternative translation would be ‘those who expect the secret of the good words’.
  439. ^439. For a discussion of pun, see Aditia Gunawan & Griffiths 2021: 150–151.

. <colophon>
50 <quote type="normalized">mula manibakən sastra duk iṅ teja <supplied reason="undefined">di</supplied>vasan, huvus iṅ vulan katiga pun, ini babar iṅ pustakanipun, nora catur sagara vulan.</quote>
. <quote type="translation">The beginning of copying the text was around noon; it was finished in the third month. This is the disclosure in the book: zero-four-sea-moon (1440 Śaka).</quote>
. <note>Based on <ptr target="#EdASD"/>.</note>
. </colophon>
. </msItem>
55 </msContents>
. <physDesc>
. <objectDesc>
. <p>Old Western Javanese Quadratic script on
. gebang.</p>
60 <p>The manuscript consists of 29 leaves of <foreign>gebang</foreign> (<foreign>Corypha gebanga</foreign>), measuring 35 × 3.5 cm. Each leaf on each side contains four lines of writing.</p>
. </objectDesc>
. <handDesc>
. <p/>

70 <msIdentifier>
. <settlement>Jakarta</settlement>

. <idno>L. 624 &amp; L. 1+</idno>
. </msIdentifier>
75 <msContents>
. <msItem>
. <colophon>
. <quote type="diplomatic" xml:lang="osn-Latn">təlas sinurat· bulan kasapuluḥ bijilna, poEna Aṅgara manis·, tulis·na tə Acan· ras·ti, masa di nusakrata, panəpen hada-hade pun· //o// mala<supplied reason="omitted">m</supplied>paḥh <choice>
. <orig>iṅpara</orig>
80 <corr>iṅampura</corr>
. </choice>
. <choice>
. <orig>ka</orig>
. <corr>ku</corr>
85 </choice> na sa<supplied reason="lost">stra</supplied>
. <gap reason="lost" unit="character" quantity="3"/>pa, kuraṁ vuvuhan·, Ḷviḥ loṅan·, ṅada praña saṁṅ amaca manavas·ta saṁ ṅaṚṅe pun·,·</quote>
. <quote type="translation">It is accomplished to be written on the tenth month, its day was Tuesday <foreign>manis</foreign>. The writing is not beautiful yet, during the time when [I] was in Nusakrata, in the beautified retirement place. I ask forgiveness by the fact that the text is ... If it is lacking, please add, if exessive please reduce. The readers are <foreign>ṅada</foreign> (?) knowledgable, the listeners gain the desired result.</quote>
. </colophon>
. </msItem>
90 </msContents>
. <physDesc>
. <objectDesc>
. <p>Old Sundanese script on lontar</p>
. </objectDesc>
95 <handDesc>
. <handNote xml:id="SKKB_H1" scriptRef="class:57470 maturity:83215">
. <p>We find two kinds of <foreign>ka</foreign> final (k·). The first is the one which is commonly found in manuscripts in Old Sundanese script, and another one is a rather rare form.</p>
. <p>Two ways of representing the <foreign>panyuku</foreign> (vocalization <foreign>u</foreign>) can be found in Old Sundanese manuscripts: first, the more common form is the right angle placed below the <foreign>aksara</foreign>, while the other form simply uses a single dot (·) below the <foreign>aksara</foreign>. This manuscript uses the second type.</p>
. </handNote>
100 </handDesc>
. </physDesc>
. </msDesc>
. </witness>

. <text xml:space="preserve">
. <body><div type="edition" xml:lang="osn-Latn">
. <div type="chapter" n="1" xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_01">
175 <head type="editorial" xml:lang="eng">The Ten Accomplishments</head>
. <p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_01.01"><pb edRef="#A" n="1v"/>ndah
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">nihan varahakəna</lem><rdg wit="#B">na<gap reason="lost" unit="character" quantity="4"/>ḥhakca</rdg></app> saṅ sadu,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">de</lem><rdg wit="#B" cause="morphological">den</rdg></app> saṅ mamet
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">hayu, hana ta</lem><rdg wit="#B">hayu,<lacunaStart/></rdg></app>
180 <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">saṅ hyaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A"><gap reason="lost" quantity="1" unit="character"/><gap reason="lost" quantity="1" unit="component"/>yaṁ</rdg></app> siksa kandaṅ karəsian ṅaranya,
.<app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">kayatnakəna</lem><rdg wit="#H">kayatna-yatna</rdg></app> voṅ sakabeh,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">nihan ujar</lem><rdg wit="#B"><lacunaEnd/> Ujar</rdg></app> saṅ sadu, ṅagəlarkən saṅ hyaṅ siksa
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">kandaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#B">kadaṁ</rdg></app> karəsian.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_01.02">ini saṅ hyaṅ <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">dasa-krəta</lem><rdg wit="#B">da<gap reason="lost" quantity="3" unit="character"/></rdg></app>,
185 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">kundaṅən</lem><rdg wit="#B" cause="morphological">kudaṁṅən:a</rdg><rdg wit="#H">kundaṅən na</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">uraṅ reya</lem><rdg wit="#B">Uraṁ rye di na bvana pun·</rdg><rdg wit="#H">uraṅ rea pun</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem type="omitted_elsewhere">asiṅ nu dek
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD">nañjərkən</lem><rdg wit="#A #H">najərkən</rdg></app>
. saṅ hyaṅ
190 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">sasana</lem><rdg wit="#H">dasa</rdg></app> krəta</lem><witDetail wit="#EdASD #A #H" type="retained"/><rdg wit="#B"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg><note>This entire phrase is omitted in <ptr target="#B"/>, which however has a more extensive version of the preceding phrase.</note></app>,
.<!-- uraṅ reya <app><lem>asiṅ nu dek <app><lem wit="#EdASD">nañjərkən</lem><rdg wit="#A">najərkən</rdg><rdg wit="#B" cause="larger_variant"/></app>
. saṅ hyaṅ sasana krəta</lem><rdg wit="#B">di na bvana pun·</rdg></app>, -->
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">pakənən</lem><rdg wit="#B">pakən</rdg></app> həbəl hirup<supplied reason="omitted">,</supplied>
. <app><lem type="emn">həbəl ñovana</lem><rdg wit="#A #H">həbəl ñavana</rdg><rdg wit="#B">həbəl<lacunaStart/></rdg><rdg wit="#EdASD">həbəl ñevana</rdg></app>, jadyan kuras,
195 <app><lem wit="#EdASD">jadyan</lem><rdg wit="#A">jadya</rdg></app> tahun,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">dəgdəg</lem><rdg wit="#H">dədəg</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD">tañjər</lem><rdg wit="#A">tajər</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD">jaya</lem><rdg wit="#A">ya</rdg><rdg wit="#H"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app> praṅ,
.
200 <app><lem wit="#A">ñovana</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD #H">ñavana</rdg><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="ac"/><rdg wit="#EdASD">ñevana</rdg><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="pc"/></app> <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">na uraṅ</lem><rdg wit="#B"><lacunaEnd/> na Uraṁ</rdg></app> reya.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_01.03"><app><lem wit="#B #EdASD #H">ini</lem><rdg wit="#A"><gap reason="lost" unit="character" quantity="1"/>ni</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">byaktana</lem><rdg wit="#B">byitana</rdg><rdg wit="#EdASD">byakta</rdg></app> saṅ hyaṅ
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">dasa-krəta</lem><rdg wit="#B">dasakrata</rdg></app> ṅaranya, kalaṅkaṅ saṅ hyaṅ
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">dasa-sila</lem><rdg wit="#B">dasa<lacunaStart/></rdg></app>, maya-maya saṅ hyaṅ dasa-marga, kaprətyaksaan na dasa-<app><lem wit="#A #EdASD" rend="hyphenleft">indriya</lem><rdg wit="#H">-indraya</rdg></app>, pakən ṅrətakən
205 <app><lem wit="#A #H">di</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app> bumi lamba,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">di bumi</lem><rdg wit="#H"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app>
. <app><lem type="emn">parək</lem><rdg wit="#A">paR̥<unclear>ka</unclear></rdg><rdg wit="#EdASD #H">tan parək</rdg></app>.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_01.04"><app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">ini pakən</lem><rdg wit="#B"><lacunaEnd/> pak·kən</rdg></app> uraṅ ṅrətakən
. <app><lem wit="#A #B #EdASD">bumi</lem><rdg wit="#H">di bumi</rdg></app>
210 <app><lem type="norm">lamba, caaṅ jalan</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD #H">lamba caaṅ jalan</rdg><rdg wit="#A">la<unclear>mbha</unclear><gap reason="lost" unit="character" quantity="3"/>ṁ<unclear>ja</unclear>lan·</rdg><rdg wit="#B">laba, caAṁ jalan</rdg></app>, pañjaṅ tajur, paka <app><lem wit="#A">pradana</lem><rdg wit="#B">prədana</rdg><rdg wit="#EdASD #H">pridana</rdg></app>, liñih pipir,
. <app><lem wit="#B #EdASD #H">caaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A"><unclear>ca</unclear>A</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD">bu<pb edRef="#A" n="2r"/>ruan, aṅgəs</lem><rdg wit="#A">buruAn·, agəs</rdg><rdg wit="#B">buruAn· A<lacunaStart/></rdg><rdg wit="#H">bruan, aṅgəs</rdg></app> ma imah kaəsi, ləit kaəsi, parañje kaəsi,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">huma</lem><rdg wit="#B"><lacunaEnd/>ma</rdg></app> kaomean, sadapan karaksa, palana ta hurip
. <app><lem wit="#A #B #H">hirup</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app>,
215 <app><lem wit="#EdASD">sove</lem><rdg wit="#A #B #H">sovera</rdg></app><!-- or to emend soāra? {@sowāra@} (= sawwara?) all --> varas,
. <app><lem wit="#A #B">ñovana</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">ñevana</rdg><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="pc"/><rdg wit="#EdASD">ñavana</rdg><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="ac"/><rdg wit="#H">ñovara</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A">saṅ mavaṅ rat</lem><rdg wit="#B">saṁ mava ra<lacunaStart/></rdg><rdg wit="#EdASD">sama vaṅ <supplied reason="omitted">sa</supplied>rat</rdg><rdg wit="#H">saṅ mava rat</rdg></app>, saṅkilaṅ di lamba, trəna<supplied reason="omitted">,</supplied> taru<supplied reason="omitted">,</supplied> lata<supplied reason="omitted">,</supplied>
. <app><lem wit="#A">guluma</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">galuma</rdg><rdg wit="#H">gulama</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">hejo</lem><rdg wit="#B"><lacunaEnd/>jo</rdg></app> lembok tumuvuh, sarba pala
220 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">vovohan</lem><rdg wit="#B #H" cause="morphological">voḥvoḥhan</rdg></app>, dadi na
. <app><lem wit="#A #B #H">hudan</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">hujan</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">landuh</lem><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="ac"/><rdg wit="#B">ladaḥ</rdg><rdg wit="#EdASD">landuṅ</rdg><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="pc"/></app><supplied reason="omitted">,</supplied> tahun tumuvuh<supplied reason="omitted">,</supplied> daek
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">makahurip na</lem><rdg wit="#B">makahurip<lacunaStart/></rdg></app> uraṅ reya, iña eta saṅ hyaṅ sasana <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">krəta, di lamba</lem><rdg wit="#B"><lacunaEnd/> di laba</rdg></app> ṅaranna.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_01.05">ini saṅ hyaṅ dasa-<app><lem wit="#A #EdASD" rend="hyphenleft">krəta</lem><rdg wit="#B">-krata</rdg></app>, nu dipajarkən
225 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">kalaṅkaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#B"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app> saṅ hyaṅ
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">dasa-sila</lem><rdg wit="#B">dasa<lacunaStart/></rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A">ta</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD #H"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app>, ya maya-maya
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">saṅ hyaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#B"><lacunaEnd/> hyaṁ</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">dasa-marga ta</lem><rdg wit="#B">dasa-mrəga<lacunaStart/></rdg></app>, kaprətyaksaan na dasa-<app><lem wit="#A #EdASD" rend="hyphenleft">indriya</lem><rdg wit="#H">-indraya</rdg></app>.</p>
230<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_01.06">ini
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">byaktana, cəli</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">byakta, cəli</rdg><rdg wit="#B"><lacunaEnd/>na, cəli</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">ulah</lem><rdg wit="#B #H" cause="morphological">mulah</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #B #EdASD">baraṅ</lem><rdg wit="#H">salah</rdg></app> deṅe mo ma nu siəp dideṅe, kenana dora bañcana, saṅkan <pb edRef="#H" n="1v"/>uraṅ nəmu
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">mala, na</lem><rdg wit="#B">mala,<lacunaStart/></rdg></app> lunas papa
235 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">naraka</lem><rdg wit="#H">raka</rdg></app>, heṅan
. <app><lem wit="#A">lamunna</lem><rdg wit="#B"><lacunaEnd/>n:a</rdg><rdg wit="#EdASD #H">lamun</rdg></app> kapahayu ma,
. <app><lem wit="#B #EdASD">sinəṅ<pb edRef="#A" n="2v"/>guh</lem><rdg wit="#A">sinəguh</rdg><rdg wit="#H">sinaṅguh</rdg></app> utama
. <app><lem wit="#A #B #EdASD">bijilna</lem><rdg wit="#H">bijil</rdg></app> ti paṅrəṅə.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_01.07">mata
240 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">ulah</lem><rdg wit="#B #H" cause="morphological">mulah</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">baraṅ</lem><rdg wit="#B #H" cause="lexical">salah</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">dələ, mo</lem><rdg wit="#B">dələ, <lacunaStart/></rdg></app> ma nu siəp didələ, kenana dora bañcana,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">saṅkan uraṅ</lem><rdg wit="#B"><lacunaEnd/> Ura</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#B #EdASD #H">nəmu</lem><rdg wit="#A">nimu</rdg></app>
245 <app><lem wit="#A #B #H">mala, na</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">mala na</rdg></app> lunas papa
. <app><lem wit="#A #B #H">kalesa</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">naraka</rdg><note>Or emend to <foreign>naraka</foreign>, as in the previous paragraphs?</note></app>, heṅan <app><lem wit="#A #B">lamunna</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD #H">lamun</rdg></app> kapahayu ma, sinaṅguh
. <app><lem wit="#H">utama bijil ti mata</lem><rdg wit="#A #EdASD">utamaniṅ dələ</rdg><rdg wit="#B">utama bijil ti<lacunaStart/></rdg><note>Or conjecture <foreign>paṅdələ</foreign>?</note></app>.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_01.08"><app><lem type="reformulated_elsewhere">kulit ulah dipake gulaṅ-gasehan, ku panas ku tiis,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">kenana</lem><rdg wit="#B"><lacunaEnd/>nana</rdg></app> dora bañcana, saṅkan uraṅ nəmu
250 <app><lem wit="#A #B">mala, na</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">mala na</rdg></app> lunas papa naraka, heṅan lamunna kapahayu ma, sinəṅguh
. <app><lem wit="#A">utama</lem><rdg wit="#B">uta<lacunaStart/></rdg></app> bijilna ti kulit.</lem><note type="altLem">kulit ulah...bijilna ti kulit</note><witDetail wit="#A #B #EdASD" type="retained"/><note>This paragraph completely missing in <ptr target="#H"/>. The manuscript <ptr target="#H"/> contains a diferent list after <foreign>mata</foreign> (1.7), i.e. <foreign>iruṅ</foreign>, <foreign>suṅut</foreign>, <foreign>letah</foreign>, <foreign>ləṅən</foreign>, <foreign>suku</foreign>, <foreign>payu</foreign>, and <foreign>baga lavan purusa</foreign>. It means that Holle’s reading is presumably based on <ptr target="#B"/>, which is now lost in this part. In this regard, I will retain the paragraphs (from 1.9–1.15) based on the list in <ptr target="#A"/>, but I will record readings from <ptr target="#H"/>.</note></app></p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_01.09">letah ulah salah nu dirasakən, kenana dora bañcana, saṅkan uraṅ nəmu mala, na lunas papa naraka, heṅan
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">lamunna</lem><rdg wit="#H">lamun</rdg></app> kapahayu ma,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">sinəṅguh</lem><rdg wit="#H">sinanaṅguh</rdg></app> utama bijilna ti letah.</p>
255<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_01.10">iruṅ ulah salah ambə, kenana dora bañcana, saṅkan uraṅ nəmu mala, na lunas papa <pb edRef="#A" n="3r"/>naraka, heṅan
. <app><lem wit="#A">lamunna</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD #H">lamun</rdg></app> kapahayu ma, sinəṅguh utama bijilna
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">ti iruṅ</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">timiruṅ</rdg><note>It seems that this is a misprint of the edition.</note></app>.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_01.11">suṅut ulah <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">baraṅ</lem><rdg wit="#H">salah</rdg></app> carek<supplied reason="omitted">,</supplied> kenana dora bañcana, na lunas papa
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">naraka</lem><rdg wit="#H">kalesa</rdg></app>, heṅan
260 <app><lem wit="#A">lamunna</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">lamun</rdg></app> kapahayu ma, sinəṅguh utama bijilna ti suṅut.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_01.12">ləṅən mulah <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">baraṅ</lem><rdg wit="#H">salah</rdg></app> cokot, kenana dora bañcana, na lunas papa naraka, heṅan
. <app><lem wit="#A">lamunna</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD #H">lamun</rdg></app> kapahayu ma, sinəṅguh utama bijilna ti ləṅən.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_01.13">suku mulah
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">baraṅ</lem><rdg wit="#H">salah</rdg></app> tiñcak, kenana dora bañcana, na lunas papa naraka, heṅan
265 <app><lem wit="#A">lamunna</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD #H">lamun</rdg></app> kapahayu ma, sinəṅguh utama
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">bijilna</lem><rdg wit="#H">bijil</rdg></app> ti suku.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_01.14">payu ulah dipake
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">kətər</lem><rdg wit="#H">kətir</rdg></app>, kenana dora
. <app><lem wit="#A">bañcana,</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">bañcana</rdg></app> na lunas papa naraka, heṅan
270 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">lamunna</lem><rdg wit="#H">lamun</rdg></app> kapahayu ma, sinəṅguh utama
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">bijilna</lem><rdg wit="#H">bijil</rdg></app> ti payu.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_01.15"><app><lem wit="#H">baga lavan purusa</lem><rdg wit="#A #EdASD">baga purusa</rdg></app> ulah dipake
. <app><lem wit="#A">kañco<pb edRef="#A" n="3v"/>lah</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">kañcoleh</rdg><rdg wit="#H">kacoleh</rdg></app>, kenana dora bañcana, na lunas papa naraka, heṅan lamunna kapahayu ma, sinəṅguh utama
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">bijilna</lem><rdg wit="#H">bijil</rdg></app> ti baga lavan purusa, ya ta sinaṅguh dasa-krəta ṅaranna, aṅgəs
275 <app><lem wit="#A #H">ma kapahayu</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">kapahayu ma</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">na dora</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">dora</rdg></app> sapuluh, rampes tvah na uraṅ reya, makaṅuni tvah saṅ deva ratu.</p>
. </div>
.<div type="chapter" n="2" xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_02">
. <head type="editorial" xml:lang="eng">The Ten Devotions (dasa-prəbakti)</head>
280 <p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_02.01">nihan sinaṅguh dasa-prəbakti ṅaranya,
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">anak</lem><rdg wit="#A">Ana</rdg></app> bakti di bapa,
. <app><lem wit="#A #H"><num value="1">sa</num></lem><rdg wit="#EdASD"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app>, eve bakti di laki, <num value="2">2</num>, hulun bakti di pacandaan, <num value="3">3</num>, sisiya bakti di guru, <supplied reason="omitted"><num value="4">4</num>,</supplied>
. <app><lem wit="#A">voṅ</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">vaṅ</rdg><rdg wit="#H">uraṅ</rdg></app> tani bakti di
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD">vado</lem><rdg wit="#A"><del rend="ui">da</del>va<del rend="ui">ta</del></rdg><rdg wit="#H">devata</rdg><witDetail wit="#H" type="ac"/><rdg wit="#H">vadana</rdg><witDetail wit="#H" type="pc"/></app>, <supplied reason="omitted"><num value="5">5</num>,</supplied>
285 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">vado</lem><rdg wit="#H">vadon</rdg></app> bakti di mantri, <num value="6">6</num>, mantri bakti di nu naṅganan, <num value="7">7</num>, nu naṅganan bakti di maṅkubumi, <supplied reason="omitted"><num value="8">8</num>,</supplied> maṅkubumi bakti di ratu, <num value="9">9</num>, ratu bakti di devata, <num value="10">0</num>, devata bakti di hyaṅ,<!-- maybe mark this phrase as possible interpolation -->
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">ya</lem><rdg wit="#A">yu</rdg></app> ta sinaṅguh dasa-prəbakti ṅaranna<!-- ṅarana in the msA, normalisation to note in the preface -->, <num value="10">0</num>.</p>
.
. </div>
.<div type="chapter" n="3" xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_03">
290 <head type="editorial" xml:lang="eng">The Five Series</head>
. <p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_03.01">ini na lakukənən, talatah saṅ sadu jati, oṅkara nama
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">sivaya</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">sevaya</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem wit="#A">səmbahniṅ</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">səmbah iṅ</rdg><rdg wit="#H">səmbahni</rdg></app> hulun, di saṅ hyaṅ pañca-tatagata, pañca ṅaraniṅ lima, tata ma ṅaraniṅ sabda, gata ta ma ṅaraniṅ raga, ya eta
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">na</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">ma</rdg></app> pahayuən sareanana,
295 <app><lem wit="#A #H">pañcaksara</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">pañca aksara</rdg></app> guru-guruniṅ
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">janma</lem><rdg wit="#H">camah</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem wit="#A">ka</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD #H"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg><note>This abbreviation for Old Javanese <foreign>kaliṅanya</foreign>, quite common in SMG, was again misunderstood by ASD in 7.1.</note></app>,
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">pañcaksara</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">pañca aksara</rdg></app> ma byakta, nu
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">katoṅton</lem><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="pc"/><rdg wit="#EdASD">katiṅton</rdg><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="ac"/></app>
300 <app><lem type="emn">kavrətan</lem><rdg wit="#A #EdASD #H">kavrəton</rdg></app>, kacaksuh
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">kaindriya</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD" cause="syntactic">ku indriya</rdg></app>, guru ma panañaan na uraṅ reya,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">ña</lem><rdg wit="#H" cause="morphological">iña</rdg></app> mana diṅaranan
. <app><lem wit="#A">guruniṅ</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">guru iṅ</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">janma</lem><rdg wit="#H" cause="orthographical">jalma</rdg></app>,
305 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">saṅmoha</lem><rdg wit="#H">saṅ mota mota moha</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A">ma</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD #H"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app>
. <app><lem type="norm">saaṅgəsna</lem><rdg wit="#A">saAgəsna</rdg><rdg wit="#EdASD #H">saṅgəsna</rdg><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="pc"/><rdg wit="#EdASD">sagəsna</rdg><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="ac"/></app> aya bvana.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_03.02">ini byaktana ṅaranya, ya pañca-byapara, saṅ hyaṅ prətivi, apah, teja, bayu, mvaṅ akasa, carek saṅ sadu mahapurusa,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">eta</lem><rdg wit="#H" cause="lexical">emboh eta</rdg></app> keh drəbya uraṅ, kaṅkən prətivi kulit, kaṅkən apah darah ciduh, kaṅkən teja panon, kaṅkən bayu tulaṅ, kaṅkən akasa <pb edRef="#A" n="4v"/>kapala,
310 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">iya</lem><rdg wit="#H">iña</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">prətivi</lem><rdg wit="#A">prəvi</rdg></app> di sarira ṅaranya, ña mana
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">dikaṅkənkən</lem><rdg wit="#A">dikaṅkəkən</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A">ka</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD #H" cause="syntactic">ku</rdg></app> nu mava bumi, ya maṅupati
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">dadi</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app>
315 <app><lem wit="#A #H">prabu</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">pra</rdg><note>ASD note <q>Sesudah tarahan seharusnya ada prabu</q>. This note is ambiguous for it is more plausible that the word <foreign>prabu</foreign> appears before <foreign>rama</foreign>. But if it is the case, than it is misread since the manuscript undoubtedly contains the word <foreign>prabu</foreign> just before <foreign>rama</foreign>.</note></app> rama rəsi
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">disi mvaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#H">di simaṅ</rdg></app> tarahan.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_03.03">ini pañca-putra,
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">prətivi</lem><rdg wit="#A">prativi</rdg></app> saṅ maṅukuhan, apah saṅ katuṅ maralah, teja saṅ karuṅ kalah, bayu saṅ sandaṅ grəba, akasa saṅ
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">vrəti kandayun</lem><rdg wit="#A">vr̥ətkiṇdayun·</rdg></app>.</p>
320<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_03.04">ini pañca-kusika,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">saṅ kusika, di</lem><rdg wit="#H" cause="eye-skip"/></app> gunuṅ, saṅ garga di rumbut, saṅ
. <app><lem wit="#A">mestri</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">mesti</rdg><rdg wit="#H">mistri</rdg><note>The variation of readings is due to the problematic transciption of the character <foreign>ṭā</foreign>. In the Old West-Javanese manuscript corpus, this character can represent both <foreign>ṭā</foreign> or <foreign>tra</foreign>. Faced with the choice to read <foreign>mesṭi</foreign> or mestri, I prefer the latter, since it is the more common spelling in OS texts, i.e., <title>Carita Parahyaṅan</title>, <title>Saṅ Hyaṅ Sasana Mahaguru</title>, etc. Cf. Old Javanese <foreign>metri</foreign>.</note></app> di
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">mahameru</lem><rdg wit="#H">mahamiru</rdg></app>, saṅ purusa di mandiri, saṅ patañjala di pañjulan.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_03.05"><app><lem wit="#A">lamunna</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">lamun</rdg></app>
325 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">pahi</lem><rdg wit="#H">eta</rdg></app> kaopeksa saṅ hyaṅ vuku lima,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">na</lem><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="ac"/><rdg wit="#EdASD">dina</rdg><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="pc"/></app> bvana boa halimpu, ikaṅ desa kabeh,
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD">desa kabeh</lem><rdg wit="#A">desa beḥ</rdg><rdg wit="#H"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app> ṅaranya, purba, daksina,
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">pasirma</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">pasima</rdg><note>The spelling of this word, derived from Skt. <foreign>paścima</foreign>, shows considerable variation in the OS corpus. I retain the spelling of <ptr target="#A"/> as it occurs again in the next paragraph, and a similar spelling is found in <title>Kavih Mahañana</title>.</note></app>, utara, madya.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_03.06"><app><lem wit="#EdASD">purba, timur</lem><rdg wit="#A #H" cause="dittography">purba ti timur</rdg></app>, kahanan hyaṅ isora, putih rupanya, daksina kidul,
330 <app><lem type="reformulated_elsewhere"><app><lem wit="#EdASD">kahanan</lem><rdg wit="#A">kihanan·</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">hyaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">hya</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">brahma</lem><rdg wit="#A">br̥ḥma</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem wit="#A">baṅ</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">mirah</rdg><rdg wit="#H">abaṅ</rdg></app> rupanya,
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">pasirma</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">pasima</rdg></app> kulon</lem><witDetail wit="#A" type="retained"/>
335 <rdg wit="#EdASD"><supplied reason="omitted">kahanan hyaṅ brahma, mirah rupanya, pasima, kulon</supplied></rdg>
. <note>ASD explicitly indicate their reading of this phrase as supplied, whereas in fact it is the reading of the manuscript with one semantic substitution (<foreign>mirah</foreign> for <foreign>baṅ</foreign>) and one orthographic normalization (<foreign>kulvan</foreign> to <foreign>kulon</foreign>).</note></app>, kahanan hyaṅ mahadeva, kuniṅ
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">rupanya</lem><note>ASD considered this word to be omitted in the manuscript, so they added it as though it were a conjecture, but actually it is simply there in <ptr target="#A"/>.</note></app>, <pb edRef="#A" n="5r"/><app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">utara lor, kahanan hyaṅ visnu, hirəṅ rupanya</lem><rdg wit="#H" cause="eye-skip"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app>, madya təṅah, kahanan hyaṅ
. <app><lem type="emn">sivah, sarva varna</lem><rdg wit="#A #H" cause="haplography">sivah, varna</rdg><rdg wit="#EdASD">aneka varna</rdg></app> rupanya, ña mana sakitu saṅ hyaṅ vuku lima
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">di</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">dina</rdg></app> bvana.</p>
340<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_03.07">ini vuku lima di mahapandita, sandi ma karasa si tutur, tapa ma karasa si
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">liṅlaṅ</lem><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="ac"/><rdg wit="#EdASD">laṅlaṅ</rdg><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="pc"/></app>, luṅguh ma karasa si
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">pagəh</lem><rdg wit="#H">pagih</rdg></app>, prətyaksa ma
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">karasa</lem><rdg wit="#H">karaksa</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A">sy asəmbava</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">si asəmbava</rdg><rdg wit="#H">səmbava</rdg></app>, kaləpasən ma karasa
345 <app><lem type="emn">si maṅdumi</lem><rdg wit="#A #EdASD">madumi</rdg><rdg wit="#H">maduman</rdg></app> tan kaduman,
. <app><lem type="reformulated_elsewhere">maṅhiṅi tan
. <app><lem type="emn">kahiṅanan</lem><rdg wit="#A">kahiṅinan</rdg><rdg wit="#H">pahiṅətan</rdg></app></lem><witDetail wit="#A #H" type="retained"/><rdg wit="#EdASD">maṅhiṅətan tanpa hiṅa</rdg></app>, sakitu vuku lima di mahapandita.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_03.08">nihan pavvitaniṅ krəta, sya saṅ devata lima, pahi ṅavakan ṅaran di maneh,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">pahi</lem><rdg wit="#H">pahiṅ</rdg></app> mirəṅəh <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">rua di</lem><rdg wit="#H">ra</rdg><witDetail wit="#H" type="ac"/><rdg wit="#H">ru</rdg><witDetail wit="#H" type="pc"/></app> maneh, heṅan
350 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">lamunna</lem><rdg wit="#H">lamun</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">mo</lem><rdg wit="#H">hamo</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">karaksa</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">karasa</rdg></app> ma,
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">kady aṅganiṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">kady aganiṅ</rdg></app> vilut tuməmu vilutnya bənər tuməmu benernya, kitu keh
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">eta, ku</lem><rdg wit="#H">eta kaṅkən</rdg></app> tvahniṅ janma mana
355 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">krəta, ku</lem><rdg wit="#H">krəta mana prəlaya</rdg></app> tvahniṅ<pb edRef="#A" n="5v"/> janma
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">mana na</lem><rdg wit="#H"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A">hayu</lem><rdg wit="#H"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg><rdg wit="#EdASD">layu</rdg><note>It seems this is a printing error.</note></app>.</p>
. </div>
.<div type="chapter" n="4" xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04">
360 <head type="editorial" xml:lang="eng">The Acts of the Servant (karmaniṅ hulun)</head>
. <p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04.01">ini karmaniṅ hulun,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">sakajalan</lem><rdg wit="#H">saṅkan jalan</rdg></app> uraṅ hulun, karma ma ṅaranya pibudiən,
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">tiṅkah</lem><rdg wit="#A">tikah</rdg></app> paripolah, sakajalan ṅaranya, maka takut maka
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">jarot</lem><rdg wit="#H">ṅalət</rdg><note>Holle clearly missread two similar <foreign>aksara</foreign>s: <foreign>ja</foreign> as <foreign>ṅa</foreign> and <foreign>2/ro</foreign> as <foreign>Ḷ</foreign>.</note></app>, maka atoṅ maka
365 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">təaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#H">tya</rdg></app>, di tiṅkah di pitvahən, di ulah di
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">pisabdaan</lem><rdg wit="#H">sabda</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem>makaṅuni lamun di harəpən saṅ deva ratu pun</lem><note>ASD consider this phrase as the beginning of the next paragraph.</note></app>.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04.02">maka satya di kahulunan,
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">mana</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">maka</rdg></app> lokat dasa-kalesa, boa ruvat mala mari papa,
370 <app><lem wit="#A #H">kapaṅguhniṅ</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">kapaṅgihniṅ</rdg></app> kasorgaan.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04.03">lamun
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">tətəiṅ</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">tə<supplied reason="omitted">ṅ</supplied>təiṅ</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">ṅavakan</lem><rdg wit="#H">avakan</rdg></app> karmaniṅ hulun,
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD">kitu</lem><rdg wit="#A">kətu</rdg></app> eta ləvih
375 <app><lem type="emn">madan usyat</lem><rdg wit="#A">madan:usya</rdg><rdg wit="#EdASD">madan usya</rdg><rdg wit="#H">manan nu sya</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">titindih</lem><rdg wit="#H">titi di</rdg></app> ukir, ditapa di luhur gunuṅ, kena palaraṅ ditapa, di na
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">hunur</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">luhur</rdg></app> gajah hunur
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD">siṅha</lem><rdg wit="#A">siha</rdg><rdg wit="#H">syaha</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD">dəkət</lem><rdg wit="#A">dəkət:ə</rdg><rdg wit="#H">dəkət si</rdg></app> mahabañcana.</p>
380<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04.04">ini <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">tvahniṅ janma</lem><rdg wit="#H">taṅguhnana</rdg><witDetail wit="#H" type="ac"/><rdg wit="#H">tvahniṅ janma</rdg><witDetail wit="#H" type="pc"/></app>, pigunaən na uraṅ reya, ulah mo turut saṅ hyaṅ siksa
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">ka<pb edRef="#A" n="6r"/>ndaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">kanda</rdg></app> karəsian, jaga raṅ dek luput iṅ na
. <app><lem wit="#H">pañca-gati saṅsara</lem><rdg wit="#A">pañcagantisaṁsara</rdg><rdg wit="#EdASD">pañcagati, saṅsara</rdg></app>, mulah
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">carut</lem><rdg wit="#H">carutkən</rdg></app> mulah
. <app><lem type="emn">sok rereh</lem><rdg wit="#A">sorereh</rdg><rdg wit="#EdASD #H">sarereh</rdg></app>, mulah
385 <app><lem wit="#EdASD">ñaṅcarutkən</lem><rdg wit="#A">ñaṁcarukən</rdg><rdg wit="#H">caṅcarutkən</rdg></app> maneh, kaliṅanna ñaṅcarutkən maneh ma ṅaranya,
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">na</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">nu</rdg></app> aya dipajar hantə,
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">na</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">nu</rdg></app> hantə dipajar vaya,
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">na</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">nu</rdg></app> iña dipajar lain,
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">na</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">nu</rdg></app> lain dipajar iña, ña
390 <app><lem wit="#A">karah hədapna</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">karah <supplied reason="omitted">ə</supplied>dapna</rdg><rdg wit="#H">karah handapna</rdg></app> makira-kira, budi-budi,
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">ṅajərum</lem><rdg wit="#A">ṅajrərum</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">mijahətan</lem><rdg wit="#H">mijahətan, hidəpna soraṅan</rdg></app>, eta byaktana ñaṅcarutkən maneh ta ṅaranna.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04.05">ñaṅcarutkən sakalih ma ṅaranna, mipit mo amit, ṅala mo
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">menta</lem><rdg wit="#A">meta</rdg></app>,
395 <app><lem type="norm">ṅajumput</lem><rdg wit="#A #EdASD #H">ṅajuput</rdg></app> mo sadu, makaṅuni
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">tu numpu</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD" cause="dittography">tu tunumpu</rdg></app> maliṅ,
. <app><lem type="norm">ṅəntal</lem><rdg wit="#A #EdASD">ṅətal</rdg><rdg wit="#H">ṅagətal</rdg></app> ṅabegal, siṅ savatək cəkap carut, ya ñaṅcarutkən sakalih ṅaranna.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04.06">saṅuni tu meor, ṅodok,
. <app><lem wit="#A">ñopet</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD #H">ñepet</rdg></app>, ṅarəbut, ṅarorogoh, papañjiṅan,<pb edRef="#A" n="6v"/> makaṅuni ṅotok ṅovo, di pamajikan, di paṅhulu tandaṅ, makaṅuni
400 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">di tohaan</lem><rdg wit="#H" cause="eye-skip"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app> di maneh, itu ləvih mulah dipiguna, dipitvah ku uraṅ hulun.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04.07">ulah mo pake na sabda atoṅ
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">təaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#H">tyaṅ</rdg></app> guru basa, bakti suksila di pada
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">janma</lem><rdg wit="#H" cause="orthographical">jalma</rdg></app>, di kula-kadaṅ baraya, makaṅuni di tohaan uraṅ, suku ma pake disila, ləṅən ma pake umun.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04.08">jaga raṅ pacarek dəṅ menak dəṅ
405 <app><lem wit="#EdASD">gusti</lem><rdg wit="#A">guti</rdg><rdg wit="#H">gusti dəṅ mantri</rdg></app>, dəṅ buhaya iṅ kalih,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">dəṅ</lem><rdg wit="#H">di</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">astri</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">estri</rdg></app> laraṅan, makaṅuni
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">dəṅ</lem><rdg wit="#H">di</rdg></app> tohaan uraṅ, jaga raṅ
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">digunakən</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">dipiguhakən</rdg></app>, mulah surah di tinəṅ uraṅ, saṅuni
410 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">salah</lem><rdg wit="#H">salah na</rdg></app> tembal, kajəəṅ səmu mo suka
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">ku</lem><rdg wit="#H" cause="syntactic">kabirəṅəh ku</rdg></app> tohaan uraṅ,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">ulah</lem><rdg wit="#H" cause="dittography">mulah</rdg></app><supplied reason="omitted">,</supplied> pamali<supplied reason="omitted">,</supplied> bisi urug bənaṅ ditapa, hilaṅ bənaṅ cakal bakal, bisi ləṅit batri hese, kapaṅguh ku saṅ hyaṅ jagat saṅsara,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">katigra<pb edRef="#A" n="7r"/>ha</lem><rdg wit="#H" cause="lexical">kanugraha</rdg></app> ku saṅ deva ratu.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04.09">lamun hamo satya di tohaan uraṅ,
415 <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">aṅgəs</lem><rdg wit="#A">agəs</rdg></app> ma jaga raṅ vaya di kagəriṅ, jaga raṅ palay, jaga raṅ irəg, duga-duga majar maneh
. <app><lem wit="#A">tətəiṅ</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">tə<supplied reason="omitted">ṅ</supplied>təiṅ</rdg><rdg wit="#H">maṅarti tətəiṅ</rdg></app> amat<supplied reason="omitted">,</supplied> mana
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">dipajar</lem><rdg wit="#H" cause="morphological">dipajarkən</rdg></app> satya di kahulunan, heṅan jaga raṅ cəta ma
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">mulah luhya</lem><rdg wit="#H">mulhya</rdg></app>, mulah kuciva, mulah
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">ṅontoṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">ṅotoṅ</rdg></app> dipivaraṅ, mulah hiri mulah dəṅki,
420 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">dəṅ</lem><rdg wit="#H">di</rdg></app> dəṅən sakahulunan, makaṅuni ñəəṅ nu mənaṅ
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">pujyan</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">pudyan</rdg></app>, mənaṅ parəkan, ñəəṅ nu dineneh ku
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">tohaan</lem><rdg wit="#H">tohaan uraṅ</rdg></app>, teka dek
. <app><lem wit="#A">ñətñot</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">ñetñot</rdg><rdg wit="#H">ña</rdg></app> tinəṅ uraṅ, hayva<supplied reason="omitted">,</supplied> pamali,
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">kapamalyanana</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">kapamalyanna</rdg></app> karah, jadi
425 <app><lem rend="check" type="emn">əluh</lem><rdg wit="#A #EdASD #H">nəluḥ</rdg></app>, barəh hate, hamo bənaṅ
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">ditambaan</lem><rdg wit="#A">ditabaan</rdg></app>, jampe mo matih,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">paksa</lem><rdg wit="#H">paksa jampe</rdg></app> mo
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">mrətyaksa</lem><rdg wit="#H">mrəksa</rdg></app>, ja
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">hantə</lem><rdg wit="#A">hanətə</rdg></app>
430 <app><lem wit="#A">katurutan</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">katurutan ku</rdg><rdg wit="#H">katurut</rdg></app> saṅ hyaṅ siksa kandaṅ karəsian.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04.10">kitu jaga raṅ
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">naṅganan</lem><rdg wit="#A">naganan</rdg></app>, mulah kira-ki<pb edRef="#A" n="7v"/>ra digəlaṅan, jaga raṅ kagəlaṅan, mulah mo bakti di nu naṅganan, kena itu
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD">tanda</lem><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="pc"/><rdg wit="#A #EdASD #H">tunda</rdg><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="ac"/></app> saṅ deva ratu.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04.11">jaga raṅ kəna pañuruhan, mulah mo
435 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">raksa</lem><rdg wit="#H" cause="lexical">pake</rdg></app> saṅ hyaṅ siksa kandaṅ karəsian, pakən uraṅ satya di pivaraṅan,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">heṅan</lem><rdg wit="#H"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">lamun nu</lem><rdg wit="#H">lamun uraṅ</rdg></app> ṅalor ṅidul ṅulon ṅetan, gəs ma mulah si vok
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD">cante</lem><rdg wit="#A">cate</rdg></app>, mulah si mur cante, mulah si mar cante, mulah darma cante, ya ta sinaṅguh saṅ hyaṅ catur-yatna ṅaranya.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04.12">ini kaliṅanna, si vok cante ma ṅaranna,
440 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">kavujukan</lem><rdg wit="#H">kavujuk</rdg></app> ku hakan inum, si mur cante ma ṅaranna,
. <app><lem wit="#A">salimaha milu</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">salima hamilu</rdg></app>
. <app><lem type="emn">ṅaramankən</lem><rdg wit="#A #EdASD">ṅaramakən</rdg><rdg wit="#H" cause="lexical">ṅaramekən</rdg></app> nu maliṅ, nu ṅarəbut, nu meor,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">ya</lem><rdg wit="#H">ya ta</rdg></app> salah doṅdonan ṅaranya,
. <app><lem>si mar cante ṅaranna</lem><note>Supply <foreign>ma</foreign> as in the analogous sentences in this paragraph?</note></app>, ṅala dagaṅan, mas pirak lalambaran, hantə di<pb edRef="#A" n="8r"/>titah ku nu mivaraṅ,
445 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">ya</lem><rdg wit="#H">ya ta</rdg></app> salah
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">sadeya</lem><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="ac"/><rdg wit="#EdASD">sadeyan</rdg><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="pc"/></app> ṅaranna, darma cante ma ṅaranna,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">daranan</lem><rdg wit="#H">darma</rdg></app> di kacəcəb tohaan uraṅ, disuruh ñokot, ṅadarat, matyan nu
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">tan yogya</lem><rdg wit="#H">tan payogya</rdg></app>
. <app><lem>ka</lem><note>Or to emend <foreign>ku</foreign>?</note></app> tohaan, gumanti ya ṅisəsan,
450 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">kena vagəy</lem><rdg wit="#H">kena kavagəy, kena kakaruh</rdg></app>, kena kula-kadaṅ, kena baraya, eta ulah dipiguna,
. <app><lem wit="#A">kena pamali salah binarih ṅaranna, itu darma cante ṅaranna, eta mulah dipitvah</lem><note type="altLem">kena ... dipitvah</note><rdg wit="#EdASD" cause="eye-skip"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg><note>The omission in ASD seems to be due to eye-skip from <foreign>dipiguna</foreign> to <foreign>dipitvah</foreign>.</note></app> ku
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">uraṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">Ura</rdg></app> hulun, bogoh di kacəcəb, cəcəb di kabogoh, itu
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">tan yogya dipitvah</lem><rdg wit="#H">tan yaya toh</rdg></app> ku uraṅ hulun.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04.13">ini pakən uraṅ nurut ka tohaan, pakən uraṅ pañjaṅ dipihulun, pakən uraṅ
455 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">həbəl</lem><rdg wit="#H">pañjaṅ</rdg></app> diasa ku tohaan uraṅ, turut saṅ hyaṅ siksa kandaṅ karəsian, birəṅəh na paṅ<pb edRef="#A" n="8v"/>hulu tandaṅ,
. <app><lem wit="#A">lamunna</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD #H">lamun</rdg></app> ñəsəl tohaan, milu uraṅ ñəsəl dəi dəṅ tohaan,
. <app><lem wit="#A">lamunna</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD #H">lamun</rdg></app> muji tohaan, milu uraṅ muji dəi dəṅ tohaan, lamun hamo ma
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">bisa</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app> milu muji milu meda dəṅ tohaan, tosta ciṅciṅ
. <app><lem wit="#A">təhər</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">təgaṅ</rdg><rdg wit="#H">di thar</rdg></app> uraṅ bakti ka tohaan.</p>
460<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04.14">jaga raṅ ləmpaṅ ṅalasan, baju
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">simbut</lem><rdg wit="#H">caṅcut</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #H">paṅadva, dataṅ ma ka sisi, sakarajən dibaju, disimbut</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD" cause="eye-skip"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg><note>Again, ASD shows <foreign>saut du même au même</foreign> caused by the repetition of the word simbut.</note></app>, lamun hamo dəṅ tohaan, isəskən na siksa kandaṅ
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">karəsian</lem><rdg wit="#A">kaśyin</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">siksaanana</lem><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="pc"/><rdg wit="#EdASD">siksaanna</rdg><witDetail wit="#EdASD" type="ac"/><note>Diplomatically, the ms A reads <foreign>siksaAn:ana</foreign>. ASD interpret as <foreign>pamaéh</foreign> what I interpret as consonant doubling mark, and are hence obliged to emend in order to obtain the reading <foreign>siksaanana</foreign>.</note></app> ta, ulah dek
465 <app><lem wit="#EdASD #H">ṅundər</lem><rdg wit="#A">ṅudər</rdg></app> ka huma beet sakalih, ka kebon sakalih, hamo ma bənaṅ uraṅ laku sadu.</p>
.<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04.15"><app><lem type="emn">salaṅ iṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A #EdASD">salaṁ</rdg><rdg wit="#H">saṅkilaṅ</rdg></app> kəboan iṅ alas, kayu batri naṅtu, bvah bənaṅ
. <app><lem wit="#EdASD">ṅararaṅgean</lem><rdg wit="#A">ṅararagyen</rdg><rdg wit="#H">karageyan</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem type="emn">taṅgəhan</lem><rdg wit="#A #EdASD #H">taṁgəḥkən</rdg></app> suluh, turuban supa, caṅrədan təvvan, odeṅ, ñərua<pb edRef="#A" n="9r"/>n, eṅaṅ, ulam, parakan, siṅ savatək babayan, ulah uraṅ baraṅ ala, saṅuni
. <app><lem wit="#A">tu nurunkən</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">turunkən</rdg><rdg wit="#H">nurunkən</rdg></app> sadapan sakalih, ulah eta dipiguna, kenana puhuniṅ dosa, taṅkalniṅ papa kalesa.</p>
470<p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_04.16">jaga raṅ nəmu <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">jalan, gəde</lem><rdg wit="#B"><lacunaEnd/> gade</rdg></app> beet, baṅat
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">dicaṅcut</lem><rdg wit="#B">caṁcut</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">dipaṅadva</lem><rdg wit="#B">paṅadva</rdg></app>, sugan uraṅ pajəəṅ dəṅ
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">gusti, dəṅ</lem><rdg wit="#B">gu<lacunaStart/></rdg></app> mantri, ulah mo paṅidalkən,
. <app><lem type="emn">paṅadoṅkoṅkən</lem><rdg wit="#A">paṁṅadokokoṁkən·</rdg><rdg wit="#EdASD">paṅgadokokoṅkən</rdg><rdg wit="#H">paṅdoṅkokən</rdg></app>, lamun bujaṅga
475 <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">brahmana</lem><rdg wit="#B"><lacunaEnd/> bramana</rdg></app>, viku haji, maṅkubumi, anak ratu,
. <app><lem wit="#B #EdASD">bəṅhar</lem><rdg wit="#A">bəhar</rdg></app> kokoro, <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">makaṅuni</lem><rdg wit="#B">maka<lacunaStart/></rdg></app> guru loka, ulah mo
. <app><lem type="conj">paṅidalkən</lem><rdg wit="#A #EdASD #H">pahi paṁṅidalkən·</rdg><note>My conjecture <foreign>paṅidalkən</foreign> is based on the hyptothesis that a dittography occurs in the word <foreign>pahi</foreign> and <foreign>paṅi</foreign>. The interjection word such as <foreign>ulah</foreign> and <foreign>ulah mo</foreign> is usually followed by a verb. Cf. <foreign>ulah mo paṅidalkən, paṅadokokoṅkən</foreign> in 4.16.</note></app>,
. <app><lem wit="#A">paṅdəukən</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD"><gap reason="lost"/></rdg><rdg wit="#H">paṅdoṅkokən</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD">kena</lem><rdg wit="#B"><lacunaEnd/> kena</rdg></app> itu guru saṅ prəbu.</p>
480 </div>
.<div type="chapter" n="5" xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_05">
. <head type="editorial" xml:lang="eng">Rules of Interaction for Men and Women</head>
. <p xml:id="siksaKandangKaresian_05.01">iṅətkən na siksa kandaṅ karəsian, dəṅ
. <app><lem wit="#A #EdASD #H">isəskən</lem><rdg wit="#B">i<lacunaStart/></rdg></app> na haloan, ulah dek
485 <app><lem wit="#A">ṅərikən</lem><rdg wit="#EdASD">ṅəriṅkən</rdg><rdg wit="#H">ṅiriṅkən</rdg></app>
