Cf. <foreign>saṅ hyaṅ sasana krəta</foreign> in SKK 13.3 and 15.1 which seems to be an equivalent expression.</note> [it is] like the crooked meeting its crooked.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.04"><foreign>Paesan </foreign>means mirror. The mirror is like this: If it is not regarded attentively,<note><foreign>kavaas</foreign> ‘to be observed, to be regarded attentively’. In MdS <foreign>waas</foreign> means ‘moving, stirring of satisfying happy feelings (because of seeing an enchanting landscape, listening to a sweet melody, thinking about pleasant experiences, etc.)’. Such a nuance also occurs in OS: SA 42–44 <foreign>sia ləmpaṅ sumoreaṅ, təhər rəmbay na cimata, vaas di na kasorgaan </foreign>‘While going he looked back, and burst into tears, sadly remembering the heavenly abode’. However, in this context, the meaning is more related to MdS <foreign>awas </foreign>‘be able to see well; look properly with o.’s eyes, pay attention closely’ and OJ <foreign>avās </foreign>‘clear (clearly visible or audible), (of persons:) clear, having clear insight; to be clear (evident) that; bright, becoming light’.</note> our image is vague. If it is regarded attentively, our appearance is clear upon that mirror. Likewise are we humans here. If we can follow the customs<note>The word <foreign>upacara</foreign> means ‘the proper conduct, etiquette’, = OJ. In MdS it means ‘ceremony’ = Mal.</note> of others adequately, it may well be internalized<note>Noorduyn &amp; Teeuw note two meanings of this word. The first is ‘to be ignorant’ or ‘to be miserable’, as in MdS = OJ <foreign>kalesan</foreign> ‘afflicted by misfortune’. The second is ‘to be aware of, to become acquainted, to acquaint oneself’. In this passage, the second meaning seems to make more sense. It is attested in RR 729–730 <foreign>aiṅ hayaṅ kalihasan</foreign>, <foreign>təhər dek neaṅ dayəhna </foreign>“I want to acquaint myself personally, and after that I wish to visit their city”. In the Indonesian version of the edition of BM (l. 210) we have <foreign>timburu nu kalihasan</foreign>, but in the english version <foreign>timburu nu kahiasan</foreign>. Since the usage here is transitive, I propose the meaning ‘to internalize’. Cf. SKK 18.5.</note> by our feelings. If we cannot follow the advice, it is called stupid.</p>
1550<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.05"><foreign>Jambaṅan </foreign>means an object giving reflection.<note>Hardjadibrata gives ‘to be reflected in the water’ as the meaning of <foreign>muruy</foreign>, but I rather follow KUBS which paraphrases <foreign>muruy</foreign> as meaning <foreign>ngeunteung kana cai</foreign> ‘to look into water as mirror’. Hardjadibrata glosses MdS <foreign>pamuruyan</foreign> as ‘an object which is reflected’ whereas I consider that it means ‘a place for using water as mirror’. The word is not found in OJ.</note> The mind of the one who is accomplished is like clear water. That is the reason why we should regard [it] attentively, then the heart will be pleased.<note>The meaning of <foreign>rame</foreign> is based on the reference in OJ (&lt; Skt <foreign>ramya</foreign>) ‘to be enjoyed, pleasing, delightful, beautiful’; in MdS it means ‘lively, busy, noisy; pleasant, cosy, animated (discussion), much frequented; closely populated; exciting, thrilling (story, book, film)’ = Mal. <foreign>ramai</foreign>. Cf. SKK 11.7 <foreign>heraṅ tinəṅ, rame ambək</foreign>.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.06"><foreign>Desa</foreign> means settlement. If the settlement is empty, there is nothing to be followed. Words are like that: if they are not substantial, they are considered deceitful. But if the residence is filled, that is to be followed. Likewise are words: they should be meaningful, so that they be considered truthful in character.<note>This seems to be a compound of the type <foreign>sakit hati</foreign> in Malay, so I translate it as ‘truthful in character’. See the second meaning of <foreign>lakṣaṇa</foreign> in OJED ‘action, doing (as opp. to inaction, words, thinking, etc), taking action, proceeding, operating, performing, practice’.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.07">Likewise are we humans here. If we wish to know the source of the joy and happiness, we should remember the word of the Darma Pitutur. This is the verse:</p>
.<p rend="stanza" corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.08">‘The pond is the habitat of the goose;<note>The metaphor of the goose and pond also occurs in VG 2 <foreign>lamunna bahe ka keñca ṅaranna talaga haṅsa, asih voṅ sajagat, pañudana pacar pimula di pahoman</foreign> “if the land is sloping to the left, it is called the pond and the goose, all people will give compassion. The means of purification: <foreign>pacar</foreign> should be planted in the worship place”.</note> the forest is the elephant’s habitat; the sea is the habitat of fishes; flowers are the habitat of the bee’.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.09">The meaning is: if we are going to imitate behavior (<foreign>cəta</foreign>), we should not ask from the wrong people. If we seek to know about the clear pond, fresh water,<note> I choose the B reading, because <foreign>taman heraṅ</foreign> does not make sense; See also <foreign>talaga heraṅ</foreign> at the end of the section. Several OS texts relate the adjectives <foreign>heraṅ</foreign>, or its synonym <foreign>həniṅ</foreign> ‘clear’, with <foreign>talaga</foreign>, viz. PNJ 142–142 <foreign>saṅ hyaṅ talaga heraṅ</foreign>, <foreign>saṅ hyaṅ talaga həniṅ</foreign>; BM 52–53 (as toponym): <foreign>nəpi ka Talaga Həniṅ</foreign>.</note> [we should] ask the goose. The meaning is: if there is a person who is firm in steering,<note>The word <foreign>apraniti</foreign> is derived from Skt. <foreign>praṇīti</foreign> ‘conduct, leading, guidance’. Cf. OJ <foreign>pranīti</foreign> and MdS <foreign>praniti</foreign>. However, the prefixed form <foreign>apranīti</foreign> is not recorded in OJED.</note> whose mind is clear, [and] whose heart is pleasant, that is indeed comparable to the goose on the clear pond.</p>
1555<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.10">If we seek to know about the depth of the sea, <supplied reason="subaudible">we should</supplied> ask a fish. The meaning is: like the man who knows about the mind of the divine king and about the mind of the great scholar.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.11">If we seek to know about the remoteness of forests, [we should] ask the elephant. This is its meaning: what is comparable to the remote<note>The word <foreign>lvar</foreign> literally means ‘exterior’. In MdS, <foreign>luar</foreign> as an adjective for a place often means beyond control: <foreign>urang luar</foreign> ‘outsider’, <foreign>nagara luar</foreign> ‘foreign country’. It is worth noting that MdS <foreign>liar</foreign> means ‘go out, go away from home, wander (roam, rove) around (e.g. of animals seeking food)’. The interchangeability of <foreign>u</foreign> and <foreign>i</foreign> in <foreign>lvar</foreign> and <foreign>liar</foreign> is comparable to such a pair as <foreign>kulon</foreign>/<foreign>kilen</foreign> ‘west’. Cf. RR 963–964 <foreign>sadataṅ ka təgal luar, məntasiṅ di na Saṅ hiaṅ</foreign> ‘Having reached the outer fields, they crossed the Saṅ Hiaṅ’. BM 1381 has Tigal Luar as a toponym, but I think it should be emended to <foreign>təgal luar</foreign>, and probably it is not a toponym: <foreign>ṅalalar ka mulah bəṅhar, ñaṅlandəh ka təgal luar</foreign>. Thus, I translate <foreign>ləvəṅ lvar</foreign> as ‘remote forest’ (cf. Mal. <foreign>hutan liar</foreign>). ASD translate <foreign>lvar</foreign> as ‘isi’ (content).</note> forest is knowing other people’s minds;<note>The relation of the metaphor remote forest (<foreign>ləvəṅ lvar</foreign>) with knowing about people’s mind (<foreign>ñaho di tinəṅ nu reya</foreign>) is hard to understand. It seems to make more sense if the remote forest refers to the peoples mind, so perhaps we need to make conjecture by omitting <foreign>ñaho di</foreign>.</note> what is comparable to the elephant is the power<note>The partial reduplication <foreign>bəbədas</foreign> ‘power’ is from <foreign>bədas</foreign> adj. ‘strong, powerful’. The word <foreign>bedas </foreign>can be found in MdS, the reduplicative form <foreign>bəbədas</foreign> is no longer exist.</note> of Majesty the king.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.12">If we seek to know about the fragrance and sweetness of flowers, [we should] ask the bee. The meaning is: what is comparable to the bee is the skillful man, who is wandering, roaming, [so that he] knows other people’s habits. What is comparable to the fragrant flower is the person who has good conduct, sweet <foreign>baruṅusan</foreign>,<note>The word <foreign>baruṅusan </foreign>is a hapax, not found in dictionaries, perhaps derived from <foreign>buṅus</foreign>. The closest word seems to be OS <foreign>baruṅut </foreign>(cf. MdS <foreign>berengut</foreign> and OJ <foreign>muruṅut</foreign>), but it connotes a negative attitude ‘look surly, look angry, grim’. MdS <foreign>barangasan</foreign> is also similar, but again has a negative connotation ‘grumpy, ill-tempered (by nature), short-/quick-/hot-tempered, irascible, irritable’.</note> smiling expression, pleasing attitude.<note>On the combination of <foreign>tiṅkah suka</foreign>, cf. SA 240 <foreign>tiṅkah suka budi suka </foreign>‘pleasure in behavior and in mind’.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.13">The meaning is: we should not ask from the wrong people. If we seek to know about every kind of story,<note>In this list, we can discern two types of stories: the first are known in the OJ tradition, such as <foreign>Kuñjarakarṇa</foreign>, <foreign>Rāmāyaṇa</foreign>, <foreign>Ādiparva</foreign>, <foreign>Koravāśrama</foreign>, <foreign>Bhīma Svarga</foreign>, <foreign>Raṅga Lave</foreign>, <foreign>Bhomāntaka</foreign>, <foreign>Sumanasāntaka</foreign>, and <foreign>Tantri</foreign>. The <foreign>Saṅ Hyaṅ Hayu</foreign> is also a known OJ work, but it is clearly not a narrative text, and this fact causes doubt about the reading to be adopted here. The other titles, such as <foreign>Darma Jati</foreign>, <foreign>Jayasena</foreign>, <foreign>Sedamana</foreign>, <foreign>Kalapurbaka</foreign>, and <foreign>Jarini</foreign> seem to designate Sundanese-language works or the names of protagonists in known texts. Except for Kalapurbaka, which presumably refers to the text about the birth story of Kala in Old Sundanese (ed. Aditia Gunawan &amp; Agung Kriswanto 2009), the other narratives are difficult to identify among transmitted Old Sundanese works. For the relationship between these stories as one of the frameworks for analyzing the dating, see Chapter 5.</note> such as<note>For the meaning of <foreign>gəs ma</foreign> as ‘such as, for instance’, see Chapter 3, §Morphology.</note> <foreign>Darma Jati</foreign>,<note>Darma Jati is difficult to identify. However, we recognize this name in the main protagonist in Tutur Bvana. In this story, Darma Jati is the Supreme God in cosmology. He fights against Kala Sakti, the representation of evil. As a name of a supreme deity, Darma Jati also appears in Kavih Paniṅkəs.</note> <foreign>Saṅ Hyaṅ Hayu</foreign>, <foreign>Jayasena</foreign>,<note>Jayasena is another name for Bhīma in the Virātaparva. Could it contain a story of Bhīma other than the Bhīma Svarga?</note> <foreign>Sedamana</foreign>,<note>Sedamana is attested as one of a character in the Fragment of Carita Parahyaṅan, as a person who built the palace of Pakuan.</note> <foreign>Kuñjarakarna</foreign>, <foreign>Ramayana</foreign>, <foreign>Adiparva</foreign>, <foreign>Koravasrama</foreign>, <foreign>Bima Sorga</foreign>, <foreign>Raṅga Lave</foreign>, <foreign>Boma</foreign>, <foreign>Sumana</foreign>, <foreign>Kalapurbaka</foreign>, <foreign>Jarini</foreign>,<note>Jarini could not be confirmed, although this name also appears as a text in Svavar Cinta.</note> <foreign>Tantri</foreign>, all types of stories, [we should] ask the performer (<foreign>memen</foreign>).</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.14">If we seek to know about all kinds of songs (<foreign>kavih</foreign>):<note>For <foreign>kavih</foreign> as a specific genre in Old Sundanese literature, see Chapter 4.</note> songs for the elderly,<note>The combination <foreign>bvat tuha </foreign>literally means ‘for old age’. The <foreign>Kavih Mahañana</foreign> begins with opening lines <foreign>ini kavih mahañana, pikavihən bvat maṅkuk</foreign> “This is the song of great mind, to be sung for living”. </note> long songs, amusement songs,<note>I render <foreign>lalaṅuan</foreign> from OJ <foreign>laṅ</foreign>ə̄ ‘subjectively) the feeling of longing or being entranced (by beauty or love), aesthetic experience, romantic feelings, the raptures of love’. In MdS, we only find the derivative form <foreign>kalangenan </foreign>‘amusement, pleasure, sport, entertainment’.</note> advice songs,<note>The title <foreign>kavih pañaraman</foreign> is mentioned as a title of the Old Sundanese poem published as <foreign>Sevaka Darma</foreign>. See Chapter 4.</note> allusive songs,<note>In MdS, <foreign>sisindiran</foreign> has two meanings, one from <foreign>sindir</foreign> ‘allusion’, the other a technical term for verse with rhyme, like the Malay <foreign>pantun</foreign>.</note> <foreign>peṅpeledan </foreign>songs,<note>Danadibrata notes <foreign>péléd</foreign>, <foreign>méléd</foreign> ‘<foreign>mundur bari nyisi sabab di hareupeun rék aya nu ngaliwat</foreign>’ (move backward while tilting the body to the side because someone wants to pass). If the OS word <foreign>peled</foreign> is the same as MdS <foreign>péléd</foreign> which refers to movement, then <foreign>kavih peṅpeledan</foreign> presumably refers to a kind of singing along while rocking the body.</note> rafter hole (<foreign>boṅboṅ kaso</foreign>) [songs], <foreign>pore rane </foreign>[songs]<foreign>, </foreign>sword-grass track (<foreign>porod ərih</foreign>) [songs]<foreign>, babahanan </foreign>songs<foreign>, </foreign>bearish (<foreign>babaroṅan</foreign>) songs<foreign>, taṅtuṅ </foreign>songs<foreign>, </foreign>lament songs<foreign>, </foreign>dancing songs, all types of songs, [we should] ask the virtuoso (<foreign>paraguna</foreign>).<note>In OJ, the term <foreign>paraguṇa</foreign> means ‘(Skt.) the virtues (talents, etc) of others’, but it does not seem to fit the context. In Sanskrit, we find several meaning of <foreign>guṇa</foreign> related to music ‘the string of musical instrument, the merit of composition (consistency, elegance of expression)’. It is difficult to decide whether the <foreign>paraguna</foreign> is the virtuoso composer of music or of its lyrics, or the virtuoso performer. Since AG 3r contains <foreign>paraguna</foreign> in a list with <foreign>memen</foreign>, the latter option seems preferable: <foreign>panday bəsi panday omas, memen paraguna, hambha lavak </foreign>“blacksmith, goldsmith, performer, virtuoso, [and] joker”. Cf. KaMan 1491–1492 <foreign>pahi dəṅən paraguna</foreign>, <foreign>kumbakara</foreign> (ms. <foreign>hambakara</foreign>) <foreign>palukisan </foreign>“All together with the <foreign>paraguna</foreign>, jar maker, painter”; see also lines 1496–1498: <foreign>kasorgaan hamba da … dək</foreign>, <foreign>citrakara</foreign> (ms. <foreign>cətakara</foreign>) <foreign>paṅlukisan</foreign>, <foreign>mara gəndiṅ</foreign> (ms. <foreign>gidiṅ</foreign>) <foreign>patumeṅan</foreign>. Cf. OJ where Zoetmulder notes <foreign>prakavi</foreign> ‘the poets (= <foreign>para kavi</foreign>); versed in poetry’. In this case, I take <foreign>para</foreign> as a prefix (see my comment on <foreign>prətələm</foreign> in SKK 7.3; cf. Chapter 3, §Morphology).</note></p>
1560<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.15">If we seek to know about the jesters (<foreign>para macəh</foreign>):<note>In MdS <foreign>maceuh</foreign> means ‘extreme(ly), excessive(ly) (given over to bad habits)’, but in OJ, Zoetmulder interprets <foreign>pacəh</foreign> as ‘(prob. with an open mouth &gt;) merry, laughing, hilarious; astonished, amazed’. The personal article <foreign>para</foreign> seems to indicate that <foreign>macəh</foreign> is a noun, so I interpret it as meaning ‘jester’ in the present context. Cf. <foreign>mirus</foreign> below.</note> the performance of a jester (<foreign>cəta macəh</foreign>), the performance of a buffoon (<foreign>mirus</foreign>),<note>My emendation of transmitted <foreign>nirus</foreign> to <foreign>mirus</foreign> is based on the parallel passage in <ref target="DHARMA_CritEdSasanaMahaguru.xml#sasanaMahaguru_10.02">SMG 10.2</ref> where we find <foreign>mirus</foreign>. Although it seems to be an active derivation from base <foreign>pirus </foreign>(attested in OJ), the word functions as a noun in OS. I interpret <foreign>mirus</foreign> as synonymous with <foreign>pirus</foreign> ‘buffoon’ (cf. Acri 2014).</note> the mask show (<foreign>tatapukan</foreign>), the bear show (<foreign>babaroṅan</foreign>), <foreign>bakutrak</foreign> show (<foreign>babakutrakan</foreign>)<foreign>,</foreign><note>Cf. MdS <foreign>bakutrak</foreign> = <foreign>baketrak</foreign>, <foreign>ngabaketrak</foreign> ‘adj. hard; <foreign>teuas ngabaketrak</foreign> very hard’. It is noteworthy the resemblance of onomatopoeia words <foreign>kutrak</foreign>, <foreign>ketrok</foreign>, <foreign>kétrok</foreign>, <foreign>kotrék</foreign> in MdS which indicate a sound of knocking two or more hard items, viz. <foreign>pakotrék</foreign> ‘with a click or a bang knock against each other, give sound when touching each other (e.g. of two sticks, of two teeth growing towards each other)’; <foreign>ketrok</foreign> ‘vi. knock (esp. with the hand on a door etc.); <foreign>ngetrok</foreign> knock or strike a blow on st. (e.g. on so.’s head with a ladle); <foreign>ngetrokkeun</foreign> knock on/against with st.; kutrak-ketrok and ketrak-ketrok keep on knocking; <foreign>keketrok</foreign> knock (at the door); <foreign>pangetrok</foreign> (door-) knocker’. I interpret <foreign>babakutrakan</foreign> as a kind of performance that involves combat with wooden sticks.</note> <foreign>abaṅ-abaṅan</foreign> (?)<foreign>,</foreign><note>In MdS, <foreign>abang</foreign> means ‘1 n. term of address for men coming from Jakarta and surrounding areas whose mother tongue is Malay. <foreign>abang</foreign> 2 adj. Jav. red; <foreign>abang panatas</foreign> term to indicate the reddish colour of a cert. type of rooster; <foreign>abang-abang lambé</foreign> flattery (behind which o. hides his true feelings or intentions), blarney, (sl.) soft sawder’. I am inclined to interpret that it is probably connected to <foreign>abang-abang lambé</foreign> ‘flattery’ which alludes to a kind of performance involving the act of flattering.</note> swallowing a pointed bamboo (<foreign>nərəy pañcaṅ</foreign>)<foreign>,</foreign><note>My emandation pañcaṅ is based on a connection of this word with Mal. pancang n ‘potongan bambu (kayu dan sebagainya) yang pangkalnya runcing, ditancapkan atau dihunjamkan ke tanah (untuk tanda batas, tambatan, penguat pinggir parit, dan sebagainya)’ (KBBI, s.v. pancang). This word is not attested in OS, however, it occurs in pantun Lutung Kasarung 8: ku dalem henteu ditolih, ja dalem pancang ngombara ‘[It is] not regarded by the dalem, because the dalem is the illuminating pole’. My emendation is also supported by the occurrence of MdS pancan ‘n. crossed slats of bamboo (to fortify scaffolding, etc.)’.</note> the sleight of hand (<foreign>munikən ləbur</foreign>),<note>The literal meaning of this phrase is ‘hiding [something and causing it to] disappear’.</note> the pounding block competition (<foreign>ṅadu ləsuṅ</foreign>)<foreign>,</foreign><note>I interpret this performance as an equivalent of what is nowadays called gondang, ngagondang ‘rhythmically pound on the rice-stamping block accompanied by singing (by several women esp. during moonlight, also on the occasion of circumcision feast and in the past as a homage to arriving and departing dignitaries); lagu gondang k.o. rice-pounding alternate singing’.</note> entering the <foreign>lantar</foreign> (?)<foreign>,</foreign><note>I wonder whether <foreign>lantar </foreign>should be emended to <foreign>lintar </foreign>‘casting net’. Cf. some meanings of <foreign>lantar</foreign> in MdJ ‘bamboo bridge railing; bamboo pole used for plucking fruit from a tree’.</note> the competition of elder women (<foreign>ṅadu nini</foreign>), all kinds of amusement, [we should] ask the actor (<foreign>həmpul</foreign>).</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.16">If we seek to know about <foreign>pantun</foreign>s<note>It seems that these four pantun titles are related to the Pajajaran cycle. Laṅga Laraṅ reminds us of Angga Larang, who is referred to in the Carita Varuga Guru as the father of King Sili Vaṅi: <foreign>prəbu aṅga laraṅ puputra prəbu sili vaṅi, jumənəṅ ñakravati pajajaran</foreign>. Bañak Catra is a character in Banyumas folklore, considered as the ancestor of the local people. The story of this figure occurs, for example, in the Babad Pasir, a Banyumas chronicle, which narrates how Bañak Catra (or Kamandaka), the ancestor of Banyumas people, came from Pajajaran (Knebel 1900). While Hatur Vaṅi is not found in the corpus of pantun narratives, one of the well-known pantun titles is Gantangan Wangi, after the name of the protagonist, a son of Prabu Sili Wangi. So perhaps Hatur Vaṅi can be identified as Gantangan Wangi, or at least as a hero belonging to Sili Wangi’s family. We can infer the existence as early as the 15th century of a tradition of pantun performance inspired by a narrative cycle centered on the Pajajaran kingdom. On <foreign>pantun </foreign>narrative in general, see Chapter 2, §Pantun.</note> [such as] <foreign>Laṅga Laraṅ</foreign>, <foreign>Bañak Catra</foreign>, <foreign>Sili Vaṅi</foreign>, <foreign>Hatur Vaṅi</foreign>, [we should] ask the <foreign>pantun</foreign> bard (<foreign>prəpantun</foreign>).<note>On the prefix <foreign>prə</foreign>-, see Chapter 3, §Morphology.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.17">As for all kinds of<note>All occurrences of <foreign>salvirniṅ</foreign> in this text, which are located as a first word in 11.15–19, is an emendation. Manuscript A consistently has <foreign>savaliraniṅ</foreign> or <foreign>savalviraniṅ</foreign>, while B <foreign>savaluraniṅ</foreign> or <foreign>savaliraniṅ</foreign>. It seems that the scribes have confused the words <foreign>sarva</foreign> and <foreign>lvir</foreign> and they intend to write <foreign>sarva lviraniṅ</foreign>?</note> decorative patterns (<foreign>tulis</foreign>)<note>See Aditia Gunawan 2019: 88–89 for the interpretation of these motifs. Some of these names are still known from modern batik and the chance is very high that the context of their use was mostly textile also at the time of the SKK’s composition — though we cannot exclude that some patterns were also used on other materials.</note> [such as] the spiral motif (<foreign>pupuñjəṅan</foreign>)<foreign>, </foreign>the writhing motif (<foreign>hihiṅgulan</foreign>)<foreign>, </foreign>the flower motif (<foreign>kəkəmbaṅan</foreign>)<foreign>, </foreign>the forest motif (<foreign>alas-alasan</foreign>)<foreign>, </foreign>people motif (<foreign>uraṅ-uraṅan</foreign>)<foreign>,</foreign><note>Here I interpret <foreign>uraṅ</foreign> as ‘people’, while ASD translate it as ‘shrimp’. We only find <foreign>huraṅ</foreign> and never <foreign>uraṅ</foreign> in the meaning shrimp’ in OS. Cf. RD 18 <foreign>mətu banaspati niṅ avaṅ-avaṅ, tavur na bələm huraṅ hayu</foreign>; SC 165 <foreign>təhər pelag olah-olah, na paray dikəmbaṅ lvapaṅ, huraṅ ta dikəmbaṅ dadap</foreign>. On this point, I revise my interpretation in Aditia Gunawan 2019: 88–89.</note> picture motif (<foreign>məmətahan</foreign>)<foreign>, </foreign>the diagonal motif (<foreign>sisiraṅan</foreign>), the climbing fern motif (<foreign>taruk hata</foreign>), lotus flower, any kind of decorative pattern, [we should] ask the painter (<foreign>lukis</foreign>).</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.18">As for all kinds of forging, the three weapons are what differentiates them. As for the weapons for the king, they are sword, sickle (? <foreign>abət</foreign>),<note>Previous editors have interpreted the word <foreign>abət</foreign> as meaning ‘whip’, based on its resemblance to the verb <foreign>sabət</foreign>. In OJ and MdS, <foreign>sabət</foreign> means ‘to whip, slap’. Zoetmulder glosses <foreign>abət</foreign> as ‘sweeping stroke, slash; a striking weapon?’ I prefer to relate <foreign>abət</foreign> to Mal. <foreign>sabit</foreign> ‘sickle’ which is more plausible as a weapon produced by a blacksmith.</note>, <foreign>pamuk</foreign>, cleaver (<foreign>golok</foreign>), stabbing knife (<foreign>peso təndət</foreign>), kris. The Raksasas are their deities, for they are utensils to kill everything. As for the weapons of the peasants, they are machete (<foreign>kujaṅ</foreign>), hatchet (<foreign>baliuṅ</foreign>), big axe (<foreign>patik</foreign>), weeding hook (<foreign>kored</foreign>), tapping [knife] (<foreign>sadap</foreign>).<note>The context suggests that the word <foreign>sadap</foreign> refers to <foreign>peso sadap. </foreign>See Hardjadibrata (2003), s.v. <foreign>péso</foreign>, a kind of knife to tap the sap of areca (sugar) palm. On Balinese drawings representing a figure of a tapper bearing a knife, see Jákl (2021: 27–36). Cf. Mal. <foreign>sadap </foreign>‘to tap’, <foreign>penyadap </foreign>‘tapper’.</note> The Detyas are their deities, for they are utensils to obtain things to eat and things to drink. As for the weapons of the scholar (<foreign>pandita</foreign>), they are the [betelnut] cutter (<foreign>kalakatri</foreign>),<note>According to Tom Hoogervorst (personal communication, 5 November 2019), the word appears as Makasar <foreign>kalakatti</foreign>, Bugis <foreign>kalakatti</foreign>, Gayo <foreign>klati</foreign>, Karo Batak <foreign>kalakati</foreign>, Minangkabau <foreign>kalakati</foreign>. We also find similar words that mean ‘areca nut cutter’ in various Indian languages, both New Indo-Aryan (e.g. Oriya <foreign>khilikāti</foreign> [Turner 1962–1966: 203]) and Dravidian (e.g. Malayalam kiḷikkatti [Gundert 1872, s.v. kiḷi and katti]). In the light of this evidence, it is likely that the word was borrowed into Nusantaran languages from some Indian sources, and it is clear that the OS reflex is an example of intrusive <foreign>r</foreign>. See Chapter 3, §Phonology.</note> whittling knife (<foreign>peso raut</foreign>), <foreign>doṅdaṅ</foreign> knife, <foreign>paṅot </foreign>knife, spike (<foreign>pakisi</foreign>). The Danavas are their deities, for they are utensils to cut everything. That is, once again, why the three weapons are differentiated: for the king, for the peasant, for the scholar. Thus, if we wish to know all of that, [we should] ask the blacksmith (<foreign>panday</foreign>).</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.19">As for all kinds of carvings: made like snakes, made like bears, modeled after birds, modeled after monkeys,<note>The word <foreign>vəre</foreign> is only attested in this OS text. It is surely equivalent with OJ <foreign>vre </foreign>‘monkey’.</note> modeled after lions — every kind of carving, [we should] ask the scabbard carver (<foreign>maraṅguy</foreign>).<note>The word <foreign>maraṅguy</foreign> is a variant spelling of <foreign>maraṅgi</foreign> (cf. <foreign>suruy</foreign> vs. <foreign>suri </foreign>in SKK 11.1). In MdS (as also in OJ) <foreign>maraṅgi</foreign> is ‘a kris scabbard maker’. However, the present context suggests a more general meaning than a <foreign>kris</foreign> scabbard maker. Since this section follows a list of weapons, it seems plausible that the word could mean more generally ‘scabbard carver’. </note></p>
1565<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.20">All kinds of preparations:<note>See Riadi Darwis 2019 for general interpretations of these techniques.</note> <foreign>ñupar-ñapir,</foreign><note>The reduplication word <foreign>ñupar-ñapir</foreign> is unidentified. The word <foreign>cupar</foreign> in MdS denotes ‘vi. not on (of st. that should have taken place etc.); <foreign>nyuparkeun</foreign> make that st. does not take place, cancel st., undo st., nullify st., annul st., upset (so.’s plan)’, which is unlikely to be the semantic range intended in the present context. I am inclined to relate <foreign>capir</foreign>, the base word of <foreign>ñapir</foreign>, with MdS <foreign>cewir</foreign> (with change of vowel <foreign>a</foreign> to <foreign>ə</foreign> and <foreign>p</foreign> to <foreign>v</foreign>) which means ‘n. (torn off) piece, strip (of paper, fabric, meat); (esp. used with the prefix <foreign>sa</foreign>-, e.g.) <foreign>sacewir kertas</foreign> a strip/sheet of paper; <foreign>nyewiran</foreign> tear off strips or pieces somewhere; <foreign>cecewir</foreign> kp. ear’. Cf. Mal. <foreign>suwir</foreign> which is mainly used to designate dishes such as <foreign>ayam suwir</foreign>. </note> <foreign>rara mandi,</foreign><note>The combination <foreign>rara mandi</foreign> literally means ‘bathing girl’; in SC 174, the food that is processed with this technique is fish scales: <foreign>sisitna dirara-mandi</foreign>, <foreign>tulaṅna dibatcu-raṅu</foreign>. The meaning indicates that the food is processed with gravy. In OJ, <foreign>mandi</foreign> or <foreign>maṇḍi</foreign> means ‘effective; poisonous’, which seems unsuitable with the context.</note> make <foreign>cobek</foreign> (<foreign>ñocobek</foreign>),<note>In MdS <foreign>cobék</foreign> means ‘k.o. spiced dish (baked or cooked), (further indicated by the main constituent) e.g. <foreign>cobék belut</foreign> a <foreign>cobék</foreign> of rice-field eel; <foreign>cobék hurang</foreign> a <foreign>cobék</foreign> of prawns’.</note><foreign> ñopoṅ koneṅ,</foreign><note>In MdS, <foreign>copong</foreign> means ‘with a (running) hole/opening in it (e.g. coin, needle); (of so.’s mind, heart:) clarified, cleared, relieved. However, there is no nasal form *<foreign>nyopong</foreign> in MdS. If we take the base meaning from MdS, then <foreign>ñopoṅ</foreign> seems to mean ‘to make a hole’. Meanwhile, <foreign>koneṅ</foreign> is in MdS the common name of saffron (Mal. <foreign>kunyit</foreign>). What these words could mean together is unclear to me.</note> <foreign>ñaṅlarkən,</foreign><note>The verb <foreign>ñaṅlarkən</foreign> is not recorded in dictionaries. I leave the word without interpretation.</note> <foreign>ñarəṅsəṅ,</foreign><note>We find <foreign>disarəṅsəṅ</foreign> in SC 178 <foreign>hayam bərəm disarəṅsəṅ</foreign> ‘red chicken prepared with <foreign>sarəṅsəṅ</foreign>’, but the context does not give a clear meaning. The base word seems to be <foreign>səṅsəṅ</foreign>. In MdS <foreign>nyeungseung</foreign> (from <foreign>seungseung</foreign>) indicates ‘beginning to shape, beginning to swell (of the breasts of a girl)’, while in OJ <foreign>səṅsəṅ</foreign> means ‘radiant, radiating, aglow’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>söṅ</foreign>).</note><foreign> ñəsəṅit,</foreign><note>The word <foreign>ñəsəṅit</foreign> seems to be connected with MdS <foreign>seungit</foreign> ‘fragrant’, so <foreign>ñəsəṅit</foreign> could yield a meaning ‘to make fragrant’. Could it be synonymous with <foreign>diruruum</foreign>? </note><foreign> ñayaṅ ku pədəs</foreign>,<note><foreign>ñayaṅ ku pədəs</foreign> literally means ‘build a nest with the pepper’.</note> roasting (<foreign>bəbələman</foreign>), grilling (<foreign>papaṅgaṅan</foreign>), <foreign>kakasian,</foreign><note>Cf. OJ <foreign>kasyan</foreign> ‘food prepared in a particular way’, attested exclusively in the list of food items found typically in the inscriptions of 10th-c. King Sindok. SKK seems to confirm that the base word would be <foreign>kasi. </foreign>Alas, the meaning remains obscure.</note> mincing (<foreign>hahañaṅan</foreign>)<foreign>,</foreign><note>The form <foreign>hahañaṅan</foreign> is a hapax in OS, but the base <foreign>hañaṅ</foreign> is recorded in OJED, meaning ‘unsalted’, listed among the types of dried meat (<foreign>ḍeṅ</foreign>); cf. the Mantyasih I inscription (907) B.3:<foreign> ḍeṅ hasin, ḍeṅ hañaṅ, ḍeṅ taruṅ</foreign>. However, a Balinese dictionary records <foreign>anyang</foreign> as ‘lauk dari daging cincang, dicampur dengan kelapa’. I choose to translate it as ‘mincing’, based on the Balinese sense of <foreign>anyang</foreign> and a close semantic meaning with <foreign>raraməsan</foreign> ‘mixing’.</note> mixing (<foreign>raraməsan</foreign>)<foreign>, </foreign>perfuming (<foreign>diruruum</foreign>)<foreign>,</foreign> sweetening (<foreign>diamis-amis</foreign>) — every kind of preparation, [we should] ask a <foreign>harəp catra</foreign>.<note>While <foreign>harəp</foreign> means ‘the front, fore part’, and <foreign>catra</foreign> is probably based on Sanskrit <foreign>chattra</foreign> ‘parasol’, the way in which the combination of these two words would yield the meaning ‘cook’ that we expect here is obscure. Cf. <ref target="DHARMA_CritEdSasanaMahaguru.xml#sasanaMahaguru_15.06">SMG 15.6</ref>.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.21">All kinds of (woven) textile:<note>For the interpretation of motifs/types of woven textile, see Aditia Gunawan 2019: 89–92.</note> candlenut flower (<foreign>kəmbaṅ muñcaṅ</foreign>), <foreign>seṅgaṅ</foreign>’s stem (<foreign>gagaṅ seṅgaṅ</foreign>), moon-alike (<foreign>same leg</foreign>), group of səmat (<foreign>səmat sahurun</foreign>), plaited cage (<foreign>añam cayut</foreign>), <foreign>sigəji</foreign> motif, stone motif (<foreign>pasi-pasi</foreign>), <foreign>kalaṅkaṅ ayakan</foreign>, <foreign>poleṅ raganis</foreign>, <foreign>jayanti</foreign>, <foreign>cəcəmpaan</foreign>, <foreign>paparanakan</foreign>, <foreign>maṅin haris</foreign>, <foreign>siliganti</foreign>, <foreign>boeh siaṅ</foreign>, <foreign>bəbər natan</foreign>, <foreign>papakanan</foreign>, <foreign>surat avi</foreign>, <foreign>parigi ñeṅsoh</foreign>, <foreign>gagañjar</foreign>, <foreign>lusiyan bəsar</foreign>, <foreign>kampuh jayanti</foreign>, <foreign>hujan riris</foreign>, <foreign>laris</foreign>, <foreign>boeh alus</foreign>, <foreign>ragen paṅanten</foreign> — every kind of textile, <supplied reason="subaudible">we should</supplied> ask the weaver (<foreign>paṅəyək</foreign>).</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.22">If we seek to know about all kinds of laws: established customs (<foreign>acara</foreign>) are under codified law (<foreign>adigama</foreign>),<note>In Skt., as well as in OJ, <foreign>adhigama</foreign> means ‘ the act of obtaining, acquisition; mastery, study, knowledge) study, knowledge; the knowledge of right conduct (according to the law); name of a work on law’. I prefer to interpret it as ‘a work on law or codified law’.</note> <foreign>adigama</foreign> is under teacher’s regulations (gurugama), teacher’s regulations are under elders’ regulations (tuhagama), elders’ regulations are under approval (satmata),<note>Attested in OS and OJ, the word <foreign>satmata</foreign> is a variant of <foreign>sanmata</foreign> ‘Skt. agreed to, approved; thought highly of, esteemed; opinion; consent, assent) approval, assent; kind (benevolent) disposition towards others, favour, sympathetic reception; (adj.) kindly disposed, sympathetic’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>sanmata</foreign>).</note> approval is under public outcry (surak loka), public outcry is under court proceedings (vicara). High people<note>I consider <foreign>utama-janma</foreign> as a Sanskrit compound ‘high people, high birth’. Cf. Ślo 31j <foreign>kaliṅanya, saṅ sādhujana sira saṅ vvaṅ uttama-janma, yadyapi sira nirdhana</foreign>, <foreign>kasyasiha tuvi, agaveha ta sira salah kārya, salah hiḍəp, taha tan maṅkana saṅ vvaṅ uttama-janma</foreign> “The meaning is: <foreign>saṅ sādhujana</foreign> is one of high birth. Even if he is poor and also pitiable, will he do a wrong act [and will he have] wrong thoughts? No, the one of high birth is certainly not like that”. TK 24j.2<foreign> mapan ikaṅ sinaṅguh uttama-janma </foreign>“for he is considered to be one of high birth”; KM 248<foreign> riṅ voṅ aṅucap-ucap lāvan rabiniṅ voṅ tumuli kapiṅhit dene lakine voṅ uttama-janma</foreign>, <foreign>iku strīsaṅgrahaṇa arane </foreign>“If someone speaks with a married woman and then she is isolated in the house by her husband [and the latter is] one of high birth, that is called adultery”<foreign>.</foreign></note> are outside of guilt, people outside<note>The word <foreign>vaheya</foreign> seems to correspond to Skt. <foreign>bāhya</foreign>/OJ <foreign>vāhya</foreign> ‘(being) outside, outward, external, outwardly visible, pertaining to the world of the senses’.</note> are of high guilt<note>I have attempted to give a literal translation but must admit that at the present state of our knowledge of the social system in 15th-century Sunda, the meaning of the phrase utama-janma vaheya dosa, vaheya-janma utama dosa remains quite obscure.</note> — every kind of law, [we should] ask the tandas.<note>For the use of the personal article <foreign>para</foreign> marking <foreign>taṇḍa</foreign> as plural in OJ context, see, e.g., <foreign>Ghaṭotkacāśraya</foreign> 5.5, 48.7, and <foreign>Sumanasāntaka</foreign> 15.10, 19.4 (cf. Jákl 2019). In contrast with OJ <foreign>taṇḍa</foreign>, <foreign>tanda</foreign> in OS is related with a legal, not a military context.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.23">If we seek to know about the strategies of war: <foreign>makara</foreign> formation,<note>In this paragraph there are six terms containing the word <foreign>bihva</foreign>. This word is obviously a localized spelling of Sanskrit <foreign>vyūha</foreign>. In OJ, both <foreign>vyūha</foreign> and <foreign>byūha</foreign> are attested. I choose the reading <foreign>bihva</foreign> of A instead of <foreign>byiha </foreign>found in B based on phonological reasons: from <foreign>vi-yu-ha</foreign> &gt; <foreign>bi-yu-ha</foreign> &gt; <foreign>bi-hu-va</foreign> &gt; <foreign>bihva</foreign>. The term <foreign>makara-bihva</foreign> is a localized spelling for <foreign>makarabyūha</foreign>, and designates a kind of battle formation. In OJ, this battle array occurs in the BY 13.24: <foreign>hetu śrī nr̥pa dharmasūnu maṅutus magəlara makarabyūhādbhuta</foreign>|<foreign>dhr̥ṣṭadyumna ghaṭotkacāgrani supitnya makatutuka vīra sātyaki </foreign>| <foreign>saṅ mādryātmaja netra pāndavasutā suṅuta saṅ abhimanyu nāsikā </foreign>| <foreign>śrī dharmātmaja təṇḍas aṅga valakaṅ para ratu tinata təkeṅ vugat </foreign>“And so Yudhiṣṭhira had his troops drawn up into the wonderful <foreign>makara </foreign>battle array: Dhr̥ṣṭadyumna and Ghaṭotkaca were ensconced on the tips of the pincers, the heroic Sātyaki on the mouth, the sons of Madrī were on the eyes, the [five] sons of the Pāṇḍawas were on the tentacles, Abhimanyu on the nose, Yudhiṣṭhira on the head, and on the body, the back and the tail were the allied kings” (Supomo 1993: 82–83; 187). See also Jákl 2014: 48.</note> chariot formation,<note>The term <foreign>sakata-bihva</foreign> means ‘chariot formation’ (cf. Skt. <foreign>śakaṭa</foreign>). In OJ, this formation is attested in RY 9.76, when the troops of Aleṅka seek to kill Hanoman: <foreign>dinānan ikaṅ rākṣasānuṅ pravīra, asiṅ tan surud riṅ musuh śūra sāra, ya muṅgvi harəpniṅ rathānuṅ paṅəṇḍas</foreign>, <foreign>ṅaranyāhaləp śākaṭabyūhanāma</foreign> “They were extremely courageous demons, who would not retreat in the face of a powerful and brave opponent. They were re-arranged in front of his wagon to form the advance guards, of the excellent battle array <foreign>śākaṭabyūha</foreign> (wagon-battle array)” (Soewito Santoso 1980: 269).</note> <foreign>linsang</foreign> formation,<note>The term <foreign>lisaṅ-bihva</foreign> is a hybrid. It is true that <foreign>lisaṅ</foreign> in not found in MdS, but it is likely related to Mal. <foreign>linsang</foreign>, a kind of carnivorous mammal (Prionodon gracilis).</note> lion formation,<note>The ‘lion formation’ (<foreign>siṅha-bihva</foreign>) is attested in the <foreign>Sumanasāntaka </foreign>147.11 as <foreign>singhāṅantī guhā byūha </foreign>‘lion waiting in the cave formation’, in the episode when Prince Aja is surrounded by seven kings who use this battle array.</note> <foreign>garuda</foreign> formation,<note>The ‘eagle formation’ (<foreign>garuda-bihva</foreign>) occurs under the synonymous name <foreign>khagendrabyūha</foreign> in Sutasoma 99.8: <foreign>khagendrabyūhānuṅ gəlarira patuk bāṇa matəguh, həlar kānan śaṅkottara kiva muvah salva janaka, ri təṇḍas saṅ vīrāpatih ika mahācūra suyaśa, narendre pr̥ṣṭhāṅgəhnira milu dhīra māya ri vugat </foreign>“His battle-array was that called the <foreign>garuḍa</foreign> formation, with the strong Bāṇa as his beak, on the right wing were Śaṅka and Uttara, on the left Salva and Janaka; at the head was the courageous prime minister, very powerful and very famous. The king’s place was to the rear at the tail assisted by the fearless Māya” (Soewito Santoso 1975 I: 155; 1975 II: 195).</note> wheel formation,<note>This formation is mentioned in BhY 13.22, in the episode of Abhimanyu’s death. This character died because he was trapped in the wheel formation made by the Koravas:<foreign>yekan garjita saṅ varadvija harəp ri hilaṅanira Pāṇḍaveśvara </foreign><foreign>nāhan marma nirāgave gəlar anindya vəkas iṅ atidurgamārusit </foreign><foreign>cakrabyūha ṅaranya nora vənaṅ aṅrusaka ri taya Bhīma Phalguna </foreign><foreign>Karṇa Droṇa Kr̥pādi Korava sukinya makakipiṅ ikaṅ vatək ratu </foreign>“Desiring the destruction of the Pāṇḍawas, the eminent brahmin was delighted, and he drew up his army into a perfect formation that was most difficult to penetrate. It was called the discus battle array, which, in the absence of both Bhīma and Arjuna, would be indestructible. Karṇa, Droṇa, Kr̥pa and the Koravas were stationed on the hub, while all the other kings were on the rim” (Supomo 1993: 187).</note> needle point (<foreign>suci-muka</foreign>), iron cage (<foreign>bajra-pañjara</foreign>),<note>Although in Sanskrit studies, it is customary to associate the word <foreign>vajra</foreign> with the meanings ‘thunderbolt’ or ‘diamond’, I choose to interpret the loanword <foreign>bajra</foreign> as ‘iron, steel’. Rigg (1862: 364) defines <foreign>waja</foreign> as ‘a kind of hard iron or steel’ and explicitly connects it to Skt. <foreign>vajra</foreign>. Hoogervorst (2017: 386) notes that the meaning of ‘steel’ also manifests itself in Skt. through such compounds as <foreign>granthivajraka</foreign>, <foreign>śaivalāvajra</foreign>, <foreign>śoṇavajra</foreign> and <foreign>svarṇavajra</foreign>, all denoting types of steel<foreign>. </foreign>The precise term <foreign>bajra-pañjara</foreign> also occurs in the Bukit Gombak I inscription from 14th-century West Sumatra (Krom 1912: 51; Brandes 1913: 258–259), in the royal epithet <foreign>saraṇāgatabajrapañjara</foreign> ‘iron (or diamond) cage for those who come to seek refuge’. Cf. the terms combined with <foreign>vəsi</foreign> or <foreign>bəsi</foreign> in OS and OJ: <foreign>koñjara vəsi</foreign> ‘iron-cage’ in CVG 226 (in Pleyte 1913: 376), <foreign>ruji bəsi</foreign> ‘iron fencing’ in SC quoted in fn. 345, and further <foreign>kandaṅ</foreign>, <foreign>pagar</foreign>, and <foreign>rajəg </foreign>in the toponyms Kandaṅ Vəsi in CP, Pagar Vəsi and Rajəg Vəsi in OJ inscriptions.</note> surrounding dog (<foreign>asu maliput</foreign>), grazing peacock (<foreign>mərak simpir</foreign>),<note>The term <foreign>mərak simpir</foreign> also occurs in KaPang 89 as a name of a textile motif.</note> tailless crow (?, <foreign>gagak saṅkur</foreign>),<note>In Malay, <foreign>sangkur</foreign> means ‘bayonet’, but in Balinese it means ‘have a small tail or no tail at all’. It seems that the Balinese meaning is intended in the text. Zoetmulder (OJED, s.v.) gives a meaning of <foreign>saṅkur</foreign> ‘a part. type of shield (<foreign>ḍaḍap saṅkur</foreign>)? perh. “without tassels”’? Cf. Bal. (KBW): “tailless”’.</note> descending civet (<foreign>luvak maturun</foreign>), climbing deer (<foreign>kidaṅ suməṅka</foreign>), crocodile hole (<foreign>babah buhaya</foreign>),<note>The base word <foreign>babah</foreign> is not found In MdS, but the verb <foreign>ngababah</foreign> means ‘make a hole in st. (a bamboo wall etc. to break in), break through st., break in; <foreign>babahan</foreign> (in a wall etc.) made hole; body opening’. It seems that the base <foreign>babah</foreign> itself has the meaning ‘hole’. Cf. OJ <foreign>babahan</foreign> ‘door, gate, entrance, opening, aperture’. Cf. also Mal. term <foreign>lubang buaya</foreign>, used as a toponym. This suggests that <foreign>babah buhaya</foreign> in this list probably refers to a battlefield landscape, not a battle formation.</note> taking the <foreign>liṅga</foreign> jewel form (<foreign>ṅaliṅga manik</foreign>),<note>In other OS texts (such as SC 1009, BM 1405, and VL 6), <foreign>liṅga manik</foreign> is a term for a specific type of land. This suggests, in the present context, that the term does not designate any kind of battle array, but rather a particular type of battlefield.</note> the victorious land (<foreign>ləmah mrəvasa</foreign>),<note>The word <foreign>mrəvasa</foreign> is derived from <foreign>prəvasa</foreign>, related to <foreign>pravasa</foreign> in OJ. OJED only gives the derived form <foreign>kapravasa</foreign> ‘overpowered’. It is clearly from <foreign>paravaśa</foreign> ‘(Skt) subject to another’s will, subdued, obedient; overpowered, destroyed’. In OJ we find <foreign>amaravaśa</foreign>/<foreign>pinaravaśa</foreign> to overpower, destroy’, which seems to be an equivalent of <foreign>mrəvasa</foreign> in our text. I interpret it as an adjective of <foreign>ləmah</foreign>.</note> ruling (<foreign>adipati</foreign>), dominating power (<foreign>prəbusakti</foreign>),<note>The term <foreign>prəbusakti</foreign> (Skt. and OJ <foreign>prabhuśakti</foreign>) ‘sovereignty’ is often attributed to Śiva as one of his four powers (<foreign>caduśakti</foreign>). Based on OJ treatises, the elements of <foreign>prabhuśakti</foreign> are: 1. fearlessness (<foreign>abhītaḥ</foreign>), 2. undecaying (<foreign>akṣayaḥ</foreign>), 3. unaging (<foreign>ajaraḥ</foreign>), and undying (<foreign>amaraḥ</foreign>) (DhP 282.18–284.16 in Acri 2017; Tjñ 4 in ​​Sudarshana Devi Singhal 1962; see also Chapter 10 §<foreign>Cadu-śakti</foreign>: The Four Powers of the Teacher).</note> the application of war and battle, the effort of <foreign>sapətrik</foreign> (?)<note>One would expect <foreign>siṅ savatək tiṅkah praṅ ma</foreign> between <foreign>savətrik</foreign> and <foreign>saṅ</foreign>. Probably it occurs an eye-skip from <foreign>siṅ</foreign> to <foreign>saṅ</foreign>?</note> — [we should] ask the commander (<foreign>hulu jurit</foreign>).</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.24">If we seek to know about of all kinds of formulas and mantras:<note>The words aji and mantra often occur as a twin form. In OJ, aji has broad meanings ‘holy writ, the scriptures, sacred text; authoritative text (containing e.g. rules of conduct for a brahman; instructions on administration, politics, the practice of arms, the writing of poetry, etc); sacred or magically powerful formula’. In OS, this word is oftenly juxtaposed with mantra, and our context in SKK implies that this word refers to ‘the sacred or magically powerful formula’ rather than ‘scriptures’. Cf. KaPani 664–665 sesedaan sasaktiyan, ṅagəralakən aji mantra “performing supernatural powers, applying formula and mantras”. We also find the combination aji mantra in several passages in SHH (3.2, 3.2, etc.). Cf. SHH 3.3 kajñāna ṅaranya ajñāna ginavay-gavay, apan ginavay ikaṅ aji mantra huṅkara padkara “kajñāna means artificial knowledge, because the formulas [and] mantras of huṅ syllable, of pad syllable are made up (artificially)”.</note> mutterings and prayers (<foreign>jampa jampiya</foreign>)<foreign>,</foreign><note>The combination <foreign>jampa-jampya</foreign> is attested in SHH 3.3 <foreign>ginavay taṅ gəlar pūjā, aji mantra, veda śānti, mvaṅ jampa-jampya samādhi </foreign>“the ceremony, the worship, the formulas, the mantras, the Vedas, the pacifications, as well as the spells and incantations [and finally] meditation are produced”. It seems that <foreign>jampa-jampya</foreign> is a localized representation (with spontaneous nasalization) of Skt. <foreign>japa-jāpya</foreign> ‘muterings and prayers’. Cf. MdS <foreign>jampé</foreign> ‘magic spells for remedy<foreign>’</foreign>. See Chapter 3, §Phonology.</note> restoring consciousness (?, <foreign>gəgəiṅ</foreign>)<foreign>, </foreign>diagrams (?, <foreign>susuratan</foreign>)<foreign>,</foreign><note>The base word <foreign>susuratan</foreign>, <foreign>surat</foreign>, means ‘(drawn) line, writing, drawing, letter’ (OJED, s.v.). It probably refers to a kind of written/drawing formulas or mantras.</note> protections (<foreign>sasaranaan</foreign>)<foreign>,</foreign><note>I interpret <foreign>sarana</foreign> in Skt. meaning: <foreign>śarana</foreign> ‘refuge, protection’.</note> distance vision (? <foreign>kaseraṅan</foreign>)<foreign>, pavayagahan,</foreign><note>Not found in dictionaries, probably related to OJ <foreign>vayakah</foreign>, which Zoetmulder notes “is this the base-word? <foreign>kawayakah</foreign> one on top of the other, in layers?” (OJED, s.v. <foreign>wayakah</foreign>).</note> (mantras) with flowers (? <foreign>pupuspaan</foreign>)<foreign>, </foreign>purification mantras (<foreign>susudaan</foreign>)<foreign>, </foreign>life giving mantras (?, <foreign>hurip-huripan</foreign>)<foreign>,</foreign><note>I take the meaning of <foreign>hurip-huripan </foreign>as an equivalent of MdJ <foreign>urip-uripan </foreign>‘dipitulungi lsp. supaya urip’ (Poerwadarminta 1939: s.v. urip).</note><foreign> tunduk iyəm </foreign>(?)<foreign>, </foreign>astrological formulas (<foreign>pararasen</foreign>)<foreign>,</foreign><note>It occurs as a title of an OJ text on astronomy. On manuscripts from the Merapi-Merbabu area containing this text, see Kartika Setyawati et al., 2002: 36, 37, 139, 165.</note> gnomon (<foreign>pasaṅkvan</foreign>)<foreign>,</foreign><note>In OJ, saṅku means ‘I bowl, dish’. It is also a Sanskrit-derived śaṅku ‘peg, nail, spike; arrow, spear, dart; pin or gnomon of a dial)’, but in the OJ context, it usually refers to a ’particular weapon (spear)’ (OJED, s.v.). According to Zoetmulder, the last meaning of śaṅku is ‘the appointed time (lit. “the time indicated by the pointer on the sundial”)’. Being placed after pararasen, which is related to astronomy, I tend to interpret pasaṅkvan according to the last meaning, as the astronomy formulas based on the sun, in contrast with pararasen (based on the moon).</note> — every kind of sacred formula, [we should] ask the <foreign>brahmana</foreign>.</p>
1570<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.25">If we seek to know about making offerings in the shrine (<foreign>saṅgar</foreign>): the drawings,<note>I understand <foreign>patah </foreign>as Skt <foreign>paṭṭa</foreign> ‘drawing’ (= OJ <foreign>pəṭa</foreign>), attested in SHH 28.3 apa ta katuduhaniṅ gavay saṅ manon ri sakala, ri sədaṅnyan rakut ikiṅ bhuvana śārīra samaṅke, nyaṅaji kāvya sāṅkhya prakaraṇa kalpa purāṇa nyāya viniścaya chanda gaṇita, ṅuniveh tāṅgəlar pūja dhyāna samādhi, mvaṅ paṭṭa liṅga liṅgir pratimā bimba, vihāra śāla kamūlān, parhyaṅan, cetya caṇḍi prasāda stūpa, nahan sakvehniṅ gavay saṅ manon ri sakala kabeh “What are the visible aspects of the activities of the Witness in the manifest, while he is involved in the physical world like this? Here: scriptures, poetry, Sāṅkhya, grammar, ritual, mythology, logic, decision, meter, mathematics; moreover, he performs worship, meditation, absorption. And drawings, liṅgas, statues, images, vihāras, hospices, kamūlāns, sanctuaries, caityas, caṇḍis, towers, stūpas. Such are all the works of the Witness in the manifest”.</note> the leaf offering, <foreign>palajaṅ</foreign> offering,<note>The word palajaṅ is obscure. However, I notice the occurrence of pulajaṅ in GS 121.3–8, which likely refers to a kind of plant. It occurs in the context of offering: ameta pulava maṅke, ki putut amintuhu, tandyaṅ mintar antuk sariñjiṅ, pulajaṅ sampun madaṅ, sampun maṅkva katur, lah ta ninva mumujaa “‘Now you should seek pulavas!’ The putut disciple obeys her. He immediately left, acquiring one basket. Pulajaṅs are ready, now they are already given. ‘Here, Nini! [Requisites] to perform the offering’”. In OJ, pulava is ‘a part. kind of tree (the white fragrant flowers are used in offerings); offering-flowers (KBW s.v. plava II)’, so there are two possibilities: either palajaṅ should be emended to pulajaṅ so we can render it as a synonym of pulava, or palajaṅ is another type of flower used for offering.</note> flower offering, putting a cloth on <foreign>liṅga</foreign>, maintenance of deities — every kind of offering, [we should] ask the <foreign>jaṅgan</foreign>.<note>The term <foreign>jaṅgan</foreign> denotes some kind of religious practitioner and appears frequently in OJ sources. Zoetmulder defines the word <foreign>jaṅgan </foreign>as <foreign>‘jaṅga</foreign> field?’, and <foreign>jaṅga</foreign> as ‘a part. kind of climber with fragrant flowers, prob. = gaḍuṅ’ (OJED, s.v. jaṅga). In MdJ and Bal., jaṅga is a kind of flower = gaduṅ. It seems that term jaṅgan is derived from the name of the flower. It is noteworthy that in Bali, the gadung flower is used for worship. However, jaṅgan as a person occurs in Par 4.27: kaget sira jaṅgan aṅiḍəpakən katunon “The jaṅgan was surprised while watching [it] burn down”. Pigeaud translates this term as ‘rural doctor’ in DV 78.7d: akveh iranya maṅasrayeṅ thani lavan jaṅgan prasiddheṅ jagat “Over many places is their spreading, looking for support in the peasants lands, with the <foreign>janggan</foreign>s (<foreign>rural doctors</foreign>) officiating to the world (the public in general)”, while Robson translates it as ‘rural curer’ (“Numbers of them are found roundabout and they seek the support of the villages and ‘rural curers’ as is well known”). Cf. Kuñj (591–595 in van der Molen 1983), which mentions kajaṅgan along with other places for religious practitioners: kategan kajaṅgan kadevagurvan paṅabətan (K paṅabəkṭan H; om. A) pamaṅuyon paguntuṅan paṅubonan. Supomo (1977: 65–66) notes that jaṅgan also occurs not only in the meaning of person, but also as an establishment in the Arjunavijaya. </note></p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.26">If we seek to know about the descent of time, month of the quake,<note>The meaning of the combination <foreign>bulan grəmpa</foreign> is unclear. The most plausible hypothesis is to take it as a phrase, not as a compound, and to interpret <foreign>bulan</foreign> as ‘month’, and not ‘moon’. This may refer to the earthquake augury found in texts such as <foreign>paliṇḍon </foreign>or <foreign>paliliṇḍon</foreign>, which describe month-based augury. The ceiling of the Kr̥ta Ghoṣa pavilion in Klungkung, painted in the mid-20th century, contains a <foreign>paliṇḍon</foreign> illustration with text corresponding to each month, e.g. an earthquake in the second month is associated with the goddess Gaṅgā (Sastrawan 2022: 18).</note> year without neck, [year] without head, walking world, immobile world, buried earth, earthquake<note>I take <foreign>bumi-grəmpa</foreign> as a localized spelling of Skt. <foreign>bhūmikampa</foreign> ‘earthquake’<foreign>. </foreign>In the recently discovered Warunggahan inscription (issued in 1305), which describes loss of a land title document in an earthquake, the term <foreign>bhūmikampa</foreign> is used for earthquake (Sastrawan 2022: 20).</note> — every kind of knowledge of ancient accounts (<foreign>carek nu bəhəla</foreign>),<note>Cf. SKK 15.1 where we encounter the similar expression <foreign>carita nu bəhəla</foreign>.</note> [we should] ask the <foreign>bujaṅga</foreign>.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.27">If we seek to know about the precepts of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> (<foreign>darma-siksa</foreign>), the precepts of the community (<foreign>siksa kandaṅ</foreign>), becoming an ascetic (<foreign>pasuk tapa</foreign>),<note>My translation of <foreign>pasuk tapa</foreign> as ‘becoming an ascetic’ follows Noorduyn &amp; Teeuw’s translation of SA 213 <foreign>avakana pasuk tapa </foreign>“you should devote yourself to asceticism”.</note> the meditation (?, <foreign>padonaan</foreign>),<note>I interpret <foreign>padonaan</foreign> as an equivalent of <foreign>padhyānan</foreign>, from <foreign>dhyāna </foreign>‘meditation’, even if the form <foreign>pa</foreign>- -<foreign>an</foreign> of <foreign>dhyāna</foreign> is unattested. Cf. SC. 500–503<foreign> patra dəṅ darmasonya, rudamala dəṅ askara, maṅləvi darmaprətuti, darmaveya padonaan. </foreign>In OJ, <foreign>paṅdonan</foreign> means ‘expedition’. I presume that this is due to the interchangeability of phonemes /y/ and /v/: <foreign>padyanaan</foreign> &gt; <foreign>padvanaan </foreign>&gt; <foreign>padonaan</foreign>. Cf. the use of <foreign>ivə</foreign> (Kawa6.4) for MdS <foreign>ieu</foreign>, more commonly spelt <foreign>iyə</foreign> in OS manuscripts.</note> the very pure (act?) (<foreign>mahapavitra</foreign>), the precepts of the teacher, the ten virtues (<foreign>dasa-sila</foreign>), the five teachings (<foreign>pañca-siksa</foreign>), foot sole of the teacher (<foreign>guru-talapakan</foreign>), misfortune of the world (<foreign>jagat-upadrava</foreign>), four powers (<foreign>cadu-sakti</foreign>), the reality of the world (<foreign>tato buvana</foreign>), the reality of the body (<foreign>tato sarira</foreign>), the reality of knowledge (<foreign>tato ajñana</foreign>) — every kind of contents of the books, [we should] ask the scholar.<note>See my analysis of the order and the meaning of these doctrines in Chapter 10.</note> </p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.28">In the first place the blessings (<foreign>kasorgaan</foreign>) in the manifest world: the kingship, the nobility, the eminence, the authority, the supremacy, <supplied reason="subaudible">we should</supplied> ask the king.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.29">If we seek to know about the organization of land (<foreign>patitis bumi</foreign>):<note>In OJ, <foreign>patitis</foreign> means ‘aiming at; direction in which st. moves, goal, target’, while in MdS it means ‘just struck, precisely (as it should), exact.’ Cf. SA 281–282 <foreign>siar sariniṅ ajñana, əsi patitisniṅ rasa </foreign>“You should seek the essence of knowledge, the aim of the feeling”. Literally meaning ‘the aim of land’, <foreign>patitis bumi</foreign> seems to mean here the way land is organized.</note> keeping the land apart,<note>In MdS, <foreign>ngampihkeun</foreign> means ‘have st. kept/stored somewhere (e.g. a car in the garage, animals in the pen or the corral for the night)’. Cf. RR 1112–1114 where we encounter <foreign>ṅampihan</foreign>, translated as ‘give direction’ by Noordyn &amp; Teeuw: <foreign>adiiṅ na Puspa Lava, ku sia gəra jənəṅan, gəra nu ṅampihan rama, na dayəh gəra pagəhan</foreign> “My younger brother, Puspa Lawa, you must quickly take command, give direction to the chief, quickly fortify the town”.</note> consulting all people, ordering [or] discussing (<foreign>marin masini</foreign>), cutting<note>See Hardjadibrata (2003: s.v. <foreign>déngdéng</foreign>), <foreign>ngadéngdéng</foreign> ‘cut similarly, cut/chop straight (e.g. of a piece of wood or bamboo); <foreign>ngadéngdéng jukut</foreign> cut straight the edge of lawn’.</note> and trimming on a level,<note>I interpret <foreign>maras pade </foreign>as two words: maras, from paras, meaning ‘to trim’, and <foreign>pade</foreign> ‘on a level’. I believe that the last word is a variant of <foreign>pada</foreign> ‘equal’. Cf. SA 545 where the active form of pade, made, is attested: <foreign>hañjuaṅ sasipat mata, handələm salaput hulu, </foreign>mañara made paparas<foreign>, javer kotok made toṅgoṅ</foreign>. In MdS, we have a nasal between syllables <foreign>mandé </foreign>(Hardjadibrata 2003: s.v. <foreign>pandé.</foreign> Cf. SC 709 <foreign>mo kadeṅdeṅ kaparas pade, mo karaksa kaopeksa ika</foreign>; PR 36r <foreign>salaran tapa, pakən ṅavastu sa(ṅ)hyaṅ hayu, ka madiya ka vindu puhun rahayu, sahur nu visesa, agəs saṅkup paksa tuṅgal sampak deṅdeṅ paraspade, krəta uraṅ sajagat. </foreign></note> measuring and making equal, fining and punishing.<note>In OJ Pdg 6.1, we find <foreign>sipat</foreign> and <foreign>pīḍana</foreign> among royal punishments, together with more common list of <foreign>śukha-duhkha</foreign>s: <foreign>muvah lvirniṅ rājadaṇḍa, tan kavnaṅ tumibā riṅ saṅ vatək kr̥ta, ndya ta daṇḍa kudaṇḍa, reka, lūdan, tūtan, aṅśa pratyaṅśa, paraḍah, </foreign>sipat, pīḍana<foreign>, vākcapala, hastacapala, duhilatən, idu kasirat, mijilakən vuryaniṅ kikir, ikaṅ daṇḍakrama samaṅkana, tan dadi tumibāheṅ saṅ kr̥ta, apan sira luput riṅ valat vali rājavali, tan katapaka sira riṅ rājaśāsana </foreign>“Moreover, it is a characteristic of the royal punishments that they do not apply to the consecrated ones. As for instance: punishments and physical assault, treachery (<foreign>reka</foreign>), repeated attack (?, <foreign>lūdan</foreign>), pursuit (<foreign>tūtan</foreign>), contested dividing up of shares (?, <foreign>aṅśa pratyaṅśa</foreign>), <foreign>paraḍah</foreign> fines, <foreign>sipat</foreign> fines, oppressing, verbal assault (<foreign>vākcapala</foreign>), physical assault (<foreign>hastacapala</foreign>), defamation (?, <foreign>duhilatən</foreign>), spraying spittle (lit. “spittle that is sprayed”, <foreign>hidu kasirat</foreign>), producing “the trace of a file” (<foreign>mijilakən vuryaniṅ kikir</foreign>), all of this series of punishments, it is impossible that they would apply to the consecrated ones, for the latter are exempt from the use of violence in retribution, [especially retribution] by the king, they will not be subject to <foreign>Rājaśāsana</foreign>”. Cf. Sva sipat, ya ta lvir, 40000, tuvi pinaten kavnaṅ, ndah tan kneṅ lokika:, sajatya nir sipat; SC 300 k<foreign>asamur bənaṅ mitutur, roṅod bənaṅ nu ṅadeṅdeṅ, maraspade ñipat midana</foreign>.</note> If it is highland, it is made to be flat, headland is made to be equal<note>The word <foreign>pakpak</foreign> is not found in MdS, but probably it is clearly related to MdS <foreign>papak </foreign>‘level, equal’. In OJ <foreign>pakpak</foreign> means ‘to flatter, address with soothing words, persuade gently, coax’, which clearly does not fit the context. Here <foreign>dipakpak</foreign> probably means ‘to be made equal’. Cf. Chapter 3, §Phonology.</note> (with the shore?), all kinds of dependent villages (? <foreign>ampih-ampih</foreign>),<note>The reduplicated form <foreign>ampih-ampih</foreign> is probably equivalent with OJ <foreign>ampihan</foreign> ‘dependent villages’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>ampih </foreign>2). In MdS <foreign>ampih-ampih</foreign> means ‘put away the tools, clear the table (to eat etc.); save some pennies aside’.</note> we should ask the Maṅkubumi.</p>
1575<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.30">If we seek to know about all sorts of anchorages, especially sandbanks (<foreign>gosoṅ</foreign>), channels (<foreign>goroṅ</foreign>)<foreign>,</foreign><note>I assume ‘channel’ as the meaning of <foreign>goroṅ</foreign> based on the meaning of <foreign>gorongan</foreign> or <foreign>gurungan</foreign> in MdJ (Robson 2002, s.vv.); not in MdS.</note><foreign> kabua </foreign>(?),<note>The meaning of <foreign>kabua</foreign> is obscure. The meaning of MdJ <foreign>kabwa</foreign> ‘all’ is unlikely. It is noteworthy that <foreign>karang kabua </foreign>is recorded as the name of a small island in Banten. Can we speculate that <foreign>kabua </foreign>is a kind of reef? The B has <foreign>kabuAn· riAk·.</foreign></note>, ripples, i.e., ripples from all directions (<foreign>ryak mokprok</foreign>), deceitful ripples (<foreign>ryak maliṅ</foreign>), big waves (<foreign>alun aguṅ</foreign>), headlands (<foreign>tañjuṅ</foreign>), promontories (<foreign>hujuṅ</foreign>), islands (<foreign>nusa</foreign>), islets (<foreign>pulo</foreign>),<note>My choice to distinguish between <foreign>nusa</foreign> and <foreign>pulo</foreign> (rather than to assume they are synonyms juxtaposed as a ‘twin form’) is based on occurrences of these words in BM, where <foreign>pulo</foreign> seems to refer only to small islands, while <foreign>nusa</foreign> refers to a bigger island or territory. Cf. BM 1248–1253 on the description of the islets in Sunda strait: <foreign>itu ta pulo saṅ hiaṅ, hələt-hələt nusa lampuṅ, ti timur pulo tampuruṅ, ti barat pulo rakata, gunuṅ di təṅah sagara </foreign>“That one there was the islet Sang Hiang, halfway the realm of Lampung, to the east the islet Tampurung, to the west the islet Rakata, a mountain in the middle of the sea”. See Chapter 3, §Morphology.</note> barrier reefs (<foreign>karaṅ nuṅgul</foreign>),<note>The word <foreign>nuṅgul</foreign> is from <foreign>tuṅgul</foreign> ‘(tree)stump, trunk stripped of its branches’, cf. Mal. <foreign>tunggul</foreign>, which according to KBBI means ‘tonggak (untuk menambatkan perahu dan sebagainya)’. I interpret karaṅ nuṅgul as ‘barrier reef’.</note> south-easterly [winds] (<foreign>tuṅgara</foreign>), south-westerly [winds] (<foreign>barat daya</foreign>), all kinds of sea travel [and] sailing, [we should] ask the sea captain (<foreign>puhavaṅ</foreign>).</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.31">If we seek to know about all kinds of prices: three million, three hundred thousand, thirty thousand, three thousand, six hundred, three hundred, thirty all the more so a half (<foreign>karo bəlah</foreign>), a third (<foreign>katəlu bəlah</foreign>), a quarter (<foreign>kapat bəlah</foreign>), a fifth (<foreign>kalima bəlah</foreign>), a sixth (<foreign>kanəm bəlah</foreign>), a seventh (<foreign>kapitu bəlah</foreign>), an eighth (<foreign>kavolu bəlah</foreign>), a ninth (<foreign>kasaṅa bəlah</foreign>) — every kind of price, [we should] ask the <foreign>citrik byapari</foreign>.<note>The word <foreign>citrik</foreign> is a hapax, while <foreign>byapari</foreign> is ultimately related to Skt. <foreign>vyāpāra </foreign>‘occupation, employment, business, profession; doing, performance, action’. We expect the meaning ‘trader’ in this context. However, in MdS, as in MdJ, <foreign>catrik</foreign> means ‘disciple of a hermit (teacher in mythical wisdom, etc.); <foreign>nyatrik</foreign> be a disciple (with a hermit etc.). So the sense is possibly ‘a trader’s apprentice’.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.32">If we seek to know about the esoteric sciences (<foreign>sandhi</foreign>), asceticism, posture, direct perception, detachment, epitome, liberation,<note>Instead of <foreign>kaləpasan</foreign>, the authors of OS texts seem to be consistent in spelling <foreign>kaləpasən</foreign>, especially in the discussion of the <foreign>vuku lima</foreign>. On the use of the suffix -<foreign>ən</foreign> without irrealis meaning, see Chapter 3, §Morphology.</note> ancestor metaphysics, deity metaphysics, elemental accounts, practice accounts — every kind of deity metaphysics,<note>See the analysis of these terms in Chapter 10.</note> [we should] ask the hermits of the people (<foreign>viku para loka</foreign>).<note>I render <foreign>viku para loka</foreign> as a synonymous expression to <foreign>viku sabhuvana</foreign> in SHH. MsB has <foreign>para loka kabeh</foreign>, indicating that <foreign>loka </foreign>is more likely to be interpreted as ‘human, people’, not ‘world’. In this case, the interpretation of <foreign>viku para loka </foreign>as ‘otherworldly hermit’ given in Aditia Gunawan &amp; Griffiths 2021: 175 should be revised.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_11.33">If we want to act, we should not ask the wrong person. If we seek to know about the languages of various countries<note>On the analysis of the topographical names in this list, see Noorduyn &amp; Teeuw (2006: 156), West (2021: 188–194).</note> — the languages of China (<foreign>cina</foreign>), South India (<foreign>kəliṅ</foreign>), Persia (<foreign>parasi</foreign>), Egypt (<foreign>məsir</foreign>), Samudra,<note>The toponym Samudra is also recorded in DV ​13.2 i lvas lāvan samudra mvaṅ i lamuri batan lāmpuṅ mvaṅ i barus, yekādinyaṅ vatək bhūmi malayu satanah kapvāmatəh anūt “Lvas and Samudra, as well as Lamuri, Batan, Lampung and Barus. Those are the main ones among the Malay lands; all these countries are subject and obedient”. Samudra is the name for the whole island of Sumatra, given by the foreigners of the 14th century (e.g. Nicolo de Conti, Ludovico de Varthema). Samudra (or Pasai), located near present-day Lhokseumawe, was at that time the rising power in the island. Krom (1941: 22–5) argues that the success of Samudra/Sumatra as the name for the whole island also owed something to the older Sanskrit term Suvarṇabhūmi (‘Gold-land’) occasionally applied to Sumatra, notably by a Singasari inscription of 1286. Cf. also Reid 1987: 27–28.</note> Bengal (<foreign>baṅgala</foreign>), Makassar, Pahang, Palembang, Siam, Kelantan (<foreign>kalantən</foreign>), Bangka, Buwun, Béten,<note>Béten is perhaps equivalent to <foreign>batan</foreign> mentioned in DV 13.2 (see fn. 302).</note> Tulang Bawang, Sela, Pasai (<foreign>pasay</foreign>), Pariaman (<foreign>parayaman</foreign>), <foreign>ṅara</foreign> Rokan (? <foreign>ṅara dəkan</foreign>),<note>Previous scholars (e.g., Griffiths 2019: 216), interpreted this toponym as referring to the Indian region called Deccan, but this was based on the ASD reading nagara dəkan. Jarrah Sastrawan (p.c., January 2023) proposes that <foreign>dəkan</foreign> may refer to <foreign>rəkan</foreign> (= present-day Rokan), based on DV 13.1: lvirniṅ nūṣa pranūṣa pramukha sakahavat kṣoṇī ri malayu, naṅ jāmbi mvaṅ palembaṅ karitaṅ i təba len dharmāśraya tumūt, kaṇḍis kahvas manaṅkabva ri siyak i rəkān kāmpar mvaṅ i pane, kāmpe harv āthave maṇḍahiliṅ i tumihaṅ parlāk mvaṅ i barat “The islands and lesser islands, in the first place coming under the territory of the Malay lands. Are Jambi and Palembang, Karitang, Teba and Dhanasraya following them, Kandis, Kahwas, Manangkabwa, Siyak, Rəkan, Kampar and Pane, Kampe, Haru and Mandahiling, Tumihang, Parlak and Barat”<foreign>. </foreign>This interpretation seems likely not only because interlinguistic fluctuation between the sounds /r/ and /d/ is imaginable (OJ rəṅə̄, OS deṅe, MdS dangu/déng<foreign>é</foreign>), but also the previous typonyms are situated in Sumatra. For the word <foreign>ṅara</foreign>, we can only rely on ms. A. This word is unattested elsewhere, and should perhaps be emended to <foreign>ṅare</foreign>. Cf. OJ <foreign>ṅare</foreign> ‘a plain (at the foot of the mountain)?’, OS <foreign>uraṅ are</foreign> ‘people from the valley’, MdJ <foreign>are</foreign> or <foreign>ṅare</foreign>, ‘low, level and open, of land in contrast to mountain and wood’, Mal. <foreign>ngarai</foreign> ‘canyon, ravine’. Another option is to consider <foreign>ṅaradigan</foreign>/<foreign>ṅaradəkan</foreign> as corrupt for <foreign>arakan</foreign>, i.e. what is nowadays known as Rakhine State in Myanmar.</note> Dinah (?),<note>Previous scholars such as Atja &amp; Saleh Danasasmita (1981) and Noorduyn &amp; Teeuw (2006) have interpreted Dinah as Madinah, i.e. Medina. I must agree and add that Madinah is attested in another OS text, viz. CRP 359–361 <foreign>haris bañcana, ahis patih gajah biṅbaṅ, putri ti nusa madinah</foreign> “Haris Bancana, the younger sister of vizir Gajah Bingbang, the princess from the country of Madinah”.</note> Andalas (<foreign>andələs</foreign>), Tego, Moluccas (<foreign>moloko</foreign>), Bandan (<foreign>badan</foreign>), Bago (<foreign>pego</foreign>), Minangkabau (<foreign>malaṅkabo</foreign>), Mecca, Buretet, Lawai (<foreign>lave</foreign>), Sasak (<foreign>saksak</foreign>), Sumbawa (<foreign>səmbava</foreign>), Bali, Jenggi,<note>According to Jákl (2017: 3), the term <foreign>jəṅgi</foreign> may refer to the wider area of the east African coast, extending from the river Juba in southern Ethiopia down to Cape Delgado, a coastal promontory on the border of Tanzania and Mozambique. Jákl, who consistently translated ‘Black Africans’, does not allow the possibility that this term could refer to any Southeast Asian indigenous populations. However, our context places Jenggi after Sumbawa and Bali, so probably it refers to the eastern region of Indonesia.</note> Nusa Bini (<foreign>sabini</foreign>),<note>My interpretation of Sabini as a short form of Nusa Bini is based on its occurrences in BM 1267 <foreign>nusa dilih nusa bini </foreign>“Dilih and Nusa Bini” and KaKat 17 <foreign>parasi dəṅ nusa bini </foreign>“Persia and Nusa Bini”. However, the location of this toponym is uncertain. On Nusa Bini in BM, West (2021: 189) furnishes interesting information: “Nusa Bini presents some difficulties (cf. SSKK’s ⟨sabini⟩). No place with this name can be identified, although Coolsma (1913: 82) says it refers to a mythical ‘Island of the Amazons’ (cf. OJv, Malay <foreign>bini</foreign> ‘wife’). This is not an uncommon motif in medieval texts; Polo describes an <foreign>ysle de femes</foreign> ‘Island of Women’ (f.90v) in the Indian Ocean, and on the Catalan Atlas it is said that Java (ILLA IANA) is itself home to a ‘kingdom of women’ (<foreign>recn͠o femarum</foreign>). Jordanus says there are women’s and men’s islands in the Indian Ocean, and that men cannot live on the women’s island and vice versa (1839[~1330]:57). Zhào Rŭkuò (c.1225) also mentions a ‘land of women’ (女人國) with the same characteristics, and Pires says that local folklore told of an island near Nias (Maruz Minhac) where only women lived (Cortesão 1944:162). BM’s <foreign>Bini</foreign> is not exceptional in this context”.</note> Ogan (<foreign>ṅogan</foreign>), Kanangen, Komering (<foreign>kuməriṅ</foreign>), Sampang Tiga,<note>The reading is based on ms. A. While ms. A reflects the correct reading of toponyms with the cluster <foreign>mp </foreign>such as <foreign>sampaṅ</foreign>, <foreign>lampuṅ</foreign>, and <foreign>cəmpa</foreign>, ms. B systematically has <foreign>mara</foreign>, so the latter has <foreign>samaraṅ</foreign>,<foreign> lamaruṅ</foreign> and<foreign> cəmara</foreign>. This is due to the scribal misinterpretation of the ligature <foreign>mp</foreign> as consisting in the <foreign>aksara</foreign>s <foreign>ma</foreign> and <foreign>ra</foreign>. The toponym <foreign>sampaṅ tiga</foreign> seems to be synonymous with <foreign>simpaṅ tiga</foreign>, since the OS word <foreign>sampaṅ</foreign> means ‘road crossing’. Several instances of the toponym Simpang Tiga exist in Sumatra Selatan and Sumatra Utara.</note> Gumantung, Manubi, Bubu, Nyiri, Sapari, Patukangan, Surabaya, Lampung, India (<foreign>jambudipa</foreign>), Seram (?, <foreign>seran</foreign>), Kedah (<foreign>gədah</foreign>), Salaut (?, <foreign>solot</foreign>), Solodong, Indragiri, Tanjungpura,<note>The <foreign>Deśavarṇana</foreign> (13.2) mentions Tañjuṅnagara, which probably refers to Tañjuṅpura and listed among the Malay territories, was ‘subject and obedient’ to Majapahit. Barbosa places Tourjoãopura in Borneo (2000 [1516]: 407). It is the place where diamonds are produced. Pires calls this place Tamjompura (Cortesão 1944: 223–224).</note> Sakampung, Atas Angin, Campa (<foreign>cəmpa</foreign>), Baluk, Java — all kinds of countries, [we should] ask the interpreter who is a reliable guide to <foreign>dharma</foreign> (<foreign>darma-murcaya</foreign>).<note>The meaning of <foreign>darma-murcaya</foreign> is obscure. It seems that this compound is related to Skt. <foreign>dharmapratyaya</foreign>. Sanskrit <foreign>pratyaya</foreign> has a range of senses, growing out of its etymological meaning ‘going to’ &gt; ‘resorting to’, ‘accepting’, ‘recognizing’, ‘explaining’ &gt; ‘(basis for) trust, belief, confidence, certainty’. In the literary (<foreign>kawi</foreign>) form of MdJ, we find an expression <foreign>dadya caya-murcaya</foreign> ‘kw. minangka dadi tandhaning panuwun’ (as a token of gratitude). We find one occurrence of caya murcaya in the Kuṭarāgama: <foreign>caya murcaya, cayane kaṅ ṅala lan kaṅ bəcik </foreign>“<foreign>Caya murcaya</foreign>: the <foreign>caya </foreign>in the bad and the good”, but the sense remains obscure. Since a connection between <foreign>darma-murcaya</foreign> and <foreign>dharma-pratyaya</foreign> seems plausible in itself, but the other evidence about <foreign>murcaya</foreign> in Javanese is not obviously compatible with a derivation from <foreign>pratyaya</foreign>, we have to admit that the interpretation of <foreign>darma-murcaya</foreign> remains uncertain in the present state of our knowledge. My translation of <foreign>juru basa darma-murcaya</foreign> as ‘the interpreter who is a reliable guide to <foreign>dharma</foreign>’ is therefore tentative. I thank Tim Lubin for the information on <foreign>dharmapratyaya</foreign> in Sanskrit corpus.</note></p></div>
.<div corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_12">
1580<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_12.01">That is what should be known, as to their reliability and appropriateness. If there is one who says that he does not know, he is one who is not faithful to his own function, is very ignorant<note>My emendation of <foreign>mo təiṅ</foreign> to<foreign> moha təiṅ</foreign> is based on the occurrence of <foreign>moha təiṅ</foreign> in BM 967 <foreign>moha təiṅ nu ti həla</foreign> “the confusion was more than before”. Here I take <foreign>moha təiṅ</foreign> as an adjective ‘very ignorant’ referring to the implicit subject <foreign>nu. </foreign>Cf. AG 3v <foreign>mulah koyo moha di carekna kolot pun </foreign>“Don’t be difficult, ignorant to the words of elders”; KaPani 848–849 <foreign>hamo ñaho di pamali, moha di sabda halimpu </foreign>“Doesn’t know about the forbidden act, ignorant to the suitable speech”.</note> as to the words of our Gods, does not fear misfortune (<foreign>upadrava</foreign>), the cycle of worlds (<foreign>jagat-ganti</foreign>)<note>On the extra nasal in <foreign>ganti </foreign>&lt; <foreign>gati</foreign>, see Chapter 3, §Phonology.</note> [and] the four powers (<foreign>cadu-sakti</foreign>) of the scholar. [He] is certainly<note>On <foreign>tan avuruṅ</foreign>, cf. OJ <foreign>tan vuruṅ</foreign> ‘without fail, certainly, unremittingly’, and also MdS <foreign>mo burung</foreign> ‘id’.</note> awaited by the cauldron.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_12.02">Regarding the works, they should not be performed; regarding the actions, they should not be carried out — except (<foreign>sahiṅaniṅ</foreign>) virtuous works, for that is the thread of the ancestors [and] the thread of the gods, the memorial of the Lord of the world, when He made the unmanifest world prosperous.<note>The expression <foreign>ṅrətakən bumi</foreign> is also found in the Huludayeuh inscription (Aditia Gunawan &amp; Griffiths 2021: 176–179). Cf. SKK 16.2: <foreign>taṅkalniṅ bumi krəta</foreign>.</note> When Brahma, Wisnu, Isora, Mahadéwa, Siwa are devoted to the Lord; when Indra, Yama, Baruna, Kowéra, Bésawarna<note>Besavarna corresponds to Skt. Vaiśravaṇa.
