In Inscriptions from Bali, this deity is called Bāsava (van Stein Callenfels 1926: 5). </note> are devoted to the Lord; when Kusika, Garga, Méstri, Purusa, Patanjala are devoted to the Lord — [when] all of the gods together are devoted to Lord Séda Niskala, [then] all of them find the one who is true with direct perception.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_12.03">This is what must be found in the manifest world, the thread of the Lord for the world, so that [we are] firm in becoming ‘jewels in one cage’ (? <foreign>manik sakuruṅan</foreign>);<note>The meaning of <foreign>manik sakuruṅan</foreign> is obscure. It is attested in CP 39a: <foreign>saṅ vrəti kandayun adəg di galuh, ti iña lumaku ṅarajarəsi, ṅaṅaranan maneh rahyaṅta ti mənir, basana aṅkat sabumi jadi manik sakuruṅan, iña nu ñiyən na purbatisti </foreign>“Wreti Kandayun reigned in Galuh, from where he performed the <foreign>rajarəsi</foreign>, calling himself Rahyangta of Menir. When he departed from the whole world to become ‘a jewel in one cage’, he was the one who made the sacred rules”<foreign>.</foreign> It should be noted that in OS texts, <foreign>kuruṅan</foreign> also means ‘body’, as separate from the soul (<foreign>atma</foreign>). I suppose that the metaphoric expression <foreign>manik sakuruṅan</foreign>, which can be translated in this context as ‘a jewel in one body’, expresses that the ascetic has reached the highest state. ASD, however, translate it as ‘<foreign>berumah tangga</foreign>’ (to be married).</note> so that we are shining [in] the whole world: the servant is devoted to his master, the wife is devoted to her husband, the child is devoted to his father, the pupil is devoted to his teacher, the <foreign>mantri</foreign> is devoted to the <foreign>maṅkubumi</foreign>, <foreign>maṅkubumi</foreign> is devoted to the king, the king is devoted to the Gods. They are ordered to stabilize their bodies, directing the breath, the speech [and] the mind. </p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_12.04">If those [actions] are not performed and [not] carried out by the humans, of low, middle, and high class, each of them is thrown into the cauldron called ‘Bull Headed Copper [Cauldron]’.<note>On the visualization of <foreign>tambragomuka</foreign> (OJ <foreign>tamragohmukha</foreign>), see Teeuw <foreign>et al.</foreign> 1981: 204–216 who analyze the relief based on the <foreign>Kuñjarakarṇa</foreign> in Candi Jago.</note> Because the human is overpowered by the Gods. <foreign>Pun</foreign>.<note>Cf. <foreign>pun </foreign>in 23.2 and my comment on this word. Actually we do not expect <foreign>pun </foreign>at the end of this paragraph. </note></p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_12.05">Darma Pitutur spoke, reporting the words of the precursors: There is another comparison, like [when] we went to Java, [we] are unable to follow its language and its manners, we felt confused. After [we] returned home to Sunda, we were unable to speak Javanese. It felt as if we had not come [back] from a journey, “what we bought as a result of visiting was worthless”,<note><foreign>poos tukuna bənaṅ tandaṅ </foreign>‘what we bought as a result of visiting was worthless’ seems to be an idiomatic expression. It seems to be more or less similar with MdS expression <foreign>luput teu beubeunangan </foreign>‘gone wrong, not gained anything’<foreign>. </foreign></note> because of inability to follow its language. </p>
1585<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_12.06">That is how we are, as humans, continually<note>I interpret <foreign>haṅər </foreign>as an equivalent to <foreign>haṅgər </foreign>(= MdS <foreign>angger</foreign>). We find several words which show similar cases in MdS: <foreign>panger</foreign> is equivalent to <foreign>pangger</foreign>, <foreign>tetengger </foreign>is to <foreign>tetenger</foreign>.</note> descending from the unmanifest, [but] not finding the manners of the Gods, rushing to be incarnated as humans, because their appearance is silly, their behavior is ignorant, [and they are] incapable of following the acts of the ones who know. There are acts committed that are unfaithful, that are improper. [They] start to do evil, to trespass, to have affairs in secret (<foreign>bubunyan</foreign>) with younger and older relatives. That is why a woman enjoying a man who is not her husband is considered improper; a man enjoying a woman who is not his wife (? <foreign>əsi imahna</foreign>)<note>The expression <foreign>əsi imah</foreign> literally seems to mean ‘household’, but here we expect it to refer to the ‘wife’. Or does it rather indicate any woman present in the household, including personnel, concubines, etc.?</note> is [likewise] considered improper. [They] are liable to be thrown into the cauldron called ‘The Victorious Deer’ (Si Mrəga Vijaya),<note>The association of hell with deer is rather unusual. However, it should be noted that there is a relief at Candi Sukuh, called the Kala-mr̥ga by Hariani Santiko (2011), which depicts an arch with a Kala figure at the top center and two deer facing the outside at the bottom (see Aditia Gunawan 2019: 47, fig. 2.1, for the image). This arch encircles the main focus of the relief, namely the conversation between Lord Guru and Bhīma in the story of <foreign>Bhīma Svarga</foreign>, which takes place in hell. The arch in this relief may thus represent the gates of hell.</note> because humans prefer what is wrong. </p></div>
.<div corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_13">
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_13.01">These are the symbolic terms (<foreign>siloka</foreign>)<note>The word <foreign>siloka</foreign> is an OS term derived from Skt. <foreign>śloka</foreign> ‘stanza’, but in this context it seems to mean ‘symbolic term, symbolic expression’, as in MdS.</note> for the behavior of wrong people: lawless (<foreign>buraṅkak</foreign>),<note>The word <foreign>buraṅkak</foreign> is not recorded in MdS dictionaries, but it is attested in OJ ‘daring, lawless’, taken from its occurrence in Kuñj 62.17 (or line 1175–118 in van der Molen edition), as one of the behavior of the sinful Purṇavijāya: <foreign>saṅ pūrṇavijaya ṅaranya, sakiṅ kendran saṅkane, agəṅ dvaṣanya, atyanta həṅkaranya, vgig, buraṅkak, aṅalāpi stri laraṅan </foreign>‘Who is called Purṇavijāya from the heaven of Indra, his sins are enormous, his selfish is perpetual, naughty, lawless, tooking the forbidden womens’.</note> anxious (? <foreign>marende</foreign>),<note>The word <foreign>marende</foreign> in MdS is an active form of <foreign>paréndé</foreign> ‘to put a child to sleep by laying down for a moment’. Probably there is an allusion to the child’s condition when they are anxious before sleeping? The explanation of this term in 13.4 seems to fit this interpretation.</note> sulky (<foreign>mariris</foreign>),<note>The word <foreign>mariris</foreign> ‘sulky’ is equivalent to OJ <foreign>ariris</foreign> ‘id’. Not in MdS.</note> shameful (<foreign>viraṅ</foreign>). They are called the four demons. The meaning is: <foreign>buraṅkak</foreign> means shuddering. What is horrifying,<note>I render <foreign>gila</foreign> as in MdS ‘shudder at st., abhor st., be horrified at st’. On the prefix <foreign>maha- </foreign>(<foreign>paha</foreign>-) resulting in causative meaning, see Chapter 3, §Morphology.</note> as it were, is the behavior of the person who is envious, surly, staring, coarse (?, <foreign>gasoṅ</foreign>),<note>Unrecorded in Sundanese dictionaries, <foreign>gasoṅ</foreign> may be related to Mal. <foreign>gasang </foreign>‘lecherous person; incontinent lustful, passionate’.</note> rude in speech, ugly in behavior, hot of heart. [Such behavior] is considered improper. That is what the behavior of such men is like, horrifying as it were. He becomes a demon, Durga, Durgi, the demon Kala. His place is in the dirt of the earth.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_13.02">The dirty soils are: hollows, clusters (? <foreign>saroṅge</foreign>),<note>The word <foreign>saroṅge</foreign> is not found in any dictionary, but it is known as a toponym. In MdJ we find <foreign>rongge</foreign> ‘<foreign>wuli</foreign>. <foreign>ronggean pari: wulèn pari</foreign>. <foreign>nanging ing Kêndhal sarongge </foreign>= <foreign>saombyok</foreign>’ (‘a stalk. <foreign>ronggean pari </foreign>‘a stalk of paddy’, but in Kendal <foreign>sarongge</foreign> = a bunch’; only recorded in De Nooy &amp; Padmasoesastra 1893: 24). B has <foreign>soṅgeṅ</foreign>, which seems to be an equivalent of MdJ <foreign>suṅgiṅ</foreign> ‘to paint’, but this does not fit our context. Cf. also the similar meaning expressed by <foreign>ṅararaṅgeyan</foreign> in SKK 4.1 which corresponds to MdS <foreign>ranggeuy</foreign> ‘bunch, cluster’.</note> lime-stone cliffs (<foreign>cadas gantuṅ</foreign>), scattered stones,<note>I consider <foreign>pateṅgaṅ</foreign> to be an equivalent of <foreign>patenggang</foreign> ‘stand/lie far apart (from each other), lie scattered (of houses etc.)’. Cf. one of the meanings of <foreign>tenggang</foreign> ‘equally divided’ in Malay (Wilkinson, s.v.). See Chapter 3, §Phonology</note> gorges, swamps,<note>On the word <foreign>rañcak</foreign>, see Chapter 3, §Phonology.</note> rhinoceros ponds, tree trunks upside down<note>I interpret <foreign>nuṅgaṅ</foreign> (from <foreign>tuṅgaṅ</foreign>) as ‘upside down’ on the basis of one of its meaning in Mal. ‘upside-down, Inversion’, besides ‘to ride’. Only the latter meaning is found in MdS. Cf. OJ <foreign>tuṅgaṅ </foreign>which has the same meaning as MdS ‘to mount, ride on, sit on’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>tuṅgaṅ</foreign>).</note> and aslant (<foreign>cataṅ nuṅgaṅ cataṅ noṅgeṅ</foreign>), mine tunnels (<foreign>garuṅguṅan gareṅgeṅan</foreign>),<note>The words <foreign>garuṅguṅan</foreign> and <foreign>gareṅgeṅan</foreign> are not found in any dictionary, but are probably related with MdS <foreign>garung</foreign> ‘left unused, uncultivated’ or with <foreign>gurung</foreign> ‘culvert’. Cf. also MdS <foreign>garungsang</foreign> and <foreign>gurangséng</foreign> ‘very steep’ (the wall of a ravine, rock-face, etc.). I presume that <foreign>garuṅguṅan gareṅgeṅan</foreign> is equivalent to <foreign>garungsang-gurangséng</foreign>. Cf. Mal. <foreign>geronggang</foreign> ‘cavity; hollow’.</note> dangerous lands (<foreign>saṅhar</foreign>),<note>Cf. MdS. <foreign>sangar</foreign>. On the unexpected <foreign>h</foreign> at the start of the second syllable, see Chapter 3, §Phonology.</note> burning grounds,<note>The interpretation of <foreign>daṅdaṅ</foreign> as ‘burning ground’ is based on the meaning of <foreign>dangdangan</foreign> in MdS ‘​​cleaned up strip of ground around an area to be burnt (to prevent the flames from jumping over); ring around fire lane’. However, MdJ has <foreign>dangdang</foreign> ‘crow’ which may suggest a plausible alternative interpretation of <foreign>daṅdaṅ</foreign> because it is juxtaposed with <foreign>varian</foreign>, which seems to be related to OJ <foreign>varya-varya</foreign> ‘crawling animal’ (see fn. 331). If the later interpretation is correct, then we need to interpret <foreign>daṅdaṅ varian</foreign> as ‘[lands] of crows and crawling animals’</note> [lands of] crawling animals (<foreign>varian</foreign>),<note>Many interpretations can be imagined for the word <foreign>varian</foreign>. In MdS we find <foreign>kawarian</foreign> ‘<foreign>kalakuan nu teu umum cara nu kurang saeundan</foreign>’ (abnormal behavior like that of a crazy man)’ and <foreign>wawarian</foreign> ‘<foreign>kadaharan sésa di nu tas hajat</foreign>’ (leftover food during a celebration). In Skt., <foreign>vāri</foreign> means ‘water’, so <foreign>varian</foreign> could mean ‘watery land’. Skt. also has <foreign>varīyas</foreign> (nom. sg. <foreign>varīyān</foreign>) ‘wider, broader (`than abl.); freer, easier’ and ‘wider space, free space, freedom, comfort, ease’. In OJ, a similar word that fits our context is <foreign>varya-varya</foreign> ‘a kind of crawling animal’, which occurs in a list of despicable animals: <foreign>hiri-hiris poh, caciṅ, varya-varya</foreign>. So <foreign>[ləmah] varian</foreign> could mean ‘[lands of] crawling animals’. With reference to this OJ word, I choose to interpret <foreign>varian</foreign> as ‘crawling animals’.</note> hillocks, male soils (<foreign>ləmah laki</foreign>),<note>The compound <foreign>ləmah laki</foreign> is a hapax. There seems to be some kind of analogy with <foreign>nusa bini</foreign> which literally means ‘female Island’. In MdS, <foreign>laki</foreign> also means ‘pounder’, but it seems to be a secondary semantic development from ‘male’. For the time being, I keep the literal translation of <foreign>ləmah laki</foreign> as ‘male soils’.</note> pigsties, gutters (<foreign>kalomberan</foreign>),<note>Cf. MdS <foreign>kolombéran</foreign>, MdJ <foreign>klombèran</foreign>, Mal. <foreign>comberan</foreign>.</note> rubbish dumps, cremation grounds (<foreign>səma</foreign>)<note>See OJED, s.v. <foreign>səma </foreign>‘cemetery, graveyard’, not in MdS.</note> — every kind of soil avoided.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_13.03">What those who are obstinate in their ugly behaviors become is like that, because the behavior of men is what gives horror.<note>I presume that <foreign>mere gila</foreign> is equivalent to <foreign>makagila</foreign> and <foreign>mahagila</foreign>. See Chapter 3, §Morphology.</note> They become every sort of horrifying thing, because they do not follow the holy instruction of the accomplished one,<note>See my comment on <foreign>krəta</foreign> in 11.2.</note> because they transgress the Hermits’ Holy Precepts for Society. That is why they become horrifying. That is the meaning of <foreign>buraṅkak</foreign>.</p>
1590<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_13.04"><foreign>Marende</foreign> means: being cooled down<note>My emendation <foreign>dibeka</foreign> into <foreign>dibere</foreign> is based on the resemblance of the <foreign>aksara</foreign>s <foreign>re</foreign> (<foreign>ra</foreign> + <foreign>panéléng</foreign>) and <foreign>ka</foreign>, whether in <foreign>gebang</foreign> manuscripts or in <foreign>lontar</foreign>s.</note> and yet feeling hot; being given pity,<note>The passive word <foreign>dikahemankən</foreign> seems to be formed by the circumfix <foreign>di- -kən</foreign> with the secondary base <foreign>kaheman</foreign> (noun derived from verb <foreign>heman</foreign> ‘pity’). It seems that the literal meaning would be ‘being the object of pity’, so <foreign>dikahemankən</foreign> means ‘being given pity’. Cf. MdS <foreign>mangnyaahkeun</foreign> (from <foreign>nyaah</foreign>) ‘to take pity on so. else, feel pity for so’.</note> being given sympathy, being taken care of, being coddled, being given pleasures [and] enjoyments,<note>Cf. <foreign>ku suka ku boga</foreign> in SKK 9.1.</note> servants [and] slaves, and yet mistrusting [them]. It is clear that he is affected by the misery of which the field [called] Patana is full.<note>For other descriptions of hell, cf. Kuñj 13–14 and 26, KuñjDhK (especially stanzas 7 and 8), and the OS CaPur 75–245, discussed at length by Teeuw <foreign>et al</foreign>. 1981: 32–33. The expression <foreign>təgal si patana</foreign> refers to a place in hell mentioned in the OJ <foreign>Kuñjarakarṇa</foreign> as <foreign>bhūmipatana</foreign>. It seems that <foreign>patana</foreign> itself is a local development from Skt. <foreign>pātāla</foreign>. The development of /l/ to /n/ is quite common in the languages of Indonesia: Skt. and OJ <foreign>janma</foreign> = MdS <foreign>jalma</foreign>, Skt. <foreign>vanāntara</foreign> &gt; Mal. <foreign>belantara</foreign>, Skt. <foreign>janatā</foreign> = Mal. <foreign>jelata</foreign>. Cf. CaPur 79 which uses the term <foreign>bumipatala</foreign>.</note> Its length is one <foreign>yojana</foreign>.<note>The word <foreign>yojana</foreign>, from Skt (=OJ) ‘a measure of distance (= 4 krośas or about 9 miles?)’. Not in MdS.</note> In the east is the Sword Tree.<note>The compound <foreign>kalapa kandaga</foreign> ‘sword-tree’ is an equivalent of OJ <foreign>kalpa kaṇḍaga </foreign>which has simmilar meaning (OJED, s.v.). Cf. Kuñj 26 which gives a hint that this word refers to only one tree located in the middle of hell: <foreign>ikaṅ havan katvan tejānya sake ṅke, ya tika riṅ ayah bhūmipatāna ṅaranya, kunaṅ ikaṅ katvan āṅuṅgul riṅ tṅah ya tika kalpa kaṇḍaga ika, kunaṅ ikāṅ atpi kidul aṅadəg ahirəṅ agəṅ katvan, yeka parvvasaṅgata ṅaranya, gunuṅ vsi matakəp lavan rvavaṅnya.</foreign> In MdS, <foreign>kandaga</foreign> means a small box for valuables, a jewelry box; (C.) a kind of basket of woven leaves (with a lid). ASD translate <foreign>kalapa kandaga</foreign> as ‘<foreign>bersenjatakan pedang</foreign>’ (has a sword as weapon). Cf. the term <foreign>kayu curiga</foreign> ‘knife-tree’ in ms. K of Kuñj (l. 2624, ed. van der Molen 1983). See Bernet Kempers (1981: 203; fig. 5 and 6) on the depiction of hell in the reliefs of Candi Jago.</note> One hundred thousand men are struck [by its swords] there. In the south is the Stone Mountain. One hundred thousand evil men are suffering there together. In the west are the Fire-Headed ghosts.<note>Cf. Kuñj 14 hana ta yakṣāgnimukha, apiy ataṅān asuku. ya tika maṅusī ikaṅ pāpa “There are Five-Headed ghosts, (i.e.), fire with hands and feet. They attack the sinners”.</note> Humans cannot fathom how much suffering is there. In the north, there are one hundred people suffering together there, like grass-hoppers on a skewer. In the middle is the crow of the Patana,<note>SC 801–805 contains descriptions of hell-dwelling animals, such as the crow and the dog. In SC we encounter the <foreign>santana</foreign> crow, described as having blade wings (<foreign>maṅhəlar curiga</foreign>): <foreign>əntasniya sakeṅ kavah, diparabkən ka asu di pañcasora, asu maṅtəndas iyaksa, gagak maṅhəlar curiga, təhərna mava ruji bəsi, dəṅ na gagak santana</foreign> “After being lifted up from the cauldron, he is given as food to the Five-Sounded dogs, dogs with <foreign>yakṣa</foreign>s as their head, the crow with blade wings, then they take the iron fencing, together with the crow [called] Santana”. The word <foreign>santana</foreign> is probably none other than <foreign>patana </foreign>(see fn. 339). This passage runs parallel with Kuñj 13: <foreign>hana ta pākṣi yakṣa si ṣantana ṅaranya, gagak </foreign>(all mss. AHK; <foreign>gālak </foreign>Kern) <foreign>mahəlar curigā, kaṇḍaga pinakākukunya, kukunya bajra </foreign>(H and K;<foreign> kuku mānval bajra </foreign>A and Kern)<foreign> mahəlar kaṇḍaga, mavulu </foreign>(H;<foreign> mamava hru </foreign>K; <foreign>mavaruṅ </foreign>A and Kern) <foreign>tajī</foreign> “There are the ghost-birds called Santana, the crows with blade wings, having swords as their nails, their nails are made of iron, having blades as wings, having spikes as feathers”. In <foreign>Uttarakāṇḍa</foreign> 32, the crow is Yama’s incarnation when he faces Rāvaṇa. The crow mentioned together with the dog, both representing sinners, is also found in SHH 5.12: <foreign>hilaṅa ikaṅ bāyu śabda hədap sakeṅ śārīranya məne, ndatan mulya pih asiṅ vvaṅ magaməl, tinimpalakən raśmi, pinarəbutakən deniṅ gagak mvaṅ asu iku </foreign>“When the breath, the speech, and the mind are now gone from their body, whatever people do is worthless. The beauty (of the body) is turned off, as the crow and the dog fight over it”.</note> with the Dog ghosts. Thousands of evil people are suffering there. That is the misery of those called <foreign>marende</foreign>.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_13.05"><foreign>Mariris</foreign> means defiled, disgusting like excrement, defiled like a reeking carcass. Such is the conduct of people who are kleptomaniac, who seize indiscriminately, or even take indiscriminately, without asking, stealing, plundering, deceiving, pilfering — all kinds of lying<note>The word <foreign>curavəda</foreign> is clearly derived from Skt. <foreign>curavāda</foreign> (= OJ) ‘speaking untruths’.</note> to good persons. When he dies, his soul<note>I take -<foreign>na</foreign> in <foreign>atmana </foreign>as a possessive suffix, even though the word <foreign>atmana</foreign> as a synonym of <foreign>atma</foreign> is attested. Cf. Kuñj 2306 (van der Molen 1983: 229) <foreign>piraṅ kee hatmana riṅ sarira, limma kvehnya, mapa lvirnya</foreign> “How many numbers are the soul in the body? Its number is five. What is the form”?</note> will suffer, for one thousand [and] one hundred years afflicted by the curse of the gods. That is why<note>The conjunction <foreign>mana </foreign>is suspicious here, and should possibly be emended to <foreign>atmana</foreign>. If this is the correct emendation, then the translation would be ‘his soul is far from rebirth’.</note> birth as a human is not in sight. As for what he becomes: <foreign>koter</foreign>,<note>Unidentified animal. In SC 825–830, we read <foreign>oter</foreign> instead of <foreign>koter</foreign>: <foreign>təmah saṅ hyaṅ atma papa, jadi oter jadi jaṅgel, jambəloṅ limus sakərət, kararamu hapur muṅkal, satva kinaririsan, satva kinavədian</foreign> ‘the consequence of the sinful soul, [is that] it becomes<foreign> oter</foreign> and <foreign>jaṅgel</foreign>, <foreign>jambəloṅ </foreign>and leatherleaf slug, <foreign>kararamu </foreign>and <foreign>hapur muṅkal</foreign>, despised [and] disgusting animals’. Is it equivalent to OJ <foreign>kulir</foreign>? Cf. also MdJ <foreign>bolèr</foreign> ‘small fruit worm’.</note> <foreign>jaṅgel</foreign>,<note>Unidentified animal. In MdS, <foreign>jaṅgel</foreign> means ‘corn cob’, but here probably refers to a kind of worm or leech whose appearance is resembled corn cob?</note> crop-worm,<note>The species <foreign>hiləd tahun</foreign> is likely to refer to a kind of caterpillar. Kompas 30 May 2011 reported a high population of caterpillars in Gunung Kidul, one of the species being called <foreign>ulat tahun</foreign> (see <ref target="https://amp.kompas.com/ekonomi/read/2011/05/30/0533052/policy.html">https://amp.kompas.com/ekonomi/read/2011/05/30/0533052/policy.html</ref>). Cf. OJ <foreign>ulər tahun</foreign>. See SKK 1.2 where <foreign>tahun </foreign>means crop. Is it related to Mal. <foreign>ulat daun</foreign>?</note> horse-fly,<note>The word <foreign>pitək</foreign> ‘horse-fly, gadfly, warble-fly’, as in MdS. Cf. Mal. <foreign>pikat</foreign>, OJ <foreign>caṭak</foreign>.</note> <foreign>titiṅgi</foreign>,<note>In MdS, <foreign>titiṅgi</foreign> refers to a kind of millipede. Cf. Mal. <foreign>kaki seribu.</foreign></note> <foreign>jambəloṅ</foreign>,<note>The word <foreign>jambəloṅ </foreign>is not found in MdS, but is probably equivalent with MdS <foreign>katélong</foreign> (a kind of big centipede). Tien Wartini <foreign>et al</foreign>. 2011 interpret <foreign>jambəloṅ</foreign> as ‘lintah kerbau, lintah besar dan hitam yang tempat hidupnya di tanah lembab’. Cf. MdJ <foreign>təmbalong </foreign>‘a certain large centipede’ (Horne 1974, s.v.)<foreign>. </foreign></note> leatherleaf slug,<note>On <foreign>limus sakərət</foreign>, see my comment on the OJ word <foreign>hiris pvah</foreign> in <ref target="DHARMA_CritEdSiksaGuru.xml#siksaguru_08.04">SiGu 8.4</ref>.</note> <foreign>mear</foreign>,<note><foreign>mear</foreign> is not recorded in MdS, but I googled it and found that in Bogor people still recognize it as a kind of leech. This word is also known as the toponym of <foreign>kampung</foreign> in Jasinga, Bogor.</note> <foreign>pacet </foreign>(blood sucking haemadipsa),<note><foreign>pacet</foreign> = Mal. (also <foreign>pacat</foreign>). Cf. OJ and MdJ <foreign>pacət</foreign> ‘kind of leech’ (<foreign>Haemadipsa teylandica</foreign>).</note> leech, <foreign>ləhəṅ</foreign>, <foreign>gərəṅ</foreign><note>Both <foreign>ləhəṅ</foreign> and <foreign>gərəṅ</foreign> are unidentified animals.</note> — everything that is despised by people in general, that is what is called <foreign>mariris</foreign>.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_13.06">Disgrace (<foreign>viraṅ</foreign>) means unwilling to be sincere, unwilling to truthful, unwilling to be proper, unwilling to be frank, unwilling to be polite. If his anxiety (?, <foreign>harən</foreign>),<note>The word <foreign>harən</foreign> is not found in dictionaries, and my translation ‘anxiety’ is based on the tentative assumption of a connection with MdS <foreign>hara-haraeun</foreign> ‘present difficulties, raise objections, unfavorable (of a place or time where all kinds of things are lacking, a place difficult to pass, a bad and dangerous road, etc.)’. Hardjadibrata relates <foreign>hara-haraeun</foreign> to MdS <foreign>ara</foreign>, <foreign>aru-ara</foreign> and <foreign>uru-ara</foreign> ‘commotion, stir, disquiet, unrest, uproar’. In KS 6.11–26 we read<foreign> sakti atma ləpas, ləñəpniṅ rupa bayu, revaca saṅ harən saṅ harəsa, </foreign>“Strongly, the soul has vanished, the dissolution of the breath’s form, the anxiety and lust are <foreign>revaca </foreign>(?)”.</note> passion, love [or] astonishment is deceitful, [then] when he dies, his soul will meet with suffering, [i.e] a wobbly bridge, a slanting plank bridge, clashing stones. When they are made into being in the world, they become everything that is horrifying: rhinoceros, tiger, crocodile, great snake, everything that is horrifying. That is called disgrace (<foreign>viraṅ</foreign>). So much for the four demons.</p></div>
.<div corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_14">
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_14.01">This is like a man who travels to China, spends a long time in China. [He] knows Chinese customs, Chinese habits, Chinese language, Chinese manners, Chinese etiquette. [He] meets with three [levels] of language, [namely] low, middle, and high. [He] knows all<note>In this sentence, <foreign>pahi </foreign>cannot have a meaning ‘all’ referring to the subject like we have in other contexts, but serving as an adverb. Cf, Mal. <foreign>serba tahu</foreign>. Another adverbial meaning is attested in RR 1480–1481 <foreign>padoyoṅ pahi daékna, silih taña kahayaṅna</foreign> “matching each other with equal strength, asking each other what they wanted”.</note> about the speech of the king, the elder, and the hermit; is able to direct the breath, the speech, and the mind. That is the reason why [he] knows about the consciousness (<foreign>gəiṅ</foreign>), the higher consciousness (<foreign>upagəiṅ</foreign>), the ultimate consciousness (<foreign>parigəiṅ</foreign>). They are called the three forms of consciousness.</p>
1595<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_14.02">Consciousness is [a person endowed with it] being able to taste, to drink, [and] being able to have pleasure; that is called consciousness. What is called higher consciousness is [a person endowed with it] being able to dress, able to wear clothes, able to wear a lower garment, able to wear festive attire; that is called higher consciousness. What is called ultimate consciousness is [a person endowed with it] being able to instruct, able to command, because his speech is sweet [and] fragrant,<note>The author uses the combination <foreign>arum mavaṅi</foreign> instead of <foreign>ruum avaṅi</foreign>, reflecting a Javanese code switching; cf. Kuñj 335–336 (ms H in van der Molen edition): <foreign>śammida dupa</foreign> (em. <foreign>śammi dadupa</foreign> ed.) <foreign>mrabukk arum pavaṅi</foreign>. In Old Sundanese corpus, see KaPañ 719 <foreign>ruum buṅbuṅ gandavaṅi</foreign>, SA 824 <foreign>ruum miṅiṅ ganda vaṅi</foreign>, SC 316 <foreign>ruum səṅit rumavaṅi. </foreign>The word <foreign>rumavaṅi</foreign> in SC 316 seems to be a brief variant of <foreign>ruum avaṅi</foreign>.</note> such that the one who is commanded does not become angry, because he is touched by the impact<note>I choose the reading B <foreign>bənaṅna</foreign> instead of <foreign>bənaṅ</foreign> by comparing this passage with SKK 8.3 <foreign>ku bənaṅna ilik di guna sakalih</foreign>. Cf. <foreign>bənaṅna ñaho</foreign> in SKK 18.4.</note> of applying expressions with a deeper meaning (<foreign>siloka</foreign>).<note>The expression of <foreign>labuh siloka</foreign> is attested in SC 310 <foreign>misi na labuh siloka</foreign> ‘having endowed (<foreign>misi</foreign>) with suitable words’. In MdS, <foreign>labuh</foreign> means ‘fall (because of slipping, bumping against st., etc.); <foreign>ngalabuhkeun</foreign> let so. fall (on his face); balabuh be (lie, ride) at anchor’. Cf. OJ <foreign>alabuh</foreign> ‘to cast os. down (on or into st.) and seek one’s death’. I presume that <foreign>milabuh siloka</foreign> is similar in meaning to the expression <foreign>manibakən sastra</foreign> ‘to execute the writing’, from <foreign>tiba </foreign>‘to fall’.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_14.03">If his words (<foreign>basana</foreign>)<note>The word <foreign>basana</foreign> is at first sight ambiguous. In MdS, <foreign>basa</foreign> can have two meanings: first, it can be a conjunction ‘when, at the time of’; second, it can be a noun, ‘language, word’. In OS, the first meaning is more common (cf. SKK 12.2). But here the word <foreign>basana</foreign> appears between the particle <foreign>ma</foreign> and the punctuation mark, followed by a list of vocative words to the relatives, indicating that the meaning intended by the author must have been ‘his words’.</note> are [addressed] to a youngster, [he addresses him or her as] ‘boy’ (<foreign>utun</foreign>),<note>In MdS <foreign>utun</foreign> means ‘(a friendly term of address for boys and young men) boys, lads; utun inji (name of an unborn foetus) boy-girl; cf. <foreign>inji</foreign>’. In OS, most occurrences are vocative, although the use as common noun also appears in the combination with <foreign>si</foreign> (<foreign>si utun</foreign> ‘the child’).</note> ‘girl’ (<foreign>eten</foreign>),<note>The word <foreign>eten</foreign> is exclusively used as a vocative in the OS corpus at my disposal. It is attested in KaPaṅ <foreign>passim</foreign>, used by Jayakeling to address his wife, and by Batara Guru to his daughter Sri in KaKat. </note> ‘baby’ (<foreign>orok</foreign>), ‘my child’, ‘my little sibling’. [If they are addressed] to an elder, [he addresses him or her as] ‘my elder brother’,<note>The word <foreign>lañcək</foreign> ‘elder brother’ is not necessarily gender-specific, but it tends to be used for male addressees. Cf. MdS <foreign>pun lanceuk</foreign> ‘my husband’ (a wife when addressing her husband). The presence of <foreign>əcə</foreign> in the list also suggests that the author intended to list both a term for a male and for a female elder sibling.</note> ‘my elder nephew or niece’, ‘my elder sister’, ‘my senior’, and ‘my grandfather’. His exclamations are:<note>Cf. <foreign>vastu</foreign> in OJ (OJED s.v. <foreign>vastu</foreign> 2) ‘to declare that something will or must certainly happen, to lay down (also by means of a blessing or curse), to settle (give a pronouncement with <foreign>vastu</foreign>)’; also <foreign>pamastu</foreign> = <foreign>paṅastu</foreign> (from <foreign>vastu</foreign>?) KHWj 2.116b: <foreign>ḍuh pukulun dumadak pamastu paduka saṅ mahamuni</foreign>. I interpret <foreign>paṅvastu</foreign> as ‘salutation, blessing’ in the light of the meaning of <foreign>pangésto</foreign> or <foreign>pangéstu</foreign> in MdS, namely ‘blessing, exclamation of blessing, opening term; (esp. used as a polite term when replying if asked how he, the family is’.</note> are ‘be well!’ (<foreign>sumaṅər</foreign>), ‘what a pity!’ (<foreign>tətəiṅ amat</foreign>). As numerous are the ten pacifying acts,<note>The <foreign>dasa-pasanta</foreign> in this passage seems to be a localization case from the concept <foreign>daśa-pāramitā</foreign> found in SiGu 11. For the notion of <foreign>dasa-pasanta</foreign> influenced by Buddhist teachings, see Chapter 10, §Borrowing Buddhist Doctrines.</note> namely: being virtuous,<note>The translation of <foreign>guna</foreign> as ‘virtuous’ is based on the explanation in <ref target="DHARMA_CritEdSasanaMahaguru.xml#sasanaMahaguru_22.01">SMG 22.1</ref> <foreign>ini ma iña hayu na təmən, diṅaranan saṅ hyaṅ dasa-sila, dasa ta ma sapuluh, sila ta ma ṅaranna guna </foreign>“As for this one, it is the essence of goodness, called the ten holy virtues (<foreign>saṅ hyaṅ dasa-sila</foreign>). <foreign>Dasa</foreign> means ten, <foreign>sila </foreign>means virtuous”<foreign>.</foreign></note> reverent (<foreign>nama</foreign>),<note>In OJ and OS, the word <foreign>nama</foreign> in the meaning ‘salutation, reverential’ only occurs in invocations. The base form in Skt. is <foreign>namas</foreign>, probably the OJ and OS derivation <foreign>nama</foreign> from <foreign>namas</foreign> is similar to OJ <foreign>tapa </foreign>&lt; Skt. <foreign>tapas</foreign>.</note> sympathetic,<note>In MdS, we find <foreign>hook</foreign> only in the suffixed form <foreign>hookeun</foreign> ‘stand looking dumbfounded/ disconcerted’. The context suggests a meaning like ‘sympathy’ or ‘enthusiasm’. No other occurrence is found in OS texts.</note> forgiving,<note>On the meaning of <foreign>pesok</foreign>, See my comment on this word in <ref target="DHARMA_CritEdSasanaMahaguru.xml#sasanaMahaguru_20.05">SMG 20.5</ref>.</note> loving, compassionate, generous,<note>See my comment on the word <foreign>mukpruk</foreign> in <ref target="DHARMA_CritEdSasanaMahaguru.xml#sasanaMahaguru_20.05">SMG 20.5</ref>. For the /k/ ~ /ø/ variation, see Chapter 3, §Phonology.</note> gentle,<note>In MdS, <foreign>ulas</foreign> means ‘to polish st., coat st., spread st. (e.g. with paint, whitewash, ointment, salve, oil, etc., also in conjunction with moistening of materials with water in the traditional way of weaving). I suggest that it should be related to MdS and Mal. <foreign>elus </foreign>‘handle so. tactfully, talk to s.o. quietly, softly, sooth, calm, appease s.o.’.</note> tranquil, ingratiating. That is why someone who is given an order is happy [and] joyful, bright [and] shining. That is called the ultimate consciousness.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_14.04">These are the metaphors for it:<note>Based on the context, this metaphor seems to refer to <foreign>parigəiṅ</foreign>.</note> gold, silver, jewel, diamond. They are called the four holy courtesies. This is its meaning: gold means the speech which is right, accurate, clear, [applying] the formula of five syllables.<note>The occurrence in this context of the word <foreign>pañcaksara</foreign>, designating the Skt. phrase <foreign>namaś śivāya</foreign>, or ‘Homage to Śiva!’<foreign>,</foreign> seems to imply that it was in common use as a polite greeting to interlocutors. See examples of salutations <foreign>nama sivaya </foreign>in Chapter 10, §God among gods.</note> Silver means the mind which is accomplished, proper, good. Jewel means his consciousness is bright [and] shining, wide [and] broad.<note>The occurrence of <foreign>loganda</foreign> in this context is comparable to Mal. compounds with similar imitative reduplication: <foreign>porak-poranda, karut-marut</foreign>. See Sneddon 2010: 26.</note> Diamond means cheerfully laughing,<note>On the word <foreign>caṅciṅ</foreign>, see my comment on <ref target="DHARMA_CritEdSasanaMahaguru.xml#sasanaMahaguru_21.02"/>; cf. SKK 8.1.</note> visibly smiling,<note>The word <foreign>imuc</foreign> corresponds to MdS <foreign>imut</foreign> ‘smile’. See Chapter 3, §Phonology.</note> pleasant of heart. They are called the four courtesies.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_14.05">They are the people who originate from the pure ones among lands. The pure ones among lands are the offering place, the place of rolled offerings (? <foreign>pabuntəlan</foreign>),<note>The base word of <foreign>pabuntəlan</foreign>, viz. <foreign>buntəl</foreign>, means ‘to wrap, to roll’ in MdS. Cf. OJ <foreign>vuntəl</foreign>, <foreign>avuntəlan</foreign> ‘with a wrapping of..., with… intertwined’ attested in KY 31.2: <foreign>dyah maṅken pasavit gaḍuṅ rari gəluṅta linaraṅan avuntəlan səkar </foreign>where Soewito Santoso translates it as ‘decorated’: “Milady, now you must wear a necklace of <foreign>gadung </foreign>flowers and your hair knot may not be decorated with flowers anymore”. Seeing the relation of <foreign>vuntəl</foreign> with flowers, it may be that <foreign>pabuntəlan</foreign> refers to a place where rolled objects — probably leaves with flowers like we find in Bali nowadays — are offered. Pabuntelan is also recorded as a toponym in south Bandung (Lasmiati 2016: 389).</note> the worship place, the sturdy house (? <foreign>imah manəh</foreign>),<note>The term <foreign>imah manəh</foreign> only occurs in this text and in <foreign>Sri Ajñana</foreign>. In the latter, <foreign>imah manəh</foreign> occurs five times, referring to the abode of the Five Gods (<foreign>pañca-devata</foreign>), located in the upper world. Could it be referring to<foreign>caṇḍi</foreign>-type shrines?</note> the sanctuary, the temple tower, the <foreign>liṅga</foreign>, the statue,<note>The word <foreign>liṅgir</foreign> is a variant of <foreign>liṅir</foreign> ‘carved or chiseled image’ (OJED, s.v.). Cf. <foreign>haṅər</foreign> = <foreign>aṅgər</foreign>.</note> the <foreign>gaṅsa</foreign> stone (<foreign>batu gaṅsa</foreign>),<note>Zoetmulder defines <foreign>gaṅsa</foreign> as ‘bell-metal’ (OJED, s.v.). He mentions its occurrence in SD 29.8: <foreign>kəṇḍaṅ goṅ gaṅsa gubar asahuran </foreign>“<foreign>kendang</foreign> drum, <foreign>gong</foreign>, <foreign>gangsa</foreign>, and small gong (<foreign>gubar</foreign>) are sounding alternately”, in which <foreign>gaṅsa</foreign> clearly refers to a music instrument, but it is unclear whether it is distinct from <foreign>goṅ</foreign>, or is a particular kind of <foreign>goṅ</foreign>. SC 1110–1114 also mentions <foreign>batu gaṅsa</foreign> among objects in a shrine: <foreign>aṅgəs ma eta sakitu, ditəndən liṅga liṅgir, candi baṅ candi putih, candi hejo candi kuniṅ, harəca dəṅ batu gaṅsa</foreign> “After [mentioning] all of that, <foreign>lingga</foreign> and statue are placed [in] the red and white sanctuaries, green and yellow sanctuaries, [along with] sculptures and the <foreign>gaṅsa</foreign> stones”. Cf. BM 98–99 <foreign>iṅ na gooṅ braṅ na gaṅsa, seah na gəndaṅ sarunay</foreign> which Noorduyn &amp; Teeuw translate as “the gongs droned, the cymbals sounded, the drums and the shawms were played”. West (2021) prefers to translates <foreign>gaṅsa</foreign> as ‘flat gong’. In MdS, <foreign>gangsa</foreign> means ‘bronze’ (for basins, gongs, etc.). In MdJ, it means ‘1 classical Javanese musical instrument or ensemble of instruments (kr for gamelan). 2 bronze. 3 gamelan gong’. The term <foreign>batu gaṅsa</foreign> is perhaps equivalent to what is called <foreign>batu goong</foreign> in the Sundanese-speaking area nowadays. Examples of this kind of stone, scattered around a <foreign>lingga</foreign>, are found at Situs Citaman, Pulosari, Banten, known as Batu Goong.</note> land with statues, where human figures are created [and] sweeping [is performed]. So many are all lands which are maintained, waters that are strained [and] purified. It is indeed a good person, a kind person. He is an accomplished person. The one who is considered to originate from the pure ones among lands is aware of the holy precepts, heeding the advice of mother, father, grandfather and great-grandfather, knowing the teachings of the great scholars, upholding the words of the accomplished ones.</p></div>
.<div corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_15">
1600<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_15.01">This is the account of the ancient ones who instated the holy instructions of the accomplished ones: the deified ancestor Déwaraja, the deified ancestor Rawung Langit, the deified ancestor at Medang, the deified ancestor at Menir.<note>These figures occur (with some variant readings) in the <foreign>Carita Parahyaṅan</foreign> among the ultimate ancestors of Sundanese kings. According to this chronicle, Rahyangta Déwaraja and Rahyangta ri Medang refer to one figure, Kandiawan. Déwaraja is the name he bore before he became an ascetic, while Rahyangta ri Medang is the name he took after becoming a <foreign>rajarəsi</foreign>. In the same narrative, Rawung Langit is the fourth of the five sons of Kandiawan, who ruled as king before Mandimiñak. The last figure, who also seems to be the most important, is Rahyangta ri Mənir, the other name of Wreti Kandayun, the incarnation of the fifth <foreign>kusika</foreign>, Patañjala. He is attributed as the creator of Purbatisti and Purbajati, the two main scriptures of the ascetic group (<foreign>karəsian</foreign>).</note> They are called the four accomplished ones. That is why in the present, men who are aware of the holy supreme <foreign>dharma</foreign>, knowledgeable about the secret teachings of men, they are called esoteric men.<note>In OJtexts, <foreign>janmarahasya</foreign> means ‘the secret of life’, but here it seems to be used of menn who have secret knowledge, so we are dealing with a local reinterpretation of the term. For an occurrence of <foreign>janmarahasya</foreign> in the OJ corpus, see KuñjDhK 21.1 <foreign>yekin janmarahasya mūlya pavarahkv iri kita pituhun, ndah yatneriya paṅrəṅə̄ varavarahku tan imanimanən </foreign>“This is the sublime secret of human life — take to heart these teachings of mine to you, listen attentively to my lessons and do not treat them lightly”.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_15.02">If they die, their soul will find a beautiful heaven, finding daytime that does not turn into night, joy that does not turn into sorrow, heaven that does not turn into into [the hell of] sinners, pleasure that does not turn into pain, good that does not turn into into bad, fortunate that does not turn into unfortunate, subtle that does not turn into gross, being gone that does not turn into being present, ancestors that do not turn into gods. That is what is called the supreme liberation.<note>The word <foreign>ləñəp</foreign> is a synonym of <foreign>mokta</foreign>. Cf. <ref target="DHARMA_CritEdSasanaMahaguru.xml#sasanaMahaguru_33.03">SMG 33.3</ref> i<foreign>ni kaləpasənana ṅaranya, saṅ hyaṅ nirmala, ya catur-mokta ṅaranya, ləpas, ləñəp, mokta, hilaṅ, ya ta catur-mokta ṅaranya </foreign>“This is called the release, the holy purity. It is called the four final liberations (<foreign>catur-mokta</foreign>): release, disappearance, vanishing, dissolution. That is called the four final liberations”. Cf. also Mal. <foreign>lenyap</foreign> ‘diminished’.</note></p></div>
.<div corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_16">
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_16.01">Likewise are the people in the present.<note>Based on the context, what is meant by ‘people in the present’ here refers to deified ancestors mentioned in 15.1.</note> Compare us taking a bath, the choices of the water to be touched by us are only two: the one which is turbid and the one which is clear. Likewise are the behaviors of people, two (types) being put into practice: the bad and the good. Likewise are the people: the cause of their being treated badly is that bad behavior of theirs. Likewise are the people: the cause of their being treated well is that good behavior of theirs. That is why people are bad by their behavior, why they are good by their behavior.<note>Cf. the similar expression in <ref target="DHARMA_CritEdSiksaGuru.xml#siksaguru_06.01">SiGu 6.1</ref> <foreign>ndya ya nihan saṅ hyaṅ jagat upadrava ṅaranya, ndya ya, nihan, hala tuməmu halanya, hayu tuməmu hayunya, vilut tuməmu vilutnya, bənər tumemu bənərnya, sukha tuməmu sukhanya, duhkha tuməmu duhkhanya. </foreign>This expression alludes to the notion of <foreign>karma</foreign>. See Chapter 10, §Siksa Kurung.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_16.02">Water is like that, insofar as the choices of it are said to be two. Water that is refreshing and clear is the holy supreme <foreign>dharma</foreign>, that is what is practiced by the great scholars. Water that is haunted and turbid is the emotional conduct (<foreign>rasa-carita</foreign>), which is practiced by all the <foreign>viku</foreign>s for whom the <foreign>nec plus ultra</foreign> is worldly.<note>The mss. AB spell <foreign>paramarata </foreign>instead of <foreign>paramarta</foreign> (Skt./OJ <foreign>paramārtha</foreign>). This is common in the OS corpus: cf. RD 45 <foreign>tuturnya paramarata </foreign>“His consciousness is prominent”, PR 19r4 <foreign>ləvih balik alit sarira sunya-paramarata </foreign>“superior while returning to the subtle element, the body whose <foreign>nec plus ultra</foreign> is the void”<foreign>. </foreign>I take <foreign>paramarta</foreign> with <foreign>lokika </foreign>as compound, <foreign>lokika-paramarta</foreign>. It is an attribute to the <foreign>viku</foreign>, so that <foreign>viku lokika-paramarta </foreign>means ‘the <foreign>viku</foreign>s for whom the <foreign>nec plus ultra</foreign> is worldly’.</note> That is why it (i.e., water) is comparable to consciousness<note>It is noteworthy that ms. A consistently spells <foreign>centana</foreign> and <foreign>acentana</foreign>. These spelling variants are also attested in ms. A of the <foreign>Kuñjarakarṇa</foreign> (also of West Javanese provenance): Kuñj 808 <foreign>centanātma</foreign>; 1805 <foreign>centāna</foreign> (ed. van der Molen 1983).</note> as well as unconsciousness. Consciousness is aware and mindful of memories without turning into forgetfulness. It is the root of a favorable rebirth, the cause of a prosperous earth.<note>See my comment on a similar expression <foreign>ṅrətakən bumi</foreign> in SKK 12.2.</note> Unconsciousness is forgetfulness [and] confusion, not endowed with memory. It is the cause of destruction, the starting point of the Kali era, the base of deviation, the root of falsehood.<note>In the Old Sundanese context, the word <foreign>liñok</foreign> is only found once in this text and nowhere else. Even in OJ, this word only appears in later texts such as <foreign>Koravāśrama, Bhīma Svarga</foreign>, and <foreign>Pararaton</foreign>.</note> It is the cause of people going to hell. That should not be taken as truth by those who wish to be sincere.</p></div>
1605<div corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_17">
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_17.01">These are the words of the holy man, when he maintains his possessions.<note>The word <foreign>drəbya</foreign> ‘possession’ in this context refers to the internal possessions of the holy man, i.e., the macrocosmic and microcosmic world (<foreign>bhuvana lavan śārīra</foreign>), and the three instruments (<foreign>bāyu</foreign>, <foreign>śabda</foreign>, <foreign>hədap</foreign>). Cf. SHH 18.1 <foreign>sira ta sinaṅguh saṅ hyaṅ pramāṇa, makadrabya bhuvana lavan sarva śārīra, ṅuniveh bāyu śabda hədap </foreign>“He is considered as The Authority, having the world and body as possessions, also the breath, the speech, [and] the mind”. It seems that the author intends to associate <foreign>bāyu</foreign>, <foreign>śabda, hədap</foreign> to the three rulers. On <foreign>mahayu</foreign> as a transitive verb, cf. <foreign>mahayu na kadatvan</foreign> ‘to beautify the palace’ in the inscription Kawali 1a (Aditia Gunawan &amp; Griffiths 2021: 184–185).</note> These are the three threads in the world.<note>On the concept of <foreign>tri-tantu</foreign>, see Chapter 10.</note> Our (<foreign>kita</foreign>)<note>The pronoun <foreign>kita</foreign> only appears here in the whole SKK. See Chapter 3, §Pronoun.</note> breath is the ruler, our speech is the elders, our mind is the hermits. Those are the three threads in the world, which are considered as the support of the world.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_17.02">These are the group of three in the distant [world]:<note>Cf. <foreign>bumi lamba </foreign>in SKK 1.3 and 1.4.</note> Wisnu is considered as king, Brahma is considered as elder, Iswara is considered a hermit. It is the reason why the three threads are the support of the world, [while] the group of three are the life of the world. They are considered as the three threads for all people. [We] should hold [them] up, hold [them] fast until they are straight, true, evident, [and] present.<note>The word <foreign>vartamanah</foreign> is from Skt. <foreign>vartamāna</foreign> ‘present, existing; the present, in the present time’. On unetymological -<foreign>h</foreign> and -<foreign>k</foreign>, see Chapter 3, §Phonology.</note> The reason why the world is prosperous, why the earth is affluent, is because the actions of people are well maintained.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_17.03">Likewise, the scholars who are firm in their scholarship will prosper; the monk who are firm in their monkhood prosper; the <foreign>maṅuyu</foreign>s who are firm in their <foreign>maṅuyu</foreign>-ship will prosper; the <foreign>palikən</foreign><note>The word <foreign>palikən</foreign> is not recorded in dictionaries. It seems implausible to emend it to <foreign>palika</foreign> ‘diver’ (found in SKK 7.3) since it is mentioned along with the list of people related to religious institutions. Might there be any connection with the Skt. term <foreign>kāpālika</foreign>? See OJED <foreign>kapālikabrata</foreign> ‘of the observance of the Kapālikas’ (the correct spellings would have been <foreign>kāpālika</foreign>- and Kāpālikas).</note> who are firm in their <foreign>palikən</foreign>-ship will be prosper; the monks who are firm in their monkhood will be prosper; the wandering ascetics (<foreign>aməṅ</foreign>)<note>My interpretation of <foreign>aməṅ</foreign> as wandering ascetics is based on Bujaṅga Manik, the protagonist of the eponymous text. Another name for the protagonist is <foreign>aməṅ layaran</foreign>, attributed when the ascetic stepped off a boat, anchored in Kalapa during his first return from pilgrims as a hermit in eastern Java.</note> who are firm in their wanderership will be prosper; the <foreign>vasi</foreign>s<note>On the interpretation of the term <foreign>vaśi</foreign>, see Appendix 1.</note> who are firm in their <foreign>vasi</foreign>-ship will be prosper; the nuns (<foreign>əbon</foreign>)<note>For an explanation of the term <foreign>əbon</foreign>, see Chapter 11.</note> who are firm in their nunship will be prosper; the renouncers (<foreign>tiagi</foreign>) who are firm in their renunciation will be successful; even more so the aspirants (<foreign>valaka</foreign>) who are firm in their aspirantship will be successful; the peasants who are firm in their peasantship will be successful; the thieves (<foreign>əvah</foreign>)<note>My translation assumes that<foreign>əvah</foreign> is equivalent to MdS <foreign>euwah-euwah</foreign> ‘scoundrel, thief, robber; <foreign>manuk euwah-euwah</foreign> (C.) bird of prey’. Without proposing any gloss, OJED records <foreign>aṅəvah</foreign> as attested in Sum 10.9 <foreign>solah bhāvanirāmaṅun sih aṅəvah bapa-bapa juga denirāṅucap</foreign>. This has been translated as “Everything she did aroused affection, even if she could only sigh ( <foreign>aṅəvah</foreign>) and say ‘da, da’”. (ed. and trans. Worsley <foreign>et al</foreign>. 2013). Worsley <foreign>et al</foreign>. have taken the word <foreign>aṅəvah</foreign> to be a variant of <foreign>aṅəhah</foreign> (cf. OJED <foreign>uməhah</foreign>, s.v. <foreign>əhah</foreign>), meaning ‘to sigh, moan’). This OJ evidence does not seem to furnish a more promising angle of interpretation than MdS <foreign>euwah-euwah</foreign>.</note> firm in their thievery will be successful; the <foreign>gusti</foreign> firm in their <foreign>gusti</foreign>-ship will be successful; the minister firm in their ministership will be successful; the <foreign>masaṅ</foreign>s (?)<note>In the light of <ref target="DHARMA_CritEdSasanaMahaguru.xml#sasanaMahaguru_19.02">SMG 19.2</ref> it is clear that <foreign>masaṅ</foreign> refers to an agricultural activity: <foreign>tani ma ṅaranya, paka dibuat ñadap masaṅ ñavara, cocooan, pəpəlakan, ya tani ṅaranya</foreign> “The farmer (<foreign>tani</foreign>) means: [they] are advanced (<foreign>paka</foreign>) in harvesting rice (<foreign>dibuat</foreign>), in tapping, in putting the yoke, in planting paddy (? <foreign>ñavara</foreign>), in taking care of the livestock, in planting the crops”.</note> who are firm in their <foreign>masaṅ</foreign>-ship will be successful; the <foreign>bujaṅga</foreign>s who are firm in their <foreign>bujaṅga</foreign>-ship will be successful; the seamen who are firm in their seamanship will be successful; the <foreign>disi</foreign>s who are firm in their <foreign>disi</foreign>-ship will be successful; the elders who are firm in their eldership will be successful; the hermits who are firm in their hermitship will be successful; the rulers who are firm in their rulership will be successful. Formerly, the scholars, together with the divine king who were firm in making the world prosperous, so that the north, south, west [and] east — everything which is held by the earth [and] covered by the sky — prospered, all beings are alive, all of them.<note>I supply a comma after <foreign>maṅhurip</foreign>, since in OS this word is usually placed at the end of a clause or a sentence. Cf. FCP 26r3: <foreign>kita tuturkənən voṅ sakabeh, pinakadədəlan bvana, pinakadasarniṅ prətivi, andəlan sarva maṅhurip </foreign>“you are the person to be followed by all people, serving as the support of the world, as the foundation of the earth, the stabilizer of all living beings”. In this case, <foreign>maṅhurip </foreign>‘to live’ seems to be intransitive, and it corresponds to OJ <foreign>(m)ahurip</foreign> ‘to live, living’, not to <foreign>(m)aṅhurip </foreign>‘to give life, to grant life’.</note> </p></div>
.<div corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_18">
1610<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_18.01">All kinds of beings means: plant beings, animal beings, human beings, individual beings (<foreign>si voṅ</foreign>), the substance of the individual (<foreign>vastu si voṅ</foreign>).<note>In this context, <foreign>vastu</foreign> probably means ‘substance’. Cf. the name of the Sundanese King, Wastu Kancana, literally meaning ‘the substance of gold’ or Lingga Wastu ‘whose essence is the <foreign>lingga</foreign>’ in CVG; cf. KaPaṅ 202 <foreign>ṅaranna vastu muliya</foreign> ‘its name is the priceless essence’.</note> That is the reason that all of them are called all beings.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_18.02">Plant beings are grass, trees, creepers, shrubs, all that is alive, fresh green, wild. They are called plant beings.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_18.03">Animal beings are all kinds of animals, big or small, on land or in the water. They are called animal beings.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_18.04">Human beings are human [only] in appearance, for their character is not good.<note>This sentence and the one that follows are syntactically problematic because of the conjunction kena, whereas we expect a conjunction that expresses the meaning ‘only’ or ‘but’, such as ṅan, heṅan, or OJ words like kunaṅ, kintu which mean ‘but’ and have the same consonants as kena despite being unattested in OS. Another way to fix the syntax of this sentence would be to skip ruana janma in the first sentence and rampes yuni and rampes baṅsa in the second sentence, so that kena would make sense in the expected meaning ‘because’. Cf. The similar syntax in SKK 8.2 and 8.3.</note> Individual beings (<foreign>si voṅ</foreign>) have good character, good family, for they do not know yet the holy <foreign>dharma</foreign>. The substance of the individual is the one who is firm in the impact of knowing, knowing the holy <foreign>dharma</foreign>, knowing the reality of holy knowledge. Those are called real human beings.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_18.05">May this be sought to be internalized by the inhabitants of the world,<note>We find several occurrences where the word <foreign>əsi</foreign> refers to the person. Cf. <foreign>aya ma nu ṅəsi dayəh ivə</foreign> ‘If one resides here’ in Kawali 6 (Aditia Gunawan &amp; Griffiths 2021: 188). Cf. <foreign>əsi imahna</foreign> ‘wife’ in SKK 12.6.</note> four in number. These are <foreign>kurija, mataja, bagaja, payuja</foreign>. <foreign>Kurija</foreign> means all kinds which appear from the mouth;<note>In the corresponding SMG passage (17.1), we have <foreign>urija </foreign>(or <foreign>vurija </foreign>in ms. B)<foreign>. </foreign>See my comment on <foreign>urija</foreign> in SMG 17.1.</note> <foreign>mataja</foreign> means all kinds which appear from the eyes; <foreign>bagaja </foreign>means all kinds which appear from the vulva; <foreign>payuja</foreign> means all kinds which appear from the anus. Those are called the holy four origins.</p></div>
1615<div corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_19">
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_19.01">These are the 6 abilities of people in the world: to count (<foreign>ṅaṅka</foreign>), to chain yarns (<foreign>ñigi</foreign>), to tie (<foreign>ṅikət</foreign>), to touch (<foreign>ñigəṅ</foreign>), to bury (<foreign>ṅaruaṅ</foreign>), to heap up (<foreign>ṅaromboṅ</foreign>)<foreign>.</foreign><note>I interpret <foreign>ṅa</foreign>romboṅ based on one of the meanings of rombong in Malay, viz. ‘piling or heaping up’. This word is clearly connected to Mal. rombongan ‘a group’. Wilkinson also notes rombong as ‘Malacca basket; this is a basket of fine <foreign>pandan</foreign> matwork made usually in a set to nest one within the other; in shape round, triangular or polygonal; each basket having a separate overlapping cover. But the older <foreign>rombong</foreign> was of larger size and used for storing rice; <foreign>tĕrubong</foreign>. The small sizes (known also as <foreign>kĕmbal</foreign>) are used as work-baskets, sireh-baskets, etc.’.</note> To count means estimating; <foreign>ñigi</foreign><note>The verb <foreign>ñigi</foreign> is not recorded in dictionaries. However, Hardjadibrata notes its base <foreign>sigi</foreign> in the dialect register which means ‘end of warp yarns (hanging like a fringe)’.</note> means twisting;<note>Cf. OJ <foreign>unte</foreign>, <foreign>aṅunte, inunte, aṅunte-hunte</foreign> ‘to twist together, wind (cf. MdS <foreign>untay</foreign>)’. Cf. Mal. <foreign>untai</foreign> ‘a chain; numeral coefficient for necklace, etc.’.</note> <foreign>ṅikət</foreign> is various bindings; <foreign>ñigəṅ</foreign> is centering (? <foreign>məṅpəṅ</foreign>),<note>My interpretation of <foreign>məṅpəṅ</foreign> is based on the meaning of <foreign>pəṅpəṅ</foreign> in OJ ‘(subst.) being used at the right moment’. Cf. MdS <foreign>meungpeung</foreign> ‘while it is still ... (do st. that is not possible later, make the best while o. can)’. This word hence seems to be synonymous with OJ <foreign>səḍəṅ</foreign> ‘right time (not too early or too late), right moment, right measure (not too big or too small)’. I presume that <foreign>məṅpəṅ</foreign> is not only related to time, but also to measure or position. </note> splitting (<foreign>məlah</foreign>), using a wedge (<foreign>mañcir</foreign>),<note><foreign>mañcir</foreign> can be recognized from MdS <foreign>pañcir </foreign>‘wedge’, while <foreign>mancir</foreign> means ‘use a wedge (e.g. in splitting wood), drive a wedge in somewhere’.</note> halving, evaluating, calculating (<foreign>ṅaṅgit aṅka</foreign>),<note>My emendation of <foreign>ṅagitaka</foreign> to <foreign>ṅaṅgit aṅka</foreign> is based on the explanation of <foreign>ñigəṅ</foreign> which seems to be related to the activity of measuring and apportioning. In MdS, <foreign>ṅaṅgit</foreign> means ‘to compose/write st. (a story, speech, etc.) in beautiful form/in elegant style; write st. in verse form)’, while in OJ we only find its passive form <foreign>inaṅgit</foreign> meaning ‘to interlace, make into a garland’. It seems that the latter is the original meaning, while MdS reflects a secondary development. In OS, only the base form is attested in SC <foreign>aṅgit artati dəṅ prəlabi</foreign> ‘the composition of Artati and Prelabi’. The word <foreign>aṅka</foreign> also occurs in OS, e.g. in BM 1300 <foreign>bənaṅ aiṅ adu aṅka </foreign>which Noorduyn &amp; Teeuw translate as “what was the result of my weighing inten­tions”. I prefer to translate this phrase as “as the result of my calculation”. The compound <foreign>ṅaṅgit aṅka</foreign> (litt. ‘to compose numbers’) seems to be synonymous with <foreign>adu aṅka </foreign>(litt. ‘to match numbers’), involving a verb and a noun. On this basis, I interpret <foreign>ṅaṅgit aṅka</foreign> as ‘to calculate.</note> measuring, equating; to bury means all kinds of digging; <foreign>ṅaromboṅ</foreign> is all kinds of spaces (<foreign>hələt-hələt</foreign>). Those are called the six abilities (<foreign>sad-guna</foreign>),<note>The number of skills (guna) listed here is six, which is reminiscent of the Skt. and OJ concept of ṣaḍguṇa. What is remarkable is that the six gunas here are entirely different from those we find in OJ sources, where the same terms refer primarily to the ability of the king: sandhi ‘peace’, vigraha ‘war’, āyana ‘marching’, āsana ‘sitting encamped’, dvaidhībhāva ‘dividing his force’, and saṅśraya ’seeking the protection of a more powerful king’ (OJED, s.v. ṣaḍguṇa). The OJ tradition is in conformity with Sanskrit sources, such as Arthaśāstra 7.1.6–12 where the six are listed in prose (transl. Olivelle 2013), while they are listed in verse-form at MDhŚ 7.160: saṁdhiṁ ca vigrahaṁ caiva yānam āsanam eva ca | dvaidhībhāvaṁ saṁśrayaṁ ca ṣaḍguṇāṁś cintayet sadā “He should constantly think about the sixfold strategy: forging alliances, waging war, marching into battle, remaining stationary, pursuing a double stratagem, and seeking asylum” (ed. and transl. Olivelle 2005). In our text, the ṣaḍguṇa is recontextualized, being applied to servants.</note> so many are all the abilities of the people.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_19.02">These are the 4 desires of the people: the wish to be pure (<foreign>yun suda</foreign>), the wish to be happy (<foreign>yun suka</foreign>), the wish to ascend (<foreign>yun muṅgah</foreign>), the wish to be liberated (<foreign>yun luput</foreign>). This is what it means: <foreign>yun suda</foreign> is desiring to be healthy (<foreign>purna</foreign>),<note>For the interpretation of <foreign>purna</foreign> as healthy, see OJED (s.v. <foreign>pūrṇa</foreign> 4) ‘restored to its former condition’. Cf. <ref target="DHARMA_CritEdSasanaMahaguru.xml#sasanaMahaguru_19.02">SMG 19.2</ref> <foreign>purna ṅaranya, hantə dibogakahivaṅan, kativasan</foreign> “the one who is healthy (<foreign>purna</foreign>) means [the one who] does not have defects and diseases”.</note> refusing to suffer from any disease; <foreign>yun suka</foreign> is desiring to be rich, refusing to be deprived of possessions; <foreign>yun muṅgah </foreign>is desiring heaven, refusing to obtain [another rebirth in] the world; <foreign>yun luput</foreign> is desiring release, refusing to be taken by<note>Probably <foreign>kabava ku</foreign> should be emended to <foreign>kabava ka</foreign>, but <foreign>kabava ku</foreign> is very common, while <foreign>kabava ka</foreign> never occurs in the OS corpus. Cf. KaPani 440 <foreign>saṅkan jalma kalolita, kabava ku para yuga</foreign> “It is the reason why people are convulsed, [and] taken by various <foreign>yuga</foreign>s”. The term <foreign>yuga </foreign>here seems to have a negative connotation.</note> all heavens.<note>The noun <foreign>sorga</foreign> preceded by the word <foreign>para</foreign> occurs several times in the OS corpus, e.g. in SA 1083–1084 nu ṅəsi rahina sada, pañaraman para sorga “who lives in Rahina Sada, the lessons of all celestials”; PR 63v pahi mijil ti niskala, lain ti na para sorga “All appears from the unmanifest, but not from all kinds of heavens”. The meaning of <foreign>para sorga </foreign>seems to vary with the contexts, sometimes indicating celestial beings, sometimes a celestial place. I believe that the latter is intended in this context. This meaning also occurs in KaMah 1455–1457<foreign> eboh ta aiṅ magahan, eta tu na para sorga, kasorgaan voṅ sajagat</foreign> “Here I would like to give [you] advice, that is all kind of heavens, heavens for all people in the world”. Cf. <foreign>para nusa</foreign> ‘all kinds of countries’ in SKK 11.31. See Chapter 10, §Cosmology.</note> That is why so many are all the desires of the people.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_19.03">These are the 4 who bathe in the river, that is to say: male, female, effeminate man, unfeminine woman.<note>The expression <foreign>kədi malavadiṅ</foreign> is undoubtedly equivalent to OJ <foreign>kəḍi valavadi. </foreign>OJED glosses <foreign>kəḍi</foreign> as ‘emasculated, eunuch’ and <foreign>valavadi </foreign>as ‘a woman and not yet a woman. Prob. Skt <foreign>abala</foreign>, impotent, and <foreign>vadhri</foreign>, castrated’. On the OJ expression, Acri (2017: 229, fn. 47) notes as follows: “ <foreign>kəḍi valavadi </foreign>is used in an identical context in the <foreign>Vr̥haspatitattva</foreign>, the <foreign>Tattvajñāna</foreign> and the <foreign>Ślokāntara</foreign> (11–12.2). The last text employs the two words to explain the Sanskrit sequence <foreign>klīvo ’balo vadhriḥ</foreign>, as follows: <foreign>ṅaranya kəḍi, valavadi ṅaranya strī tan strī—‘klīva</foreign> (from <foreign>klība</foreign>, emasculated) means eunuch, <foreign>valavadi</foreign> means a woman and yet not a woman’. <foreign>Vr̥haspatitattva</foreign> 33.64 explains <foreign>kəḍi</foreign> and <foreign>valavadi</foreign> as <foreign>janmāntarapuruṣa</foreign>, which would translate as ‘transsexual’”.</note> That is the number. How many are the [types of] earmarked goods? [There are] 2, that is to say: ripe and raw, bad and good, small and big. How many are the flavors? [There are] 6, that is to say: salty (<foreign>lavaṇa</foreign>)<foreign>, </foreign>hot (<foreign>kaṭuka</foreign>)<foreign>, </foreign>bitter (<foreign>tikta</foreign>)<foreign>,</foreign><note>The spelling <foreign>kaduka</foreign> (for Skt. <foreign>kaṭuka</foreign>) is also found in the SiGu parallel. As for <foreign>tikta</foreign>, none of the witnesses of SiGu has a correct reading according to Sanskrit spelling. However, ms. C reads <foreign>tritta</foreign>, which could be interpreted as a small error for <foreign>trikta</foreign> (due to the resemblance of <foreign>aksara</foreign>s <foreign>ka</foreign> and <foreign>ta</foreign>). It should be noted that the word <foreign>trikta</foreign> was probably the common OS spelling for Skt. <foreign>tikta</foreign>. However, since it is intended as a gloss, I normalize both terms according to Sanskrit spelling in SKK and SiGu. On the spontaneous /r/, see Chapter 3, §Phonology.</note> sour (<foreign>amla</foreign>)<foreign>, </foreign>astringent (<foreign>kaṣāya</foreign>)<foreign>,</foreign><note>‘Astringent’ is the meaning of kaṣāya in Skt. and OJ, but the gloss shows that our author understood it differently. The currency of his interpretation in West Java is confirmed by <ref target="DHARMA_CritEdSiksaGuru.xml#siksaguru_02.05">SiGu 2.5</ref>.</note> sweet (<foreign>madhura</foreign>). <foreign>Lavaṇa</foreign> means salty, <foreign>kaṭuka</foreign> means spicy,<note>On <foreign>lada</foreign> as meaning ‘spicy’, see my comment on <ref target="DHARMA_CritEdSiksaGuru.xml#siksaguru_02.05">SiGu 2.5</ref>, where the word <foreign>lada</foreign> is used in the same meaning and in the same context, even though that text is formulated in OJ.</note> <foreign>tikta</foreign> means bitter, <foreign>amla</foreign> means sour, <foreign>kaṣāya</foreign> means savory, <foreign>madhura</foreign> means sweet. So many are all the things tasted by the people.</p></div>
.<div corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_20">
1620<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_20.01">These are for us to take into possession ourselves, in order that they descend continuously (<foreign>pativah-tivah</foreign>) to children [and] grandchildren, to great grandchildren, to great-great grandchildren, to <foreign>muniṅ</foreign>, to<foreign> aṅgasantana</foreign>, to <foreign>pratisantana</foreign>;<note>Cf. the similar list in AG 1v <foreign>rakeyan darmasikṣa, siya ṅavarah anak, əñcu, umpi, cicip, muniṅ, aṅgasantana, kulasantana, prətisantana, aṅgasaṅ parigal vit vəkas kulakadaṅ sakabeh</foreign> “The venerable Darmasiksa instructs his children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, great-great-grandchildren, <foreign>muniṅ, aṅgasantana, kulasantana, prətisantana</foreign>, <foreign>aṅgasaṅ parigal, </foreign>ultimate descendants, his entire family”<foreign>. </foreign>Cf. also OJ lists of descendants, mainly found in inscriptions, such as the Lintakan charter (841 Śaka) 3r20–21: <foreign>maṅkanā lavasanyan· tmuAkan· sāṁsāra, Avaknya rabinya Anaknya putunya puyutnya Aṅgasnya nāhan· liṁnirar paṅhanākan· sapatha matəhər· mamantiṅakan· hantlū manətək· gulūniṁ hayam</foreign>· “‘That is how long they will find suffering, themselves, their wives, their children, their grandchildren, their great-grandchildren, and their great-great-grandchildren’. Those were his words as he set the curse. Then he smashed the egg, slit the chicken’s throat” (draft ed. and transl. by Tyassanti Kusumo Dewanti, Wayan Jarrah Sastrawan &amp; Arlo Griffiths). ​​Gandhakuti (964 Śaka) 2v2–2v3 <foreign>katmva de santāna prātisantānira, Anak putu buyut· cicik muniṁ pituṁ Aṅśa siraji pādukā mpuṅku </foreign>“would be obtained by his offspring and offspring’s offspring: children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, great-great-grandchildren, the seven [generations of] descendants of Aji Pāduka Mpuṅku” (draft ed. and transl. by Arlo Griffiths &amp; Eko Bastiawan). On the term <foreign>aṅśa</foreign>, see Griffiths 2020: 118–122.</note> all ultimate descendants (<foreign>putu vəkas</foreign>)<note>I interpret <foreign>putu vəkas</foreign> as compound. In OJ and MdS, <foreign>putu</foreign> means grandchild, while OJ <foreign>vəkas</foreign> means ‘1. the last of a stretch in time or space, end, limit, final aim; finally; 2. the highest point, top, height, what surpasses all others, paramount, non plus ultra, first, best or worst’. Cf. <foreign>vit vəkas</foreign> in OJ.</note> of [our] family — those which are suitable be given in inheritance<note>The word dipikakolotan, which I translate as ’to be given in inheritance’, is not found in the dictionary. The meaning is based on context. The circumfix dipi- -an is used to form verbs with a causative meaning. The basic form is kakolotan, from kolot ‘old, parents’, which probably means the same as kabuyutan ‘sacred’, also ‘heirloom’, which is derived from buyut ‘great-grandfather, elder’. Cf. <foreign>dipikabuyutan</foreign> in SMG 3.7.</note> as well as those which are not suitable.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_20.02">Gains from impudence are not suitable to be given inheritance: they are called “gifts of the demons”. Gains from gambling, from subletting (?, <foreign>babalañjaan</foreign>)<note>In MdS as in Mal., <foreign>balañja</foreign> means ‘shopping’, but Rigg notes <foreign>babalanja</foreign> ‘to do marketing, to make purchases of household commodities’. It makes more sense to take it from <foreign>lañja</foreign> ‘add a second layer to the first one, cover in (over/up) st.; repeat a job or action; take a second one to a woman; take a second one to a moneylender/supplier’. So probably <foreign>babalañjaan</foreign> is a nominal derivation which means something like ‘leasing, leasehold, subletting’. The last meaning is attested in a small number of OJ inscriptions. In the Palepangan inscription, for instance, we find: len· sumaṅkā rika hana ta savaḥ bhaṭāra kmitan· rāmanta lamvit· 1 dmak·ni p⟨ū⟩ja [em., pāja insc.], mūla lamvit· 1 tan inukur· Ikā Āpan· hĭnanyan· svabhāvanya, muAṁ lañjān· pirak· dhā 14 patukan· pirak· dhā 4| panurat· pirak· mā 4 | “Besides them there was 1 lamvit of paddy field of the deity kept by the elders as endowment for the cult (pūja) — the value (mūla) of 1 lamvit was not measured, because of the destituteness of its condition — with the income from subletting (lañjān) of 14 dhāraṇa of silver; the patukan of 4 māṣa of silver; the panurat of 4 dhāraṇa of silver” (draft ed. and transl. by Griffiths 2020; cf. Bosch 1917, Bijlage M: 88–98; Boechari 1985–1986: 124–126). However, the reduplication babalañjaan seems unnatural: should we emend it to babak lañjaan? In MdS, the word babakan means newly founded hamlet.</note> are not suitable to be given in inheritance: they are called “gifts of an egocentric mind”.<note>Instead of <foreign>aṅkara</foreign>, may be it should emend <foreign>ambara</foreign> into <foreign>saṅhara </foreign>based on <foreign>ṅahara</foreign> in H? So <foreign>cipta saṅhara</foreign> yield a meaning ‘destructive mind’.</note> Nevertheless, gifts from the mother, gifts from the father, gifts from teachers, they can be given in inheritance: they are called “gods that protect us”. Profits from agriculture can be given in inheritance: they are called “jewels produced from the earth”. Profits from weaving [and] products of husbandry can be given in inheritance: they are called “rubies fallen from the sky”.</p></div>
.<div corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_21">
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_21.01">If there are rich people, then [they] redeem a woman, without knowing about her parents. [Such a woman] should not be taken as purchased servant (<foreign>dipikaritakən</foreign>),<note>My emendation <foreign>dipikaritakən</foreign> is proposed in the light of the occurrence of <foreign>krīta</foreign> ‘purchased slave’ in an OJ legal text that comments on MDhŚ 8.415: dhvajāhr̥to bhaktadāso gr̥hajaḥ krītadattrimau | paitriko daṇḍadāsaś ca saptaite dāsayonayaḥ || “There are seven kinds of slaves: a man captured in war, a man who makes himself a slave to receive food, a slave born in the house, a purchased slave, a gifted slave, a hereditary slave, and a man enslaved for punishment”. This śloka is paraphrased in BAV (5v): <foreign>ka, panaṅkaniṅ kavulā, tavan, kavula saṅke pinaṅan, krīta, ulihiṅ anuku, datrimah, ṅa, kavula paveveh</foreign> “The meaning is: the origins of the slave are the captive, the slave from lack of food, the krīta, i.e. the result of purchase, the <foreign>datrimah</foreign>, i.e. gifted slave”. In Skt. <foreign>krīta</foreign> means ‘bought, purchased; purchased from his natural parents (as a son; one of the twelve kinds of sons acknowledged by the ancient Hindū law)’. In this light, it seems plausible that the base form to which the circumfix <foreign>dipi- -kən</foreign> is applied was a word deriving from Skt. <foreign>krīta</foreign>, and <foreign>karita</foreign> seems to be the closest fit with the ms. readings. The context of <foreign>nəbus vadon</foreign> ‘to redeem a woman’ strengthens my hypothesis. It is also possible that <foreign>dipikaritikən</foreign> is the intended reading, if we can postulate a locally prevalent form <foreign>kariti</foreign> as feminine of <foreign>karita</foreign> (although the fem. of <foreign>krīta</foreign> would actually be <foreign>krītā</foreign> in Skt.).</note> lest we become involved in something wrong. </p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_21.02">There is more — when we do know about her parents, where the servant’s origin is —, if the behavior of her parents is good, the person (in question, <foreign>janma</foreign>) is still good. It is called “being defeated (<foreign>kapapas</foreign>) by <supplied reason="subaudible">ones</supplied> parents’ behavior”. <supplied reason="subaudible">She</supplied> can be taken as purchased servant. But if <supplied reason="subaudible">she is defeated</supplied> by their deceitful behavior, she should not be tolerated. It is called “a person wandering around in hell”.</p>
1625<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_21.03">There is more, [if] there is a person of good behavior, of good foundation,<note>I interpret <foreign>susuk</foreign> as ‘foundation’ based on the usage of the verb <foreign>ñusuk</foreign> which can imply the meaning ‘to build, to open up, to found’. For a discussion of the word <foreign>ñusuk</foreign>, see Aditia Gunawan &amp; Griffiths 2021: 152–153.</note> of good origin, [we should] not fail to redeem [her], but [we] should not immediately (<foreign>tuluy</foreign>)<note>The meaning ‘immediately’ is not recorded for <foreign>tuluy</foreign> in Sundanese dictionaries and GNT. However, in OJ, <foreign>tuluy </foreign>has this meaning. See OJED s.v. <foreign>tuluy </foreign>‘immediate continuation’, <foreign>tumuluy</foreign>, <foreign>tumulvi, tumul</foreign> ‘to continue immediately, to proceed from one thing to the next; to go straight on, penetrate; thereupon, straight away’.</note> take [her] as wife, lest the descendant be a servant. [We] should not fail to tell [it] to our family. After that, we should propose [to marry her], bring a betel quid and serve it.</p>
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_21.04">Those are the powerful words (<foreign>jaṅjavokan</foreign>) so that [her] family returns to its caste,<note>The use of the word <foreign>jati</foreign> in this context is intriguing since it seems to imply the meaning that <foreign>jāti</foreign> typically has in India, namely ‘caste’. The notion of caste is absent in Old Sundanese sources. However, in SKK we see a clear social hierarchy placing the <foreign>hulun</foreign> below the <foreign>tohaan</foreign>. It may therefore be that <foreign>jati</foreign> means ‘caste’ in a loose sense, referring to the low status of the <foreign>hulun</foreign>.</note> so that [she] avoids, escapes from imprisonment,<note>Instead of reading the phrase as <foreign>bətəṅ diri ti pañjara</foreign>, another possibility is to render it as <foreign>bətəṅ di riti-pañjara</foreign>, which can be interpreted as ‘ceased from the bronze cage’. The word <foreign>riti</foreign> is indeed unattested in OS, but it occurs in OJ as a kind of metal. OJED glosses uncertain meanings: ‘a certain metal (bronze, brass?). Cf. PYñ 8.3 <foreign>hana vəsi riti tambaga matahi-tahi </foreign>“there are the rusty iron, bronze (? <foreign>riti</foreign>), [and] copper”; Tk 1.101b <foreign>makadi dhātu riti tambaga mvaṅ vəsi vaja rajata kañcan</foreign>a “especially the mineral, bronze, copper, and also iron, steel, silver, [and] gold”; TK 62.35 <foreign>dhātu vəsi riri (r. riti) tambaga salaka </foreign>“mineral, iron, bronze, copper, silver”<foreign>.</foreign></note> so that [she] mingles with our good family, so that [she] avoids calamity.</p></div>
.<div corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_22">
.<p corresp="#siksaKandangKaresian_22.01">This is for us to arrange our children’s marriage. They should not be matched<note>The word <foreign>dipitotohkən</foreign> is from <foreign>toh</foreign>, which in OJ has the meaning ‘stake (in game, gambling, wager, competition, combat); main stake (in combat)’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>toh</foreign> II). However, it seems that the meaning intended by the author is more related to OJ <foreign>taruh</foreign>, <foreign>anaruh</foreign> ‘to compete with, vie with, challenge’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>taruh</foreign>), so that in our context it can be rendered as ‘to match’. In MdS, the only related word is <foreign>bobotoh</foreign>, meaning ‘the pers. who leads in a cockfight or gambling’.
